SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes that in 1991 the Parliament of the Commonwealth unanimously enacted the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991 to promote a process of reconciliation between the indigenous and wider Australian communities;
(2)supports the concept of constructive reconciliation between the indigenous and wider Australian communities;

(3)in acknowledgment of this support, adopts the vision of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, namely, `a united Australia which represents this land of ours; values the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage; and provides justice and equity for all' as a vision shared by this Chamber; and

(4)invites Members and Senators of the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia to establish an organisation to advance the reconciliation process to be called Australian Parliamentarians for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

I move this motion today in an effort to seek to bring some balance back into the debate about the future of Aboriginal people in this country and the process of reconciliation. At the moment, the House is in the middle of a fairly intense debate on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. During the last sitting week when we were debating some of the clauses of that bill it was unfortunate that at times the debate became a bit acrimonious and words were used that were not particularly appropriate. Unfortunately, the debate tended to break down into a political fight between members of the government and members of the opposition. It was a great tragedy that debate on an issue as important as the future welfare of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the land acquisition fund, which is supported by the government and I understand by the opposition, broke down and resulted in such a level of acrimony.

PARA.TAB: Today I would like to talk about the vision of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, why it is an important vision and why this parliament and all its members should share that vision and commit themselves to it. This motion is being seconded by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), a member of the opposition, and I understand that opposition members will be supporting it. The important message to go to both the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people of this country is that the principle of Aboriginal reconciliation is supported by both sides of this House.

In 1991 I had the great privilege to participate in the debate when the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation legislation was adopted unanimously by this chamber and by the Senate. The debate was very positive and the government and the opposition can be proud of this significant bipartisan achievement for this House. It was the first time in eight years that this chamber had seen unanimous support for legislation affecting Aboriginal affairs. Until that point there had been a lot of bitterness and a lot of division within this parliament about what should occur in regard to Aboriginal affairs.

In 1991 a commitment was made by the then shadow minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), and the opposition to the concept of Aboriginal reconciliation. Those opposite worked closely with the government to achieve a structure that addressed their concerns as well as the principles of Aboriginal reconciliation.

Since then we have had a number of other political debates and a number of other issues, the most important of which was the decision of the High Court in Mabo and the government's response to that decision. The legislation that was introduced occasioned very bitter debate both in the broader Australian community and, at times, in this parliament. Unfortunately, the next stage of that debate—the land acquisition fund—has also seen us go down that path.

I know that there are genuine people on both sides of this parliament with deep felt convictions who have a sincere desire to achieve the best outcome for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this country. I do not think there is any argument that people on both sides of this parliament are committed to a better outcome and a better future for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Where we tend to disagree at times is on the processes required to achieve that better outcome. That is the essence of the debate about the land acquisition fund. The argument concerns the best process to achieve those improved outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

I do not want anyone to think that we on this side of the House have a monopoly on goodwill towards Aboriginals or that we are the only ones who are truly committed to Aboriginal people. I know that there are many people on the other side of this House who are similarly committed. I have worked with them closely as a member of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and in other forums. I understand their strongly held commitment.

The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is a reflection of the spirit of goodwill that exists across the whole Australian community because it has as members people from all sectors. The honourable member for Aston has been a strong spokesperson on Aboriginal issues in this parliament and is the opposition's representative on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

What we are talking about today is the vision that the council has adopted. When it was first established, the council had to try to explain to the people of Australia what was meant by the term `reconciliation' because the whole concept of the council originated from people starting to talk about the need for a treaty, the need for some form of document wherein the non-Aboriginal Australians negotiated with Aboriginal Australians for their occupation of this land.

We have gone far beyond that, to a point where we are now trying to reconcile a whole range of differences. Commissioner Elliott Johnston from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody summed up the challenge very aptly in chapter 38 of the report of the royal commission, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think that great patience is required, especially on the non-Aboriginal side. It is the non-Aboriginal society that created the division and sustained it over a long period of time; we cannot expect the Aboriginal people to respond quickly. The non-Aboriginal society and culture is evolving and changing and the Aboriginal people must be allowed to develop their own culture in their own ways; clearly there is scope for the two to interact in a fruitful and mutually fulfilling way. The process may falter at times; appear to get lost; but it can be pulled up again and survive if we are cool and negotiate with open minds and as with equals. And in the end, perhaps together, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, the situation can be reached where this ancient, subtly creative Aboriginal culture exists in friendship alongside the non-Aboriginal culture. Such an achievement would be a matter of pride not only for all Australians but for all humankind.

That is the challenge that the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation has set for us all. That is the challenge in which this motion is seeking to involve this House. Unfortunately, since the formation of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, we have gone off the track and we have lost that vision. We have tended to be bogged down in political arguments about processes rather than returning to the essential essence of the argument, which is to try to bring together those two important cultures, the non-Aboriginal culture and the Aboriginal culture, so that we as a society are walking together, as the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation so aptly titles its magazine. That is an important and essential element of the council. The vision seeks:
. . . a united Australia which respects this land of ours; values the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage; and provides justice and equity for all . . .

It is a commendable vision which I hope this House will adopt. I know that many people on both sides of this House will be prepared to work together to help the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to achieve that vision. When we establish the Australian Parliamentarians for Aboriginal Reconciliation, I hope that I will be able to say to this House after some months that we have a very broad representation of members from both sides.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

—I second the motion, Mr Speaker. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), mentioned, I am the coalition's representative on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. I acknowledge that the shadow minister, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), has given me the opportunity to be the first member on our side to speak in this debate on the motion of the honourable member for Moreton.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that, when the council was formed about 2 1/2 to three years ago, there were 25 of us at our first meeting—12 indigenous Australians, two people from the Torres Strait and 11 people from the broader community. Amongst those people from the broader community were many well-known names, including Ian Spicer from the business community, Jennie George from the ACTU, Ray Martin from television, Robert Champion de Crespigny from the mining industry and Rick Farley from the farming community. There was also a wide range of well-known and respected indigenous people who may not be as well known across the broader community but who are well known amongst their own people.

At that first meeting, we spent many hours trying to come up with our vision because it was important that it was right. We went through a process of iteration, but we then came up with a vision and a number of key issues. The vision of a united Australia is the key to what the council and reconciliation are all about. We want a united Australia; we do not want a country that is divided, regardless of whether it is between indigenous and non-indigenous people or in any other way. We all share this land and therefore we all have to respect it. It is not my land or your land; it is our land—and that includes the indigenous people. We have to value the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were here many tens of thousands of years before the Europeans came here. It is a valuable heritage that these days is beginning to be accepted by most people.

Finally, we have noted in our vision that we need to provide justice and equity for all. It is important to note the words `justice' and `equity'. All too often when we are talking about indigenous disadvantage—whether it be shortened life expectancy, over-representation in gaols or poor health, housing and education—we want not only equity for indigenous people in all of those matters as of right but also justice. That justice should exist not only in terms of their treatment in the court system, gaols and so on but also in terms of the dispossession of their land. So it is a very important vision that has tried to encompass all the aspects that are critical to the role that the council has undertaken in a 10-year time span.

The first council membership was appointed for three years, and that three years is very nearly up. In fact, on 17 November, the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation will be presenting its report to the Presiding Officers—to you, Mr Speaker and to the President of the Senate—in the Great Hall, giving an account of its stewardship for the first three years and detailing the many things it has undertaken to bring about reconciliation in our community.

There is no doubt that we have had some major challenges along the way. From my perspective, the Mabo debate was not helpful in bringing about reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people. It was a very divisive debate. But it was obviously a very fundamental decision from the High Court—something that was very important to indigenous people and something with which the broad community is coming to terms.

The mining community, which was very anti the native title legislation at the time, has accepted that it needed to take a different position and it now supports the legislation. The farming community has also accepted the legislation. Although it caused some division across the broad community, we have overcome the major hurdle and are moving along on a number of other fronts. It is worth noting that in private industry there are a number of examples of private companies going out of their way to ensure provision of the lifeblood of Aboriginal development—jobs and businesses. At a meeting of the council that I attended last week in Adelaide a number of such examples were given.

There have also been a number of interesting examples coming from local government to show that reconciliation is clearly becoming a very serious topic. For example, the Lord Mayor of Newcastle and his council have come up with a declaration acknowledging the very important contribution that Aboriginal people make in that part of the country and stating their willingness to work with them. Bunbury in Western Australia has done exactly the same thing within the last two or three weeks. The Ti Tree Council in the Northern Territory—a white council—went to the local Aboriginal council and suggested that they merge and operate as a single council for that part of the country. Those sorts of steps are very important in achieving Aboriginal reconciliation with the broader community. But they need to be repeated across the country, time after time.

Of course, many times the police are held to be the problem when it comes to getting on with the indigenous people. But there are some good stories. For example, recently at Ballina in New South Wales there was a situation where the local police and the Aboriginal community got together. Now, when somebody from the indigenous community gets into trouble, that person is not just locked up willy-nilly. The local community is contacted, someone comes along and the community takes care of its own. That means that Aboriginal people are not being locked up for quite minor offences, and that, of course, prevents deaths in custody and so on, flow-ons likely to result from imprisonment.

Early in the life of the council I was lucky to have the opportunity to make a small contribution when we had a meeting here in Canberra. We met with the Aboriginal community on the Friday night and heard about some of the problems with the police in Queanbeyan. There are three federal parliamentarians on the Aboriginal Reconciliation Council—Senator Margaret Reynolds from the government, Senator Cheryl Kernot from the Democrats and me. The three of us went to Queanbeyan and talked with the police and the local indigenous population and arranged for them to have meetings every two or three weeks, not on particular issues but to make sure that communication was kept going and that any problems were forestalled. It seems to me that those are the sorts of things that help the process very much.

It is interesting that in places such as Cape York in Queensland, which are often seen as hotbeds of racism and other problems—and they often are—there are cattlemen who are actively involved in helping indigenous people run their own cattle stations. In the mining industry, we have had the setting up of an organisation called J-Calm recently. Twelve managing directors of the biggest mining companies in the country and the leaders of the Aboriginal communities where they want to do the mining have, for the first time, sat down together and started to talk about their problems rather than negotiate via brickbats in the media. It seems to me that those sorts of steps are very positive. We have had similar activity in the rural sector.

The trade union movement has become actively involved. There has been a lot of activity in the media. People have been talking to media operators, editors and reporters and taking reporters out to some remote Aboriginal communities and letting them see the situation on the ground. Reporters need to talk not only to the Aboriginal communities but also to the non-Aboriginal communities and get both perspectives so that when the headlines come up they are not headlines that give a totally false impression or just the bad news. They will also be able to write articles that are balanced, sensible and reasonable so that we do not stir up hysteria in the broader population and we have a very informed debate on the various issues. We will not always agree, but it is important that we deal with the facts rather than emotion. There has been a massive program of consultation with indigenous communities to get their input as to what ought to happen with the process.

We have also set up an organisation called Australians for Reconciliation. Across the land, in community after community, small groups of people who want to be associated with the reconciliation process are setting themselves up to be known as Australians for Reconciliation. They will foster reconciliation in their local community. I could go on.

I believe that I perceive the start of a sea change in attitude in this country. Irrespective of whether one agrees with some of the details of the issues, public awareness about the plight of indigenous people and the disadvantaged is much greater. There is a desire to see those matters addressed and to bring about reconciliation. I urge the House to support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like previous members, I wholeheartedly support this motion before the House. I was not in the parliament when the original motion on reconciliation was passed, so I am very pleased to have the opportunity today to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson).

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), outlined the success stories of reconciliation. That process is continuing. The process of reconciliation does need some assistance at this time. This motion will do that. I will not go over them today, but some of the political events that have occurred in the last 18 months or so have certainly set back the process of reconciliation. Nevertheless, the process is a very worthwhile one. Obviously, I recognise the contribution of the opposition in its bipartisan support of the process of reconciliation.

I detect in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people some impatience in relation to reconciliation. We have to now look towards reconciliation as more of a grassroots process. If there is any criticism of what has happened so far, it is that it has been a little top heavy. There has certainly been a great deal of support from members of this parliament, representatives of industry and representatives of the Aboriginal community at a peak level. But the sort of thing that the previous member talked about in relation to local committees engendering some sort of community participation in reconciliation is obviously important. There is certainly scope for a greater degree of community participation.

One area we have to look at is cultural understanding. Schools are very important in that respect. In my electorate, a lot of reconciliation is obviously going on in the schools. Some schools which have children of European origin are participating in Aboriginal and Islander dancing. I wonder how much that happens in schools outside electorates like mine where there are no Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children.

The question of employment is a vital one which I do not think we can ignore. Although there has been support from the top levels of business, I think local business communities could participate. Rotary clubs and chambers of commerce could participate a little more. If this parliamentary committee is formed, it could do something about that.

In my electorate, one of the shared things that ought to be emphasised is the question of remoteness. The honourable member who preceded me in the debate, the honourable member for Aston, talked about the Cape York Peninsula. The remote Aboriginal communities on the Cape York Peninsula suffer the same adversity suffered by the European people on stations. Community groups are getting together and participating in the Cape York land use study. I pay special tribute to the Cape York Peninsula Development Association which, as part of that process and in other areas, is certainly putting forward the question of reconciliation. The parliament can play a key role in all of these matters.

In conclusion, I would like to mention an event which has just occurred—an act of reconciliation which has just been announced by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), that is, the John Koowarta Reconciliation Law Scholarship. It is a joint initiative by the federal government, the Law Council and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. By funding indigenous people to begin law studies each year and supporting the recipients through to completion of their degrees, the John Koowarta Reconciliation Law Scholarship aims to partially redress an acknowledged under-representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the Australian legal system. Obviously, that is welcome. It was very good to see Mr Koowarta's widow, Mrs Martha Koowarta, speaking very eloquently on behalf of the cause of Aboriginal people. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support this motion moved by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). It is a welcome motion which has already been passed by the majority of state parliaments. It has been passed by the Senate, the ACT Assembly, the Western Australian Assembly, the South Australian House of Assembly and the Tasmanian Legislative Council. It is certainly listed for introduction in the rest of the state parliaments. I think it is a very important symbolic gesture for both the federal and state parliaments. I compliment the council on the important work that it is doing in this area. I refer especially to the work of the chairman, Pat Dodson. I also thank the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), the previous shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, who has been the coalition's representative on the council, for the enormous amount of work he has done on the council, in concert, of course, with the other people whom he mentioned today.

PARA.TAB: I now make reference to the comments by the honourable member for Moreton which were said in a somewhat different tone to what was said last week. I congratulate the honourable member for his statements today. They are actually in stark contrast to the line taken by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner). I encourage the honourable member to talk to his minister and perhaps encourage the minister to take this sort of line.

I note that the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) are also in the chamber today. Perhaps they should listen to the honourable member for Moreton, having regard to their acrimonious contributions to the previous debate on the land fund bill. It would have been helpful to both the Aboriginal cause and those seeking reconciliation if those three members had looked at the goal rather than their immediate gain in making this a divisive political issue.

It has been a disappointment that those members chose to make this a divisive political issue because nobody gains from it. Perhaps the government does, but I think it is a poor gain in light of what is lost in the community. Members of the community as a whole, when they see division in this area, believe there is reason for division. That feeds on people who believe—and there are people in the community who believe—that too much has already been given to Aboriginal people. This is because they do not understand the issues. The last thing we need to do in parliament is to make them believe that they have reasons for their suspicions. The nature of the debate during the last sitting week, that was prompted by the government's response to the coalition's amendments, only fed prejudices in the community. I ask the government, as the debate continues today, to be sensible enough to change its tack on this.

In the few minutes remaining to me, may I say that Aboriginal people in Australia have suffered enormously because of ignorance and a whole host of factors that result from their dispossession of the land. Non-indigenous Australians have a very strong attachment to the land. We only have to see people who live on the land and to look at television reports of how strong their attachment is to their farms, which are now beset by drought, to know how much their land means to them. Aboriginal people have that same connection with their land, but theirs is also a spiritual and cultural connection. All the history of Aboriginal people is connected with their particular area of land. When they are dispossessed of that land, there are ramifications through their whole community—not just for particular individuals, but the whole community loses something that was the basis of how they came to be.

Returning to the land is one part of the healing process for many of those communities, but it is not the only healing part. As we would be aware from some of the shocking photographs and television documentaries we have seen, just returning to the land is not enough unless the resources are there to make sure that people who go back to the land have acceptable sanitation, clean water, housing and all those things that are necessary for a healthy lifestyle. At present, the health statistics in Aboriginal communities are a disgrace and a matter for shame for the whole of Australia. There are many other things that concern me in relation to Aboriginal affairs that I would like to talk about, but I shall leave those to another day. I commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be given the opportunity to speak in support of this motion moved by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) this afternoon. I commend him for his initiative in advancing the cause of reconciliation between this country's indigenous people and the wider Australian community. I also acknowledge his ongoing commitment in this place and in other areas where he has been very outspoken on this issue.

PARA.TAB: There can be no doubt that reconciliation in this country is one of the biggest issues we face, both now and in the future. The measures the government has been introducing over the last 18 months in response to the High Court's Mabo decision on native title have presented the first real opportunities we have had as a nation to address these important issues in a practical way. They will bring us together as a nation when all groups in this country can come forward to take their rightful places in this society.

This motion is about reconciliation and the ways we advance it, both here in this chamber and outside in the wider community. We have to accept that there is a generational element in the issues surrounding reconciliation, as well as a racial one. The hope for reconciliation in this country lies with young Australians, with the changing attitudes of older Australians, and with the commitment of both of these groups to the sense of unified nationhood.

Oodgeroo Noonuccal recognised the importance of future generations in the reconciliation process. I am reminded of an interview I saw on the ABC about a year before her death. She talked about the meetings she attended when various Aboriginal organisations in south-east Queensland came together. They would finish the meeting with a solemn toast—mind you, always with non-alcoholic drinks, she was careful to point out. The toast went:

SPEECH.PARA: To our Fathers,
The pain, the sorrow;
To our Children,
The Bright Tomorrow.

The bright tomorrow—that is what it is all about. The reality is that, to create that bright tomorrow, Australia has to acknowledge its Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage. This motion specifically calls for us to support heritage. I welcome this initiative because it is only by coming to a lasting understanding of Aboriginal and Islander cultures that have been neglected for so long that we will be able to achieve true reconciliation. This includes acknowledging the connections of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities to the land and the sea. Indeed, this was one of the eight key issues identified by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in its `Review of key issues' paper.

PARA.TAB: As Charles Perkins said recently at the Melbourne launch of the group Australians for Reconciliation, we have to get away from narrowing the focus to purely Aboriginal reconciliation. We should really speak in terms of Australian reconciliation, and broaden the terms of reference. Charles Perkins said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . reconciliation has to occur between white and white, and black and black, between individuals, communities and organisations before it can even start between black and white.

His point, of course, was that every Australian has an interest in reconciliation, and it cannot happen in isolation. We have to encourage means by which we can advance reconciliation on a wide scale. This vital ingredient is integral to the future Australia we all want to see. The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation has done an excellent job in starting this process, and I congratulate its members on their dedication.

PARA.TAB: The council has played a vital role in devising ways of lifting the reconciliation profile. No doubt all members of the House with an interest in this issue—and I would expect all members should have an interest in this issue—are eagerly awaiting the release of the council's report which will outline just how much has been achieved by its members since its formation three years ago.

One of its primary goals is to broaden the appeal of the reconciliation process to include as many sections of the Australian community as possible in a show of support. It has been very successful in doing this, as can be seen in the council's quarterly magazine, Walking Together, which the honourable member for Moreton mentioned earlier. I believe that it is these processes that will help reconciliation.

The motion before us today presents us with an opportunity to do just that. There is wide ranging support for reconciliation by supporting the creation of the group Australian Parliamentarians for Aboriginal Reconciliation. I certainly hope there are many prospective members of the group here today which, importantly, will give us a great opportunity to show real bipartisan support for reconciliation.

It is to be hoped that there will be more bipartisan support for this initiative than was exhibited during debate on the land fund legislation, as the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) mentioned earlier. The process has to be a two-way street: support also has to come from members of the opposition. It is all very well for the honourable member for Hindmarsh to get up and make accusations against the government, but a lot of the division highlighted in the debate on the land fund legislation actually came from the opposition.
I hope that all honourable members will support the proposal before us today. Once again, I congratulate the honourable member for Moreton on putting it forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion proposed by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). It is one of some significance and some importance. We talk so very easily of reconciliation—it is a word that trips off the tongue flowingly. According to the Macquarie Dictionary `reconcile' means:

SPEECH.PARA: to render no longer opposed; bring to acquiescence—
that is not really relevant—
to reconcile someone to his fate—
we do not want to do that either—
to win over to friendliness—
yes, certainly—
to reconcile a hostile person—
yes, that is acceptable—
to compose or settle (a quarrel, difference, etc.). 4. to bring into agreement or harmony; make compatible or consistent—

Most of those definitions, I think, are relevant and appropriate because we do want a situation where indigenous and non-indigenous Australians are no longer opposed. We want to win all Australians over to friendliness. We do want agreement between different groups in Australia. We do want harmony, and we do want different groups in Australia to be compatible.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to hear the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) quoting Charles Perkins who said that reconciliation was needed for Australians rather than for Aboriginals. That is a proposition which I accept and agree with totally because there is a need for reconciliation between blacks and blacks and whites and whites as well as between blacks and whites.

I support the call by the honourable member for Moreton for an organisation called Australian Parliamentarians for Aboriginal Reconciliation to be formed. I just sound one note of warning: if we are going to form yet another organisation, let us make sure the darned thing works and it is not just another factory for words. I know that the Aboriginal people that I know and represent and those that I am privileged to call friends are sick to death with the flow of words. I have to confess standing up here today that, in the time that I have been in this parliament and have spoken many times on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues, I have used an enormous number of words. Considering the state of our Aboriginal people over the last 200 years, there has been a great deal of improvement but, in recent times, not the improvement we want to see.

Those of us who are now in this chamber know what the situation is. We have visited Aboriginal communities not only in the outback but also in what one would call the most beautiful areas of Australia, in my electorate of Cowper. I see the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who is at the table, nodding. He should know; he comes from there. Standards of living for Aboriginal people in an area regarded as one of the most beautiful growth areas of Australia are still Third World. I come back to a familiar theme because it is one that I believe in wholeheartedly: we cannot divorce the issues of health, housing, education and employment. Unless we solve those problems, we can talk about reconciliation until the cows come home. Those solutions are what have to come.

We have the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. Mention has been made that the report is coming very soon. The honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) mentioned an organisation called Australians for Reconciliation. We even have the Australian Parliament Aboriginal awareness group. It has not met for quite a while; we had better stir the chairman up, I think. We have the native title committee of this parliament, a joint statutory committee, and now we are going to form another committee. I say to the House and to the honourable member for Moreton as the prime mover in this: it is a great idea, but let us get together and make this an effective instrument of improvement for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

I do appreciate the honourable member for Moreton's acknowledging that those on the government benches do not have a monopoly on care and awareness of the problem. There are many people on both sides of this parliament who are really caring, who are really sensitive and who want everything to improve for Aboriginal people. We must have reconciliation, we must have harmony and we must see all Australians living and working together for the benefit and the betterment of us all.

There are many people of goodwill on the opposition benches, and the member for Cowper is one. The member for Aston (Mr Nugent), the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), who will be speaking shortly on this motion, and the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), are others.

I make it clear that no-one from the opposition benches, particularly the shadow minister, who has a special responsibility in this area, will be allowed to get away with it. If she does not like it, she will just have to learn to bear it.

I commend the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), who is also the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. He is a very good chairman. I commend him and commend his motion. I support it and take on board, of course, what the member for Cowper said in connection with it. There is a need for us to make sure that we deliver when we establish arrangements of this kind. I know that when a motion is sponsored by a person like the honourable member for Moreton it will deliver because he has made sure that his own committee delivers. He has it working very well and it reflects his own personal commitment to questions of this kind.

I also want to commend the comments that were made by my two government colleagues the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) and the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd). I endorse their observations. The quotes that the honourable member for Oxley referred to were particularly relevant and particularly useful.

To a large extent this motion now picks up on a letter which Pat Dodson, the chairperson of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, sent to us all last year. Pat Dodson said that the Mabo case is `a landmark in the history of relations between indigenous and other Australians.' He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council—
that is the council for Aboriginal reconciliation—
sees the decision as an opportunity to effect lasting improvement in relations between indigenous and other Australians.
He went on to say:
This opportunity could be lost without an innovative and positive response from governments that recognises and builds upon the historic nature of the decision for the nation as a whole.
He said:
Your contribution—
that is my contribution and the contributions of the honourable members for Cowper, Aston, Grey and others—
to this response is vital.

Yes it is. The honourable member for Aston, the former shadow minister and one of those people whom I identified as having a genuine concern about this, is a member of that council and he undoubtedly endorsed that letter when it went out.

PARA.TAB: It is important that we carry out this process of reconciliation. I know that white Australians prefer to call what happened 206 years ago the settlement by Europeans in Australia. Aboriginal Australians, who saw themselves dispossessed, their land taken and shooting expeditions of Aboriginals conducted of a weekend, and those who were involved at Waterloo Creek—the episode that was so brilliantly presented by my friend Roger Milliss in his book of the same name—saw it as an invasion. Why would they not? Reconciliation is essential and this is an important stage in that process. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) talked about the definition of reconciliation. When I hear that word `reconciliation' and I think of the Aboriginal people I do not think of reconciliation, from my experience of Aboriginal people, in terms of an aggressive relationship. Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleary Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House, cognisant as it is of Australia's opposition to the economic exploitation of children, as expressed in Article 32 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, calls on the Government to enact legislation to prohibit the importation of goods produced by child labour.

SPEECH.PARA: In December 1990, Australia ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The convention came into force for Australia on 16 January 1991. Article 32 of the convention says:

1. States Parties recognise the right of the child to be protected from economic exploitation and from performing any work that is likely to be hazardous or to interfere with the child's education, or to be harmful to the child's health or physical, mental, spiritual, moral or social development.

2. States Parties shall take legislative, administrative, social and educational measures to ensure the implementation of the present article. To this end, and having regard to the relevant provisions of other international instruments, States Parties shall in particular:
a) Provide for a minimum age or minimum ages for admission to employment;
b) Provide for appropriate regulation of the hours and conditions of employment;
c) Provide for appropriate penalties or other sanctions to ensure the effective enforcement of the present article.

Often in this place, the view is expressed that we should not be a signatory to conventions and treaties that extend the power of the Commonwealth. This was not the case with the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill 1994, which was passed unanimously in this House and agreed to in another place. During the debate, one speaker after another made reference to article 34 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Article 34 states:

States Parties undertake to protect the child from all forms of sexual exploitation and sexual abuse. For these purposes, States Parties shall in particular take all appropriate national, bilateral and multicultural measures to prevent:
a) The inducement or coercion of a child to engage in any unlawful sexual activity;
b) The exploitative use of children in prostitution or other unlawful sexual practices;
c) The exploitative use of children in pornographic performances and materials.
In his second reading speech, the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) stated that Australia's ratification of the Convention on the Rights of the Child:

. . . imposes an obligation . . . at both the national and the international level . . . Australia played a key role in the development of the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Australian government is committed to pursuing the aims of that convention.
During the same debate the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) expressed his support for the use of the external affairs power. He stated:

PARA.TAB: The coalition has had considerable difficulty with the use of the external affairs power by recent Labor governments, which have engaged in the practice of entering into international treaties and using those treaties to expand the reach of Commonwealth power. I am pleased to say that in this case the coalition has no such difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly, Australia's obligations under the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which was used to defend legislation against the sexual exploitation of children, should also apply to the protection of children overseas who are exploited in an economic context. It is an unfortunate contradiction that those who speak the language of labour market reform will be the first to mount the stump in opposition to the sexual exploitation of children but the first to tell you that you have no right to interfere with the working conditions some exploitative bosses or rampant multinationals wish to foist on young children in the interests of increased profit. The member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) during the Crimes Amendment (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill debate said:
. . . children are being exploited or being managed by someone who benefits from that act of exploitation.

How do the custodians of morality distinguish between the child sex procurer or the child labour exploiting factory owner? Members of this House spoke strongly on the issue of sexual exploitation of children. The member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) gave us a very vivid account of the various forms of sexual abuse of some children—I almost had to turn the television off—and the member for Moore (Mr Filing) outlined the manner in which Westerners cynically exploit Asian children.

PARA.TAB: The question is: are we prepared to transfer our moral indignation to the arena of economic exploitation of children? Are we prepared to discuss the possibility that legislation prohibiting the importation of goods produced by child labour would encourage reform in those countries which currently exploit children? Or are we to follow the philosophy of the Lyons Forum and express moral outrage only when sex is involved?

While the House was debating the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Bill, the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions issued a report entitled, Child labour: the world's best kept secret. It estimated that over 100 million children between the ages of four and 15 are exploited as cheap, compliant labour. In order to carry out its campaign against child labour, the ICFTU asked its affiliates and other trade unionists around the world to carry out research into child labour in their own countries. This report contains field studies from India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Mexico and the Philippines, and further reports in Colombia, Brazil and Peru will follow. According to the ICFTU, these field studies were carried out in the face of opposition from employers, as we would expect.

In Nepal, where the use of child labour in the carpet industry is notorious, there is no child protection act. This is despite a constitution which stipulates that `children shall not be employed in factories, mines or similar hazardous work'. The ICFTU provided a litany of cases of exploitation of children in sweatshops.

In the Philippines, where the constitution forbids the employment of children younger than 15 except under the responsibility of parents or guardians, the ICFTU field study examined the workings of a German textiles multinational which produces bras, girdles, panties and bikinis. Like some Australian companies, the company is attracted to the Philippines where child labour provides low wages. Of course, as the study discovered, reputable companies do not employ child labour directly but contract work to local firms and ask no questions. These firms employ child labour themselves or subcontract the work again. Some children start working at the age of four.

The accounts of economic exploitation and abuse of children found in the ICFTU report call for a response from this parliament. If honourable members are prepared to overcome the legal problems involved in legislating against sexual exploitation of children, then they should have the courage to challenge the economic exploitation of children.

If the disciples of free trade want to blow their trumpet about the low priced imports Australian consumers can buy once tariffs are lowered or removed, they should examine the conditions under which these goods are made. How can the rights of Australian workers be protected on a level playing field which signals to Australian industry that to be competitive in the production of, for instance, underwear they ought to take advantage of child labour?

After the Wills by-election, various Australian manufacturers told me that the only way they could survive with lower tariffs was to go offshore. Many did not want to do that. If Australians go overseas to sexually exploit children, the Australian parliament goes further than moral outrage and legislates for penalties of up to 17 years imprisonment. If an Australian manufacturer goes overseas and employs people who abuse and exploit children, the free market worshippers put a medal on its chest.

The UNICEF publication, First Call for Children—hardly a left wing propaganda rag—in its October-December 1993 issue described the bonded labour system as `one of the most virulent forms of modern slavery'. In India, the Bonded Labour Liberation Front, the BLLF, is active. It argues that poverty is not only a cause of child labour but a result. Kailash Satyarthi, chairperson of SACCS, describes it this way:

SPEECH.PARA: As long as children work, they will remain uneducated. They are losing their eyes, their lungs and different parts of their bodies. And so they will remain a liability for their nation. They can never become an asset.

Sometimes attempts at rectifying economic exploitation in Third World countries are countered with the claim that it is a form of cultural imperialism. This is a claim that needs to be taken seriously. However, it must be understood that the claim that removing children from an industry or a workplace will cause hardship to poor households is rejected by unionists in these countries.

PARA.TAB: In an article in the Far Eastern Economic Review, dated 9 July 1992, Hamish McDonald cites the criticism of B.N. Juyal. Juyal argues that child workers not only displace adult workers but depress the incomes of adults doing similar work. According to Hamish McDonald:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the main impetus for change comes from implicit threats of import bans by consumer countries.
The Australian parliament must consider this path. Section 8 of the International Confederation of Free Trade Union's campaign against child labour suggests we begin:

. . . by campaigning against the most serious abuse and exploitation of children in the sex industry and in manufacturing, mining and construction, especially where these are limited to exports and international tourism.
In Bangladesh the textile exporting industry association, under threat of losing the US market, is pressuring its affiliates to come into line with Bangladesh legislation on child labour.

PARA.TAB: In India, Pakistan and Nepal a labelling system is being introduced which identifies carpets not made by child labour. This issue has been taken up by the ACTU President, Martin Ferguson. Mr Ferguson gave his and the ACTU's support for the ICFTU proposal to include a social clause in GATT. At the same conference, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of all the forms of exploitation and abuse which the ILO strives to combat none is more serious than child labour.

Let us see some legislation. Economic integration will undoubtedly bring many benefits to Australia; it could also bring many problems. Dr Rob Lambert of the University of Western Australia states in a letter to me today:
Tragically for Australia, our free market policy planners refuse to acknowledge any impact of this political and social construction of the Asian working class on the Australian economy and society.
Our research is revealing a two fold effect.
1)Rightless, exploited teenagers in Asia are accelerating the relocation of production out of Australia, as Australian based manufacturers seek to take advantage of this `opportunity';
2)Companies that remain are intensifying labour to an extreme degree in an effort to try to maintain relatively competitive unit labour costs.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) for raising in the House this very important and serious matter. It is not a matter that can be ignored by governments. The 1992 ILO report clearly indicated that the number of children working in the world is growing, and not just in absolute terms but in terms of younger age groups. The ILO estimates that there are between 100 million and 200 million children working in the world today. It is estimated that in Asia and some Western countries 25 per cent of children between the ages of 10 and 14 are working in illegal or dangerous conditions.

PARA.TAB: I think it is worth quoting to the honourable member for Wills the full quotation from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). He does say:

SPEECH.PARA: Of all the forms of exploitation and abuse which the ILO strives to combat none is more serious than child labour.
However, he goes on to say:

The ILO's Minimum Age Convention comprehensively deals with the issue of child labour. All countries which ratify the Convention undertake to ensure the effective abolition of child labour, and to progressively raise the minimum age for admission to work.
In 1992 the ILO launched an International Program on the elimination of Child Labour . . . includes three types of actions:

PARA.TAB: .the adoption of urgent measures to end the employment of children who are very young or in hazardous occupations or working under conditions of slavery;
.information and awareness measures which try to change attitudes; and
.measures which target the underlying causes of child labour—poverty, unemployment, inadequate social protection and educational systems.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say that he has asked his department to closely monitor the ILO's program to eliminate child labour and consider the possible means by which we may be able to contribute to this program. This motion is timely. It is only right and proper that the House is considering it today. Many commentators, I guess, including the honourable member for Wills, would point out that right wing policies, the policies of the IMF and the World Bank, and austerity measures leading to the diminution of the safety net and social security measures, as well as the general deregulation movement, are the direct causes of the growth of child labour.

PARA.TAB: These matters cannot be ignored. I do not want to sweep those arguments under the carpet, but I think this is part of a broader debate in relation to free trade and GATT. The problem is serious and has to be addressed. It has to be addressed by governments; it has to be addressed as soon as possible.

It is true to say that there has been increased publicity in relation to the problem of child labour. There has been a recent ABC radio program and an SBS program; there has been a bill introduced into the US Senate; and there is also article 32 of the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. The numerous instances of child labour across the globe, affecting children as young as six years—not only in the developing world but also in places such as Portugal, the United States and Russia—should concern every member of this House.

In our electorates we all celebrate the International Year of the Family, but how can we honestly celebrate the year of the family yet tolerate the growing instances of child labour across the globe? How can we ignore the carpet weaving and glass making industries in India and Pakistan, industries which use children as young as six years? It is estimated that there are 44 million children in child labour in India alone. How can we ignore the estimate of over 100,000 children working as domestic servants in Haiti, children who receive little or no pay, who have no education and no control over their daily lives? How can we ignore the children working in the underground coalmines in Colombia and the gold mines in Peru, the children working amongst hazardous and noxious fumes in the leather industry in Egypt or the children used as forced labour in infrastructure projects in Burma?

The literature indicates that the majority of children in forced and child labour are in the agricultural industry. There are also instances of children being used as sex workers. The effect on the health of the children who work long and hard hours, often at night, is appalling. Reports on the carpet factories in Pakistan in 1991 estimated that half of the 50,000 bonded children in that industry did not reach the age of 12. They are victims of malnutrition and work related disease.

A WHO report on child workers cites other physical health hazards including bone lesions and postural deformity, attributable to such work as carpet weaving, embroidery and lifting heavy weights. Young growing bodies suffer from strain when overloaded since the bone structure, especially the spine, is soft. The eyesight of young girls working 12 to 14 hours a day in micro-computer factories or embroideries is reported to be damaged within five to eight years.

The earning power of these children is low. Children in Indonesian light bulb factories work eight hours a day, six days a week and earn the equivalent of $US3 a week. Children in Nepalese carpet factories get $1 a day or less. The effect on the education of these children is devastating. Some of the children are in education. They work all night, then go to school during the day. I do not know how effective that is. And most of them do not go to school at all. The primary school drop-out rate in Bangladesh is 80 per cent. What is the solution to the problem? I do not reject in any way the option put up by the honourable member for Wills, but the matter has to be taken further on a broader plane.

Action cannot be taken only by government. The role of non-government organisations is vital. The trade union movement, certainly in the West, has a role to play, but Australian business also should apply ethical standards. That is why I am interested to hear what the coalition has to say in relation to this motion, because business does have a role to play. The ACTU, under the leadership of Martin Ferguson, has, rightly, been taking an aggressive stance on these issues.

The ACTU and the ICFTU are working towards a social clause to ensure the right to free, independent trade unions and established standards and conditions, including the prevention of child labour, to be written into the GATT and the new General Agreement on Trade in Services. These rights must be spelt out. They cannot be embodied in some sort of bland, motherhood statement, if I might use that term; they have to be enforceable. There is also a move to include the rights of workers in the policies and programs of the IMF and the World Bank.

The difficulty is that child labour is nominally outlawed in most of the countries where abuse takes place. Enforcement is expensive and is quite often left to the NGOs and organisations similar to those referred to by the honourable member for Wills in his speech. Action has to be taken by Western governments like the Australian government.

The honourable member referred to banning imports produced by child labour. Another approach may be to introduce labelling guaranteeing that goods have not been produced by exploited children. A similar measure was introduced by the US Senate's Child Labour Bill, which forced every import in the US to carry a licence saying that the product was not made by child labour.

There is no denying the need for action. The ILO is progressing and the government has indicated, as instanced by my earlier quote, that the minister is open to options. This motion strengthens that. We certainly should be looking at a wide range of options. I conclude my remarks with a quote, which I think sums up what should be the feeling of the House, from the Director-General of the ILO, Mr Michel Hansenne:

SPEECH.PARA: Childhood is a period of life which should be devoted not to work, but to education and training; child labour, by its very nature and the working conditions in which it is carried out, often compromises children's potential to become productive and useful adults in society; finally, the use of child labour is not inevitable, and progress toward its elimination is possible wherever there is political will to oppose it with determination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) is to be congratulated on raising this motion. He is doing what a Labor government and a feeble trade union movement should have done years ago. It is to our shame and to the government's `Neville Chamberlain' approach to Asia and uncritical acceptance of World Bank economic fundamentalism that it has not been raised before. It has taken other Western countries, such as the United States and France, to put the question of labour standards and workers' rights in relation to trade rules on the international agenda.

PARA.TAB: From the beginning of the industrial revolution, capitalism has sought to exploit labour. The history of labour market conditions has been horrific at every level. Slavery, children in mines, forced labour for illiterate women—the story and its horrors are endless. No avenue of exploitation has been left unexplored. No means that could reduce labour costs have been left untouched. Any attempt to provide humane and fair working conditions has been fought relentlessly at every stage.

In the fight to eliminate slavery in Britain around 1800 it was argued that if Britain renounced slavery other countries would seize an economic advantage. Similarly, every reduction of working hours has been opposed. The same arguments were used to justify horrific working conditions, particularly for children and women. The same historical struggle is true of exploitation of the environment. Through a variety of interventions over the last 200 years most of the worst examples of exploitation have been removed in industrialised countries, although much remains to be done.

The 1980s, however, saw a giant leap backwards through the doctrine of economic fundamentalism and free trade. Deregulation and free trade aim to locate manufacturing in the lowest cost countries and export freely to the world operating within a framework of authoritarian, largely corrupt governments with minimal labour and environmental standards. As a result, an even more horrific version of the labour market conditions and environmental degradation of early 19th century industrialised countries is now being replicated in the Third World.

Aided by authoritarian regimes, the industrial revolution of the West has been telescoped into a decade. Massive urbanisation, shantytowns, sulfurous landscapes, horrendous pollution and appalling working conditions are now the norm throughout Asia, Africa and Latin America. While the motion before the House focuses on child labour, it is only one symptom of the regression to unbridled exploitation inherent in the myth of free trade.

The economic fundamentalists will sneer at the relatively `new found concern' of the West for the labour conditions of children. They will, like their 19th century predecessors, argue every esoteric position, from interference with national sovereignty to character assassination, to avoid any interference with the free market or the use of trade policy to ameliorate Third World industrial practices. Equally, they will do and say anything to avoid responsibility and anything which would hamper unchecked profits for multinational firms.

Western governments have every right and responsibility to raise the issues of child labour and manufacturing conditions, not only for humanitarian reasons. The social, economic and environmental effects of Third World industrial and labour practices are not confined to national boundaries, and Western governments have a responsibility for the growing underclasses in their own countries resulting from deregulated free trade.

It is not as if economic fundamentalism and an integrated world economy are magically and rapidly improving Third World conditions. Any dispassionate examination shows it is creating unbelievably obscene disparities in wealth. Recent studies in Indonesia show that women are paid less than subsistence wages—less than 30 per cent of the cost of basic daily needs. Real living wages have dropped by over 50 per cent in the past 10 years.
In December 1993, the publication Inside Indonesia in an article entitled `The Unknown Industrial Prisoner' stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the poor families of Indonesia are subsidising with their health and their money, the large corporations and foreign ventures.

The fact is that all trade, both internal and external, must proceed on agreed and fair rules. The efforts, however imperfect, to establish such rules in Australia over the last 200 years and in other countries cannot be thrown out in the name of free trade. International Labour Organisation standards must be enforced irrespective of national boundaries. The alternative is a reversion to the beginnings of the industrial revolution, with a growing underclass in Western economies, and entrenching massive disparities in wealth and horrendous conditions in the Third World with an accelerated global environmental crisis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the member for Wills (Mr Cleary) for raising this particular issue. It is timely. It is timely in the sense that the rather deregulationist conservative Economist magazine stated on 9 April this year:

SPEECH.PARA: Social dumping will challenge environmental protection as the issue most likely to force radical change on the global trading system.

In an international sense, the unequal competition between nations which arises from the exploitation of children and the absence of internationally recognised labour conditions is a system of unfair trade. It is all right to have a large amount of rhetoric about access to markets and about integrating with Asia. However, that has to be seen in the context of the competition that workers in this country will face and the way in which child labour in a variety of countries is exploited.

PARA.TAB: We have heard accounts of the Indian carpet industry, Nepal's textile industry, Colombia's mines and Brazil's mines. All of those nations have, despite their supposed adherence to a number of international conventions, failed to act in relation to this matter. This matter is timely, particularly when it involves a country close to our door. This week the Indonesian government will put on trial the leader of the independent trade union movement, Mr Muchtar Pakpahan.

In the case of Indonesia itself, one of the countries that we are supposedly to enhance our relationship with, four million children are at work within its factories. In the Tangerang industrial complex, in the 1,200 factories surveyed one-third of the 92,000 workers are aged between nine and 14 years. So not only is this matter timely on the world scale as we talk about international trade negotiations but it is timely in the region.

I do not say that the answer suggested by the member for Wills is the total solution. It is interesting to note at the moment that Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has introduced into the US Senate a measure which would see the Secretary of Labor list foreign industries around the world which utilise child labour.

He would then, under this legislation, list the respective host nations of those industries using child labour; measure the degree of exports from those industries into the US market; prohibit imports from those industries that have exploited child labour; and allow importers to get a certificate from an independent authority to monitor that those particular companies have made endeavours to ensure that child labour is not utilised. The legislation would then require efforts by the US President to ensure that America's action would not be one out: to ban those countries and industries that do not have the required labelling. As well as that, US companies would face criminal and civil penalties for failure to adhere to these requirements.

There is an international focus on this issue. We have had reference to the International Labour Organisation. Its articles clearly work against child labour throughout the world. The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions is obviously at the moment instigating a very strong campaign to ensure that a large number of countries around the world ratify these accords. It is interesting to note that the International Labour Organisation has received 50 million deutschmarks from the German government for a variety of measures in particular countries.

Indian Prime Minister Rao in April this year made the rather ridiculous comment that the international focus against child labour, particularly in his own country, was `an alibi for raising protectionist trade barriers'. Whilst he did make that rather ridiculous analysis of those people who were concerned at the servitude and bondage of nine-, 10- and 15-year-olds in his country, it is pleasing to see that India, along with Turkey, Brazil, Indonesia, Kenya and Thailand, has at least acceded to being part of this ILO test program to try to ensure, by extending compulsory or free education, that children are given an option other than being forced into work.

One of the interesting comparisons given in India is that the state of Kerala, which alone has free and compulsory education, has a very small level of child labour whereas in Tamil Nadu, which is next door, the situation is that basically anyone under the age of 15 is in a factory for 40 to 60 hours a week. This has to be the focus. The member for Wills is not saying that he has the total answer. There is a variety of measures—national legislation, international agreements and boycotts—which have to be tackled. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no justification for the exploitation of child workers and the Australian government must do all it can to end child labour. I am certainly not suggesting that children should not work. I support the notion of children helping around the home and on the family farm and admire the teenagers who work for a few hours each weekend to help supplement the family income. However, the term `child labour' refers to something very different. It is used to refer to the exploitation and abuse of children as workers. When a child's right to education, to health, to dignity—perhaps even to youth—is extinguished by long hours of work under poor conditions and for little pay, then this child is a child labourer.

PARA.TAB: The nature of child labour is such that it is largely invisible to statisticians. Most child labourers do not work in the official economy. They are unpaid labourers on the family farms; they are working illegally in small manufacturing; they are working on the streets selling newspapers, chewing gum, matches and their bodies. However, other examples of child labour can be quite visible. The use of children in the carpet factories of India and on the tobacco plantations of Zimbabwe is perfectly plain to see. The impact on children of this form of abuse is profound. Frequently, young bodies cannot sustain the duration and intensity of tasks and children succumb to malnutrition and disease. Even if they survive, the life chances of these children are severely limited.

As a member of the international community into which these children have been born, Australia has a responsibility to concern itself with their welfare. I understand what has motivated the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) to call for this legislation, which prohibits the importation into Australia of goods produced by child labour. I congratulate him for raising this matter today. However, I do not believe that such legislation would be effective. A ban on the importation of goods produced by child labourers would not have any significant impact on the overall prevalence of child labour. With a few notable exceptions, child labourers are not involved in producing exportable goods. For children servicing the domestic economy, the trade sanctions that are being suggested would have no impact; indeed, I suggest that trade sanctions may exacerbate the poverty that is among the root causes of child labour.

Child labourers are invariably the victims of necessity. Their families are poor. They do not have enough shelter or food. They do not have education. They are working to help their families survive. By constructing barriers to trade between the developing and the developed worlds, we are consolidating the poverty that causes child labour. While there are occasions on which it may be appropriate to use trade sanctions to enforce internationally agreed upon human rights standards, it is entirely counterproductive to use trade sanctions when the human rights abuses being targeted have an economic rather than a political cause.

There are lessons to be learnt from the recent United Nations population conference in Cairo. We have known for many years that we must curb the rate at which the world population is growing. In the past, the developed world's response to this problem has been to either turn a blind eye or hand out contraceptives. In Cairo a new approach to international action was adopted. The need to increase the decision making power of women—a power which has both a social and an economic dimension—was acknowledged. Future efforts will be directed towards giving women the resources to take control of their bodies. The problems of child labour must be addressed in a similar fashion. Child labourers work to survive. If we are to help these children, we must address the economic and social context which determines their lifestyles.

While I cannot support the motion put by the member for Wills, I share his concern in seeing that Australian laws and actions are consistent with the international standards set out in the UN Declaration of the Rights of the Child. My former colleague and friend Andrew Peacock said in this place on 21 February 1991 that, if the coalition had been in government at that time, it would have ratified the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. On several occasions my actions in this House have been inspired by this convention. I am referring specifically to my call for the practice of female genital mutilation to be outlawed in Australia and also to my support of legislation to outlaw participation in child sex tours by Australians.

In conclusion, while unable to support the motion to outlaw the importation of goods produced by child labour, this parliament must endeavour to act in accordance with the standards set out in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child. However, legislation prohibiting the importation of goods produced by child labour will not automatically achieve this end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion moved by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary). I support the motion and congratulate the honourable member. At the dawn of the 21st century, in an age of computers and robots on production lines, society still accepts that millions of children sacrifice their childhood, health and future by working in jobs that they are not strong enough to do.

PARA.TAB: It is an absolute scandal that we have child labour. I believe it is a scandal to find in some of the stately homes in Australia carpets that have been made by small children's hands. Late last year, the honourable member for Wills and I visited Nepal, Bangladesh and India. One day when we were in Nepal I remember the honourable member for Wills getting out of the bus and running into a very dark factory. He came back quite shaken and told us about looms going up two and three floors on which children were working with their fingers.

The argument that people put—an argument which was constantly put to us in India and Nepal—is that children work in such conditions so that the family can live. This was exactly the same argument put 200 years ago about children going down coalmines. It was the same argument put about sending kids up chimneys to sweep chimneys. It is an argument that we have to come to terms with. As the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) said, we have to come to terms with this practice. It involves more than just banning it; it is a whole socioeconomic argument.

We have taken the bit by the teeth on the exploitation of children for sex. We have passed legislation unanimously in this House. There was bipartisan support. We should be doing exactly the same with child labour. I remember sitting in the homes of the two leading Indian human rights lawyers. When the honourable member for Wills raised this question, the learned gentleman pointed to his own carpet and said, `Carpet such as this would be denied people. People would be denied the right to eat if we banned these children from working.' That is an argument that we cannot and must not accept.

The honourable member for Wills has taken a strong stand on this matter. I urge him to go even further and introduce a private member's bill into this parliament. People stand up in this parliament and make speeches about all sorts of things. Morality is in great abundance in this place. Raise anything about sex and everyone wants to speak. Child labour is an issue of morality. I urge the honourable member to bring a private member's bill into this place and we will see where the major parties—my own party and the opposition—stand. I am sure that there would be unanimous support for the bill.

It is wrong that these children are denied their future. They are being exploited and we in the developed world are gaining the benefits from the work they do. I totally reject the argument that families will starve unless these children continue to work. It is true, though, as the honourable member for Adelaide has said, that it is no good just standing up here and passing pious resolutions and introducing private members' bills. We have to take progressive steps. The honourable member mentioned the Cairo conference. I attended the Cairo conference and I hope that any legislation and debate will not be as tortuous as that fortnight.

I believe that this is an issue for which there would be bipartisan support. It is an issue of morality. It is time we did something about it. I believe that, as a first step, we should ban the importation of goods made by child labour, or at least require that those goods have a label, as Germany and the United States are moving to do, so that we know exactly what it is that we are importing. If we want to purchase goods made by child labour, that should be on our consciences and documented for us to see.

I support the banning of these goods. Unlike the honourable member for Adelaide, I think that it would have some benefit, as has occurred with the sanctions, which are rarely criticised, that we put against South Africa. Those sanctions had a benefit; so would this.
