SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1)recognises the work done by successive governments over the past 25 years to clean up the River Murray Basin and catchment area; and
(2)calls on the present Government to make accelerated catchment area clean-up a priority project to:
(a)mark the centenary of federation;
(b)recognise the essential role the River Murray has in Australia's future economic success; and
(c)make the assiduous use of irrigation water and the upgrading of existing drainage and effluent schemes a priority.

It is dry. I am not talking about my speech or any of the preceding speeches in the House of Representatives. The simple reality is that 1994 happens to see Australia gripped by what could well be an economically disastrous drought. With the exception of the south-east corner of the continent, much of the nation is gripped by drought. In the case of my own state, South Australia, its outlook is not as grim as that of New South Wales and Queensland, but even in South Australia many farmers are on a knife edge. Much of the west coast of South Australia looks like facing a situation where, even if it rained, they would be denied this year's crop. That, of course, is nothing like as precipitous as the case that exists in Queensland, where so much of that state is currently experiencing its third year of drought.

PARA.TAB: This motion serves to highlight the dependence that our nation has on any water source and, in the case of the south-eastern corner of our nation and the states of southern Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, the total dependence of the nation and those states on the River Murray for water of quality.

As a South Australian, I have a particular interest in the Murray and in the quality of the Murray water. I find it a very sobering reality that there are times when as much as 50 per cent of suburban Adelaide's water is sourced out of the Murray and that, in times of particularly high demand and particularly low rainfall when Adelaide's own reservoirs are run down, as much as 80 per cent of its water can for a brief time be sourced from the Murray. Add to that the simple reality that the Spencer Gulf cities, much of my own electorate in the mid-north of South Australia, and the Yorke Peninsula are dependent on the Murray and we see why South Australians are so concerned about the state and quality of the water available to them.

This is not a parochial motion. The importance of the Murray Basin to everyone in Australia cannot be overestimated. The simple fact is that the Murray Basin makes up one-third of the agricultural output of this nation. It occupies one-seventh of our surface area but it happens to be host to 25 per cent of the cattle and dairy herds in Australia, 50 per cent of the sheep and 75 per cent of the irrigated land. As a result of the relative prosperity of the Murray-Darling Basin, $10 billion a year is generated from crops in those regions.

I am asking in this private member's motion for the government to consider making a clean-up of the River Murray and its basin a priority for the centenary of Federation. I do this on good authority. I notice that in the committee chaired by the Hon. Joan Kirner, which was set up to recommend various projects to the present government for the centenary of Federation, the Premier of South Australia, Mr Brown, recommended—and his sentiments were endorsed—that a clean-up of the Murray-Darling Basin ought to be one of the ways we go about celebrating our centenary of Federation.

I would like to suggest a couple of projects that I think the government could usefully embrace as it endeavours on behalf of all Australians to undertake an environmental initiative that we can all applaud. I mention the first of those projects because I am a South Australian, but it is not a project that solely benefits South Australia. I would like to suggest that the government consider expanding the freshwater research facilities that currently exist at Albury-Wodonga so that a sublaboratory can be set up somewhere west of the Darling inflow—I nominate Mildura because it is not in South Australia and I therefore do not seem quite so parochial—to monitor the quality of the water that flows into South Australia after the Darling has met the Murray. I make that point because Captain Sturt, in his diary in 1853, noted and expressed concern at what scientists today believe was a blue-green algal bloom at the confluence of the Murray and Darling rivers.

The particular concern being felt by all Australians, and particularly by South Australians, is that in a year as dry as this we have the potential for an enormous blue-green algal outbreak right on our doorstep. If we are to monitor blue-green algal blooms and find appropriate control measures, we need research to be done in Albury-Wodonga at the Murray-Darling Freshwater Research Institute as is being done now but also to be duplicated further down the river where clearly the chemical composition and characteristics of that water have changed markedly as it has made its way through the states of both New South Wales and Victoria.

I am in fact chairman of a committee looking at the feasibility of such a facility, and the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest), who is in the chamber, is the deputy chairman of that committee. In a bipartisan sense, we have endeavoured to approach all of the state governments likely to be affected to seek some funding for an expanded role for the freshwater institute at Albury-Wodonga. I would like to put a similar plea through the parliament to the government of the Commonwealth of Australia. I have written to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and clearly, as you would expect, I have written to the Hon. Joan Kirner recommending that this sort of facility be established so that not only can South Australians have a technique for monitoring the water that flows into South Australia but real work can be done in blue-green algal control which would have particular impact for those people who live on the Darling.

This year, with river flows as low as they are and with the Darling effectively stationary, we have a great deal to be concerned about in terms of what, as I said earlier, may be potential blue-green algal blooms. Frankly, governments at the state and Commonwealth level need to be seen to be very diligent in monitoring those blooms. Part of that diligence would be the expansion of the existing work of the Albury-Wodonga freshwater research facility by the establishment of a laboratory somewhere west of the Darling inflow. I think that laboratory would allow us to monitor much more carefully the useful control mechanisms for blue-green algae, particularly as much of the research work has already been done and now needs to be modified to suit the river as it changes as a result of the Darling's inflow.

Secondly, it would be appropriate to look seriously at cleaning up the Murray-Darling Basin, to consider what is currently happening as a result of sewage inflows into the Murray-Darling. I am not here apportioning blame, because these various sewerage schemes were set up under a range of governments, but it is a simple fact that the majority of the pollution in the Murray-Darling Basin occurs as a result of sewage treatment works which are either still located on the flood plain or discharge part of their treated sewage into the Murray or Darling systems. It has been estimated that up to 70 per cent of the pollution in the Murray-Darling Basin occurs as a result of sewage inflows. Given that there are a number of major sewerage plants discharging effluent into the river and given the number of plants that still have evaporation basins on the flood plains, there is a desperate need for a national perspective on effectively cleaning up these sewage plants and locating them away from the river.

Along with the member for Mallee, I have seen much of the work that has been done in the Sunraysia region. It is very much to the credit of the Mildura irrigation trust that there has been an effective sewage treatment works established for all of Mildura's sewage treatment well away from the river and that this treated sewage water is now being used to grow native trees on, from memory, about 200 acres. The area is larger than 200 acres, but about 200 acres is planted with native trees on drippers taking up this sewage water. I am familiar with a similar project that exists at Loxton. These projects have been undertaken by a concerned local community. I think this is the sort of thing that needs to be done across the entire basin, if we are serious about having a cleaned up basin with which to celebrate the centenary of Federation.

I stand not in criticism of the government. Much is being done now to reduce salinity in the Murray. As a Murray River irrigator, I think I get better quality water now than I did 20 years ago. We ought not be too despondent about the state of the river. The centenary of Federation gives us a great opportunity to push that project further. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I rise to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I agree with him that the work already done to clean up the Murray-Darling and its catchment has been laudable. I also agree that more needs to be done. However, being parochial—and the honourable member was trying not to be, but I will be—I have to say that a waterways project such as that proposed to mark the centenary of Federation should not be limited to the Murray-Darling. We should use the expertise gained from the environmental management of the Murray-Darling and apply it to all of our waterways—with particular reference, of course, to the Hawkesbury-Nepean catchment.

PARA.TAB: This House last year debated a bill to revise the agreement that exists between the Commonwealth and three state governments for the management of the Murray-Darling Basin. That agreement developed from arrangements set in place as early as 1914 for regulating the supply of water to downstream parts of the basin. I think that agreement is a highly significant political and administrative achievement.

Bill Hayden once said that the principles of environmental law challenge the existing notions of private property rights because they deal with things that occur over large areas unrelated to property boundaries or with things that flow from place to place. He could well have said that familiar political rights are similarly challenged by the demands of environmental management.

The business of government has traditionally been about management of contrived divisions of the land—states, shires and cities bounded by lines drawn with little or no reference to the natural features of the land or to the living systems in place. Those contrived divisions have generated rivalries and disjunctions that place enormous obstacles in the way of sound environmental management. The Murray-Darling agreement shows that we are learning to transcend those traditional impediments. Although it has taken us a long time to see the damage we have done to the river system, we now have an effective tool for the enormous task of restoring it, where possible, and implementing sustainable practices for the use of its resources.

As the member for Macquarie, I have watched with close interest the operations of the Murray-Darling Basin agreement. The Hawkesbury, which is in my electorate, is the next-door neighbour of the Murray-Darling. I am very interested to see how it is going about fixing its problems and what it is using to do it. The most obvious thing that the Hawkesbury has in common with the Murray-Darling is that the need for restoration and sustainable future management have become critical. Unlike the Murray-Darling, however, the Hawkesbury has no history of overall catchment management systems or agreements.

A trust for management of part of the Hawkesbury has been established by the New South Wales government, and there are great expectations for what that body may achieve. I believe that past and future experiences of the Murray-Darling will be important for the Hawkesbury trust and I hope that the lessons learnt in one catchment are carried across into the other wherever they are appropriate.

The Murray-Darling system covers one-seventh of the land area of the continent. The rivers are under stress because of the demands arising from the scale and diversity of land uses within such a huge area. The Hawkesbury catchment is much smaller, but the river is under extreme stress because it embraces the inexorably sprawling Sydney metropolitan area. My electorate covers some of the most vulnerable and worst affected sections of the river—the sections where it flows through the soft alluvial plain. Those are the places where settlement and development have been concentrated and where the greatest demand occurs for future urban growth.

Two hundred years of agricultural use have left the catchment generally denuded of its original native forest cover. Despite pronouncements by Governor Macquarie, the banks were cleared early and have suffered much abuse. The banks have also been weakened by many years of in-stream dredging and sand extraction that have altered forever the hydrological characteristics of the river. Anyone who has seen the pitiable state of the banks of the Hawkesbury River downstream from Windsor would surely agree with Bill Hayden's contention that certain `rights' ought to be challenged.

Degradation of wetlands is another factor that the Hawkesbury River shares with the Murray-Darling. Most of the original wetlands of the Hawkesbury were within my electorate, but much of the system's capacity for water purification has been lost as they have been drained, cleared and filled. It is imperative that wetlands in the Hawkesbury system be restored and protected and that land capable of supporting created wetlands be set aside to deal with future development.

The Hawkesbury basin, despite its urban image, is the source of a surprising amount of farm and market garden production. The Sydney market benefits from the large quantities of fresh vegetables and fruit that are grown close by, and the Windsor district is the state's largest supplier of mushrooms to domestic and overseas markets. The estuarine regions of the Hawkesbury River are important oyster farming and prawn harvesting areas and they also play a crucial part in the life cycle of fish species that underpin offshore fisheries. All this production is threatened by an increasing urbanisation in the catchment.

Preservation of agricultural land is becoming an increasingly important factor in the debate about future land use in the Sydney basin. Agricultural production is threatened by increasing salinity and encroaching urbanisation. The famous blue-green algae is perhaps the most spectacular manifestation of river degradation. The Murray-Darling achieved international notoriety with dramatic aerial shots of 1,500 kilometres of water the colour of turf. The Hawkesbury had a much smaller bloom at the same time, but the effect on the regional consciousness was profound and confusing.

An occurrence of algae is of the greatest significance to the Hawkesbury River as a symptom of environmental degradation throughout the catchment area rather than as an event in itself. Algae grows well in water that is rich in nutrients and that flows slowly—and here we come to the crux of the issue for the Hawkesbury: population growth in the Sydney basin.

One-fifth of the Australian population now withdraws and diverts water from the Hawkesbury for domestic, agricultural and industrial purposes. Water that should flow in the Hawkesbury is flowing instead through long and expensive deep ocean outfalls off the coast of Sydney. The river receives sewage effluent treated to various degrees of purity from nearly one million people. Sometimes in summer that effluent is nearly all the flow there is in the river. If current predictions come to pass, by the end of the century the Hawkesbury will be giving up its water to about one quarter of the total Australian population. It will be receiving treated sewage from an extra one million people and will be expected to provide a range of recreational facilities and experiences for many of these people.

The relationship between the water required by such a population, the rate at which people use water in the future and the amount of water available in the system must be seriously addressed. The environmental consequences of withdrawing even more water from the Hawkesbury River must become determinants for planning the future of Sydney.

Essentially, the issue is about the future development of Sydney and New South Wales. Why does Sydney continue to grow at the expense of the environment in the Hawkesbury basin and at the expense of the economies and communities of rural New South Wales? It is now imperative to simultaneously take control of the cancerous growth of Sydney and the death by neglect of the rest of the state.

The Murray-Darling has a federal government overview because it crosses state boundaries. I sincerely wish the Hawkesbury crossed a few boundaries as well. The issues relating to the Hawkesbury are as important to the nation as those of the Murray-Darling. There is a legitimate federal role in the Hawkesbury. The centenary of Federation is an appropriate time to ensure that this still beautiful river is returned to some measure of its original state. I hope that by 2001 we will be able to see significant progress towards that goal.

I might add that this year is the bicentenary of the Hawkesbury basin. For 200 years, that area has been the food basket of what was the colony, and now is the city, of Sydney. We are celebrating a major event before the centenary of Federation, so it gives us another excuse. I certainly hope by that time that as the member for Macquarie I will see for the Hawkesbury a concentration of effort and a unity of purpose that matches the one expressed in the Murray-Darling agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for bringing this motion before the parliament. The fact that probably 14 electorates embrace the Murray-Darling Basin gives us all an opportunity to dwell on just how important this part of Australia really is. While I appreciate that the honourable member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) wanted to talk about an important waterway in her electorate, the honourable member for Wakefield and I would like to draw the attention of the House to, and concentrate on, the economic significance of the Murray-Darling Basin.

PARA.TAB: In the last 25 years, it is true that there have been considerable advances in the many environmental interactions which occur in the Murray-Darling Basin. I can remember as a youngster—25 years ago I could be regarded as that—absolute panic for citrus growers associated with my family when the salinity of the Murray River was so bad that irrigation had to be carefully administered to trees and crops. Regrettably, some of that still exists. But, with better management, a better research effort, better understanding and the cooperation of the states and the federal government, river salinity is much more sustainable as is.

Latterly—other speakers have already made reference to this—there has been the threat of blue-green algae. Recently I took part in an inspection of the entire length of the Darling River. I am very concerned that, with the onset of this summer, low flows and high nutrients will see another catastrophic blue-green algae outbreak along the Darling River, which the honourable member for Macquarie has already mentioned.

Whilst we have made great strides in salt management, the understanding and ability to control algae is still in its infancy. In his motion, the honourable member for Wakefield has called on the government to accelerate its consideration of priority projects to clear up the catchment and mark the centenary of Federation. What more fitting thing could there be to celebrate the centenary of our Federation than a recognition of the economic value and importance of the Murray-Darling Basin. It has the potential in the next century to be the food bowl of the international region of which we are a part.

If we are ever to achieve this, we need to think a further 100 years ahead towards the bicentenary of Federation. If we in the coalition have any say in it, it will be a bicentenary of our Federation. Any funds needed to address the issues confronting the Murray-Darling Basin need to be considered not in a bandaid fashion but rather as an investment in our future and as an investment in real regional development.

Salt is a natural by-product from the soils of an arid country like Australia. The many mistakes we have made in the past can be useful to learn from, but we need to look to the future. Huge areas of the basin are underlain by a pristine saltwater basin and, after 150 years of land clearing, irrigation and the maintenance of high river levels, this salty ground water has moved inexorably upwards. In the vast dry land mallee areas of my electorate, this ground water is so close to the surface that salt scolds are increasing in area at a rate of 15 per cent per annum, thereby impacting dramatically on the productive capacity of the land for agriculture.

I am grateful for the government's recent commitment to fund stage 2 of piping of the Wimmera Mallee stock and domestic channel supply system. This open channel stock and domestic system has served the area well and has helped to open up the inhospitable Mallee to grain and stock production. But an open channel system over permeable mallee sandy soil has served to change the ground water system and add to the problems of dry land salting.

As this is a tri-funded project between the states, the federal government and land-holders, I remind the government of the fragile financial position of farmers as the drought moves southwards, as the honourable member for Wakefield has reminded us. These farmers now no longer have the capacity to fund their share of that project.

I also commend the suggestion by the honourable member for Wakefield that the Murray-Darling Basin and the ministerial council give urgent consideration to the establishment of a lower Murray-Darling freshwater facility. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some reservation that I support the motion of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) on the River Murray Basin. It is clear that it has bipartisan support in this chamber, but this does not mean that anything will happen. I suspect that is due to the nature of Australia. So many people live on the coast around Australia that we are now watching the development of a complete dichotomy between city and rural Australia. It is a situation of great concern and, if it continues, I do not believe this nation can survive.

PARA.TAB: I cannot be accused of holding a parochial view in relation to the River Murray. My electorate in Western Australia is far from the Murray. Even though I spent my childhood growing up on the lower reaches of the Murray, that was a long time ago. I am concerned about the plight of the Murray for economic reasons because a degradation of that environment will affect the economy of Australia as a whole.

The honourable member for Wakefield said that $10 billion worth of produce comes out of the Murray valley. I believe that this figure is grossly understated and, certainly, if a multiplier effect is added, $10 billion is only a fraction of the value of the Murray to Australia. I am reliably informed that, if the Murray were to go saline, two out of five jobs that exist in Australia at the moment would be lost. Most of those jobs lost would be in the cities and I believe, therefore, that there is a clear responsibility on government and the people in the cities to help fund the much needed campaign to restore the Murray.

However, I do not put a lot of faith in that. I put much greater store by economic achievements in the Murray itself. If higher value crops which require less water can be produced in the Murray, probably far more will be achieved for the value of the Murray than by relying on the goodwill of the nation.

The largest market in the world for table grapes is the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom imports a billion dollars worth of table grapes every year. It would take Australia five years to gear up to supply that demand if we were to start tomorrow. Many years ago, two enterprising brothers at Renmark went and had a look at Europe, decided what sort of grape the British wanted, came back and were happy to provide it. Britain is a particular market, requiring a soft skinned, sweet, seedless, green grape. That is the definition of a sultana grape.

The brothers came back to Australia and, despite frustrations by AQIS, the government quarantine organisation, were able to assemble three container loads, which they got to the London market. It took three months to do that. Those grapes, sold on the London market, travelled very well and fetched a then world record price for grapes—twice the Australian providing price. The brothers came back with order books full, only to be met with obstruction from AQIS, which was able to have the banning of sultana grapes for domestic purposes instituted in Australia. For a whole year they could not legally export these grapes.

Had we been able to establish that market then—we still can now if we have the will—it would have added enormously to the value of a crop. If the Murray valley were to produce domestic table grapes for that British market it could afford to use trickle irrigation, which is a much more effective use of the water than for growing grapes for wine or for dried fruit.

The honourable member for Wakefield said that sewage is one of the great sources of pollution for the River Murray, but pollution from sewage is mainly in the area of phosphorous nitrogen and, I guess to some extent, heavy metals. Salinity is not generally affected by that. To affect salinity we either have to get greater flow in the Murray or use less water. If we could have more efficient irrigation we would be achieving both, but this can be done only with an economic base.

There are other things I would like to mention. To replant a lot of the Murray with Eucalyptus camal dulensis will provide us with a hardwood market. I believe the potential for hardwood in Europe is enormous and, if we were to start now, in 60 or 70 years time we could have a dedicated industry supplying some of the hardwood needs of the United Kingdom and Europe where there is a growing shortage of this product. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall The Hon R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —When many Australians think of the River Murray or the River Murray Basin they tend to think of individual towns or individual rivers. In fact, it is a vast area of interlocking interests that stretches from the lakes at Goolwa right up into Queensland to Charleville and Toowoomba. It is a basin consisting of three major river systems: the Darling, producing about 12 per cent of the water catchment; the Murrumbidgee Lachlan, producing about 13 per cent; and the Murray upstream from Murrumbidgee, producing about 75 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The Murray-Darling Basin and its catchment area extend over about a seventh of the Australian continent. It is approximately 1,000 kilometres wide and 1,450 kilometres long. Three-quarters of New South Wales is within the catchment area and so too is half of Victoria, 15 per cent of Queensland and seven per cent of South Australia.

By world standards the Murray River is not a large river. It is 12 times smaller than the Ganges, 20 times smaller than the Danube and 60 times smaller than the Yangtze. Although the River Murray catchment area is large, it has the lowest run-off per unit area of any major river in the world.

An event occurred in 1991 which produced the worst algal bloom in the history of the system, extending from Mungindi on the Queensland-New South Wales border to Wilcannia—approximately 1,000 kilometres. Therefore, the inclusion of Queensland in the Murray-Darling Basin in this relatively new agreement is very important in bringing further oversight of the Darling into the total management of that system. However, as is described in the Murray-Darling Basin Commission annual report of 1992-93, the powers of the Murray-Darling Basin Commission are limited in respect of the Darling River upstream from the Menindee Lakes.

That is a very important limitation. I hope that, as time passes and more emphasis is placed on quality and an integrated management of the system, the Darling River upstream from the Menindee Lakes will come under stricter management. In the past the Darling River has always, by repute in South Australia, provided good quality water which South Australia has, at times, been very dependent on. It has been turbid water, but it has, in the past, been low in salinity. It is extremely discouraging to look at the impact of the blue-green algae in the past to 1991 and the prospect of it in the future if this is to be a dry year. There has been great variation in the flows of the river system which places more emphasis on the need for management. The annual report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The rivers of the Murray-Darling Basin were first developed for irrigation in the 1880s. Since then, the quantity of water diverted from the Murray-Darling River system has increased steadily. Now, on average, two-thirds of the water that originally would have reached the sea is diverted.
That illustrates the impact and the need for far greater management of the system. The annual report also goes on to mention the annual flows of the Murray. It states:
Annual inflows to the Murray system have ranged in the past from as high as 40 300 GL . . . to as low as 2900 GL (1902-03). The long-term average inflow to the system is 12 150 GL.

That illustrates the enormous variations in the flow of the system and the consequent pressure on that system. The effect of saline ground waters on the system and the many aspects of management which had a great impetus when the agreement for the Dartmouth Dam was implemented in bringing a number of important rivers within the management of the system in Victoria have already been mentioned in this debate. I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting the motion on the basis that it is much better to prevent a problem by efficient and effective management than to deal with it after it has occurred. I congratulate the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) on the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join my colleagues in recognising the importance of the Murray River Basin and the catchment area to the economy of Australia. I do not bring any parochial view to the debate on this motion in the sense that I am fortunate enough to represent an electorate in New South Wales which is the only electorate in that state that at present has not been drought declared.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, I am familiar with the Murray-Darling Basin from two sources. Firstly, I am probably one of the few members in New South Wales, apart from the federal members who represent that area, who have actually lived and worked west of the Great Dividing Range in New South Wales. I lived and worked—I taught at a school—in Leeton in the upper parts of the basin. For that reason, I think I know a little about the intricacies and the impact of the irrigation system.

The other aspect of my experience is my involvement with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. The committee brought down a report in June 1992 entitled Biodiversity—the contribution of community-based programs. The committee was chaired at that time, as it is now, by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). The inquiry was initiated by the now Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh).

In looking at the Murray-Darling Basin natural resources management strategy program, the committee came to a particular conclusion, but I think it is worth while reflecting on some aspects that we have put on the record about the importance of the Murray-Darling Basin; namely, that it comprises approximately one-seventh of the continent, that it has a population of some 1.8 million people and that a further one million depend on its resources for their livelihood. As the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) indicated, it consists of some 20 major rivers and hundreds of smaller tributaries, which drain an area some 1,450 kilometres long and 1,000 kilometres wide.

I think the importance of the area is well known to honourable members on both sides of the House. It produces some one-third of Australia's total output from rural industries and it supports some 25 per cent of the nation's cattle and dairy farms, about 50 per cent of its sheep population and crop land and almost 75 per cent of its irrigated land. The production derived from the basin is valued at some $10 billion annually.

There is widespread community and government concern about the extent of land degradation, the deteriorating water quality, the rising ground water and the loss of native flora and fauna throughout the basin. Those are some of the concerns addressed by the committee. Fortunately, the natural resources management strategy, the NRMS, which commenced prior to 1989, was reviewed in 1993 to refocus its aims. The points to come out of that, which has been mentioned by one or two speakers, are the impost of salinity and the nature of landcare programs.

Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, you may or may not agree that, while the landcare programs address certain aspects which are causing concern, it really comes down to a sea change in some of the attitudes and some of the practices in those areas. The issue of rising ground water has been mentioned by previous speakers. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) mentioned the need to plant trees and how that addresses the rising ground water problem, and there has also been reference to how run off water from the urban areas in the basin is treated.

I believe that funding landcare programs is not necessarily the complete answer to the problem. There has to be a change of opinion within the community. That is why most of the programs that the federal and state governments have put in place involve communities to a certain extent. Without the community owning some of the solutions we will not get that broad based community response to the problem. I think it is most important, wherever we go from here—and I certainly agree with the thrust of the motion, though I do have some reservations about some aspects of it; I agree that the assiduous use of irrigation water and the upgrading of the existing drainage and effluent schemes are priorities—that there be a sea change within the community. That is how we have to address the problem. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, it is with great pleasure that I rise to support your motion. You represent the irrigation areas of the Riverland and I represent the irrigation areas of both the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and the Coleambally Irrigation Area. I notice in the motion that you say it will take 25 years to clean up the River Murray. It has only been in recent times that the River Murray Commission has had this responsibility. It was once a distribution organisation for water of the Murray and its tributaries, but now it has been given the task of making sure that the quality of water in that system is what it should be.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the people along the Murrumbidgee River who are trying to do something about cleaning up the river system. The mayor of Wagga Wagga and his council are trying to do everything in their power to stop effluent going into the river. This has been done in cooperation with the mayor of Hay, Mick Beckwith. Along with the council and the people of Hay, he has complained for years that the quality of water in the Murrumbidgee River is getting worse. They are trying to do something about the problem. They are putting their money where their mouths are and trying to improve the quality of the water in the Murrumbidgee River.

The other thing that we have to be concerned about is the amount of water that is available to people in Australia. Australia, like many other countries in the world, is very dry. We are perhaps not the driest in the world, but we are certainly up amongst the leaders. The drought announcement of recent days has brought home how precious water is to us. It is not only affecting those people in the dry land areas but will also produce problems in the irrigation areas.

We are very fortunate with our dam system, but if we look at the water in the New South Wales dams as in July we see that Glenlyon Dam is at only seven per cent of its total capacity. Pindari Dam has 47 per cent of its water capacity; Copeton, five per cent; Split Rock, 12 per cent; Keepit, 12 per cent; Windamere, 93 per cent; Burrendong, 57 per cent; Wyangala, 79 per cent; Burrinjuck, 68 per cent; and Blowering, 63 per cent. For the Murrumbidgee and Coleambally irrigation areas, I think the problem is not so much having a shortage of water but getting the water out to the irrigation areas.

Over the years the irrigators have had a lot of subliminal pressure put on them from environmental groups saying that perhaps we should not be irrigating and we should find some other means of producing food. In the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area, they produce everything except tropical fruits. If it were not for the irrigation areas—

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems a good day to note the resignation from this place of Andrew Peacock. It is typical of the man that he went without a fuss. Andrew was the member for Kooyong for 28 years, Leader of the Opposition twice and a minister in the Gorton, McMahon and Fraser governments.

—Order! The honourable member for Adelaide will resume her seat. I understand that she will have a chance to renew her comments a little later on this afternoon. It being 3.00 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.
—Mr Speaker, I table the question time roster as at 19 September.

—I inform the House that the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, Gordon Bilney, and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Gary Punch, are absent from question time. In their place, the Minister for Finance will answer questions.

—by leave—I thought that, given that Andrew Peacock was in this place for 28 years and that he will not be back here this week, this is something that the House should take note of. Some of us will have the chance to commend him on his work here and to place our remarks on the record. I think the arrangements are that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and I will speak now and other remarks may ensue later.

PARA.TAB: It shows more than a modicum of style on Andrew's part that he never stuck around for the speeches: he basically tendered his resignation and took off. He was always credited as being a man with style, and I think he has shown some more over the last week. Twenty-eight years at the top of a party is a significant achievement. I think he was the second longest serving member of the House after the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair).

His political life was lived out here under the period of seven Prime Ministers, starting in 1966. He joined the government when the likes of Sir John McEwen and the Rt Hon. Sir Paul Hasluck were in the Holt cabinet. He joined the Gorton ministry three years later in 1969 and then served in a number of portfolios: Minister for Foreign Affairs, Minister for Industrial Relations, Minister for Industry and Commerce, Minister for the Army and Minister for External Territories. This was over quite an extensive period—from 1969 to 1972 and from 1975 mostly to 1983. So he had a relatively long period of ministerial office. He was Leader of the Opposition, elected by his party on two occasions, which is, I think, a fairly rare distinction and a rare level of support shown by the party. It believed, obviously, that he was best qualified to discharge the responsibilities of the leadership of the opposition, which is always a very difficult office to fill.

There were a number of things Andrew Peacock would identify about his own career that were important to him. Bringing independence to Papua New Guinea is probably the one he would nominate as probably his greatest achievement. He did this despite the deep-seated paternalism of many of his party colleagues. Both during and after his time as foreign minister he was respected on the international stage and made his views known very strongly against the atrocities which were being committed by the Pol Pot regime in Cambodia.

Within the House he often provided a dash of colour, and he was one of the parliament's more colourful performers. He was one of the more modern 20th century Liberals, but was often thwarted by some of the more conservative elements of his own party. In some ways he was able to see the bigger picture. The fact that he had a life outside of politics was very important to him. It gave him a sense of balance, a sense of proportion and also maintained his sense of humour, which was always there, I think, in reasonably full measure.

Andrew Peacock is a tougher character than a lot of commentators give him credit for. You do not scramble into the leadership of the opposition or a major portfolio without a certain degree of toughness. I think he was quite hard when he wanted to be. Nevertheless, he was a very charming individual. Charming is not an adjective one throws around easily, but he was very charming.

TALK.START.PARA: —He still is.

—Yes, and he still is. One of his burdens in life was that he had the prime ministership thrust up at him perpetually, as though he were ordained to succeed, that he had to make the grade; otherwise, the notion had it, his destiny would not be fulfilled—and the destiny, of course, was mapped out by other people. He did say at a press conference, in a very revealing remark, `I don't know whether I ever wanted to be Prime Minister.' That was in 1988 or thereabouts. In truth, many people in the House may agree with that sentiment. I am not sure that in the end he had that burning desire to actually take responsibility for the place. At any rate, he enjoyed what he did and he did it for a long time. The political system will miss him.

PARA.TAB: It is somewhat revealing of public life today and maybe of the Liberal Party in particular that its perhaps most acclaimed machinery person has rejected the opportunity of a safe seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't help yourself, can you?
—No, just listen.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not a valedictory.
—Order! Those on my left!
—No, it is not a valedictory; he is still out there in life. That again, I think, underlines just how difficult it is to—

PARA.TAB: Mr Costello interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any difficulty being a statesman, brother, no difficulty whatsoever. I do not need any urging from you to do that. It may be a commentary on political life in general that some of the brighter people of the party machines will not take the opportunities of the safer and better seats because of the other attractions outside of political life, and an unwillingness to wear the scrutiny and the travails of public life. At any rate, Andrew Peacock wore these for 28 years. I think it is fair to say that he leaves the House with the good graces and support of all members. I do not think he had too many enemies and certainly none who would not wish him well. As he goes about his private life, I wish him well. I certainly believe that he probably thought it was a long time coming. He can go back to enjoying himself and finding that sense of satisfaction he was able to find in public life. I think, as I said, most members of the House will miss him and wish him well.

—by leave—I would like to join with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in sending my best wishes to Andrew Peacock on his retirement from the House of Representatives. I do not think there is any doubt that, with the retirement of Andrew Peacock, the parliament has lost a fine parliamentarian—a member with a strong record of achievement in government. Perhaps above all, we will remember Andrew for being a good bloke.

PARA.TAB: I speak as someone who worked for Andrew Peacock down in the bowels of the Department of Foreign Affairs when he was at the top as the foreign minister. When I was in my 20s, I worked for him as a political adviser when he was the Leader of the Opposition after the 1983 election; and, of course, I have worked with him as a member of parliament and in the shadow cabinet. To me, he has been a great friend, an ally and a confidante over many years. He has good friendships certainly on this side of the House, but I think even the Labor Party would concede in a moment of private candour that he has good friendships on the other side of the House as well. We have all enjoyed his private company, and I think that will be very much missed.

Andrew was a formidable politician who took the battle to his political opponents. He possessed great fighting qualities on the campaign trail. He was one of the very substantial parliamentary debaters of the past 20 or so years. He combined an extensive knowledge of the standing orders with a great sense of humour, as the Prime Minister pointed out, and a powerful way with words.

Andrew Peacock can look back on his record as a minister of the Crown with satisfaction. Members of the House and others will remember him in particular for his role in the foreign affairs portfolio where both his style and his substance served Australia's interests well. As the Prime Minister pointed out, the important part that he played in the independence of Papua New Guinea when he was foreign minister is seen as a high point of his career. He had very close relations with many, if not all, of the leading figures of that country.

He made many other great contributions as foreign minister, particularly to the evolution of Australian policy during the global debates of the late 1970s and the early 1980s on how to respond to the demands of the Third World, the North-South dialogue and the new international economic order. In those debates, Andrew Peacock was well ahead of his time, and the reorientation of Australian policy that he achieved has been an enduring one.

He also played a very significant role in raising Australia's profile in foreign affairs in the Asia-Pacific region. It was he, amongst others, who was instrumental in ensuring that Australia's foreign policy priority was its own region. This is not a new development; this is something that people like Andrew Peacock, when he was foreign minister, worked hard at in years gone by.

Andrew was a great Liberal who served his party twice as its leader. Over recent years, his long experience, sensible advice and practical involvement benefited this side of the House enormously. His Liberal beliefs were deeply held and applied to the circumstances of his time. His 1983 Deakin lecture on a Liberal approach to change will stand as one of his most powerful and definitive statements of belief.

We in the Liberal Party are indebted to Andrew for his long and distinguished contribution to our party and the political process in Australia. We wish him well in the future. We know that he will enjoy more time with his family and we know that he will enjoy a great deal more time studying the racing form and supporting his beloved Essendon Football Club. Judging by its performance this year, it needs a great deal more support—not that I am mocking it; the Crows did not do very well this year. Nevertheless, next year the Essendon Football Club can look forward to even more enthusiastic support from Andrew Peacock than he was able to provide this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is who will be the team who will play the Eagles.

—That is probably right. Mind you, I think next year the Crows will be a completely rejuvenated team; don't underestimate them. Andrew will be greatly missed in this place on both sides of the House. He goes with the knowledge that he has a record to look back on with pride and that he has a new future to look forward to with enthusiasm.
