It was significant that savings of the order estimated by Mr Taylor would make the Australian National Line a going concern with a real market value if they were implemented.
How about that! When we go and do it, we are accused of throwing money at this organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You couldn't give it away.
—The Leader of the Opposition has asked his question. Listen to the answer.
—The shadow minister for privatisation said this on the very same subject on 9 September:

ANSWER.PARA: The union now appears set to resist the further reforms to shipping.
Mr Rae Taylor, the chairman of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority, said:
Such reforms are essential if Australian shipping is to achieve an internationally competitive standard.
So here they are, these so-called experts—the people appointed by the Leader of the Opposition—saying that we should do all these things. The moment that we do them, they are smack bang into us.

PARA.TAB: It is not as though these views have only been expressed of late by the shadow minister for privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, get on with it.
—You're getting it, brother. On 21 April this year, the honourable member for Hume, the shadow minister for transport, said:

ANSWER.PARA: In the course of ensuring that the Australian industry can compete on a fair basis—
the coalition will be prepared to discuss measures such as a second register with the industry and look—
this is what he said; I am quoting it—
at the taxation regimes that place anti-competitive burdens on Australian shipping.
You have been in the cart for these changes. When we introduce them, you say, `Isn't this awful?'

PARA.TAB: I repeat: what is different today is that we have received a commitment from the union movement in exchange—
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very important commitment. In exchange for the bipartisan recommendations that we adopted, we received an undertaking in respect of a reduction in crew sizes, a reduction in the crewing ratio and a long-term peace accord on the waterfront combined with measures to reform labour relations so as to give the equivalent result to company employment.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the measures introduced by the government will cost in the order of $15 million to $20 million in terms of the tax implication for the PAYE exemption. It will put our international seafarers on a similar basis to those of many of our competitors—to those in Denmark, Finland, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the United Kingdom. You have been crying out for international competitiveness and when we introduce it you say, `No, no, you shouldn't do it.' Really, I think there is a great lack of sincerity on the part of the opposition.

Let me conclude by saying that, whilst all these things will flow from the agreement last Monday night, we will obviously need to be successful in achieving the total package of reform at ANL because ANL itself will only profit to the tune of about $5 million in respect of that total concession of $15 million to $20 million. That alone, of course, will not be enough to repair ANL's affairs. It needs to be restructured, and that is the task and the responsibility of Neville Wran and his colleagues. It is a very important task.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. I invite the minister to wind up his answer.

—We are committed to that task. We will direct all of our endeavours to making sure that there remains an internationally competitive shipping industry and that no effort is spared in rehabilitating ANL.
—But you said it wasn't internationally competitive.
—With these measures, it has a chance of being so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. I refer the minister to the fact that today is National Breast Cancer Day. What action is being taken by both federal and state governments to improve breast cancer screening services?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. I think it is very important that we all recognise this first National Breast Cancer Day and recognise the very clear importance of the early detection of breast cancer. It is why there has been such a concerted effort by state and federal governments alike to ensure high levels of funding and a five-year program which will see all women over 50 being screened every two years.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, after the first three years, we have seen some 604,000 women being screened for breast cancer. But, with some 6,000 Australian women being diagnosed every year with breast cancer, clearly there is no room for complacency. We are very keen to continue with this screening program, amongst other measures. The Commonwealth will be giving an extra $236 million or so over the next five years to ensure that we reach that target of one million women being screened every two years.

It is therefore very disappointing to me to discover from the recent Victorian health budget that we are not getting that commitment from at least one state government. Given the rhetoric, it is very disappointing indeed. I think it is important that these matters be drawn to the attention of the public. The public expect joint effort between the Commonwealth and the states, and the other states have been doing the right thing. Victoria has been offered $9.2 million to ensure screening. It was supposed to match that but it is falling short by over $2 million, with the result that over 40,000 Victorian women will not have the screening services that otherwise would be provided.

I think it is most important on this first National Breast Cancer Day that I draw the attention of the public to this matter and say to the people of Victoria: put pressure on your government to match the funds that are available in other states for screening purposes. That is perfectly reasonable. All Australian women expect and deserve that sort of service. It is a day for ensuring that people match the rhetoric with the reality. Withdrawing $2 million from screening programs in Victoria is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Does the minister account for the difference of valuations offered for ANL by its consultants Price Waterhouse and Salomon Brothers, and the ANL's auditors, Arthur Andersen? What instructions were given to the government's consultants before preparing the due diligence report? Were they told not to communicate with the ANL board? Further, why did the minister specifically forbid the ANL board to have a 1992 report of the company's value by Macquarie Corporate Finance updated? Why did the minister deliberately set out to deceive his cabinet, the union and the people of Australia on a shabby deal?
—He is a former chairman of the Brisbane Stock Exchange.
—Did you give him the answer?
—I was just reminding him about his chairmanship of the Brisbane Stock Exchange.
—Order! The House will come to order!

—I think the whole House is aware of the honourable gentleman's former chairmanship of that body, but I think it is worth recounting to the House the sequence of events in respect of the appointment of the due diligence process to ANL. The due diligence was called for a very good reason. It was called because we were dissatisfied with the performance of ANL which, after all, had lost money on six out of the last seven years.
—Whose fault was that?
—It was the fault of a number of things.
—Including you?
—The minister might wait for a moment. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition does not have a right in his leadership role to sit there and constantly interject.

—The due diligence was called because the government was not prepared to accept a continuation of the losses that were being sustained by ANL with some $30 million alone on average being lost in each of the last four years in its overall operations. The fact that the company had a net debt of about $180 million and a gearing ratio of 160 per cent required careful analysis, not by the board of ANL or the advisers of the board of ANL; it required independent scrutiny. The people chosen by the Department of Finance for that task were Price Waterhouse and Salomon Brothers. They conducted the first detailed due diligence process that had been undertaken for some time in respect of ANL.
—Calm down!
—I warn the honourable member for Cowan.

—They did so without any instructions from me whatsoever. They did so charged with one responsibility: to advise the government of the state of ANL if it were to be sold. And they reported to us this month.

PARA.TAB: They had numerous discussions with the board. There is no point in suggesting that there was any breakdown in communications there. The fact is that the board of ANL was opposed to the whole process of due diligence. It was unhappy with the concept of its taking place. It brought in its own consultants, Moore Stephens, to value the organisation. It is worth noting that Moore Stephens in its recommendations agreed with a number of the conclusions reached by Price Waterhouse and Salomon Brothers in their recommendations to government.

It is a matter of fact that Price Waterhouse-Salomons recommended to the government an effective liquidation of ANL. We chose not to do that. We chose instead to restructure it, to try to guarantee that everything gives it its best chance in the future. Indeed, we have reinforced that with the commitments given last Monday night, which do give ANL a genuine chance. It is our intention, I repeat, to do everything we can to achieve that result.

At the end of the day, of course, ANL will be disposed of because the way is now clear for its disposal, but it will be disposed of by way of an open tendering process that was inherent in the decision of last Monday night. If the union movement, in combination with shipping interests, can get its act together and be successful in that open tendering process against the background of the reforms we have introduced, we will be thoroughly delighted because it will guarantee our long-term objective, the commitment we have had all of this year, which is to continue to the maximum extent possible to see Australian working men and women working on our ships under the Australian flag and under Australian award conditions. All of this progress, we think, gives us a real chance of achieving those objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Has the minister seen reports concerning the low level of apprenticeships and traineeships in Australian industry? How many apprenticeships and traineeships are there and how do these numbers compare with past experience?

—I have seen reports from the opposition, in particular my shadow counterpart, suggesting that the number of people in apprenticeships and traineeships is at the lowest level for three decades. This is, in fact, repeated in The things that matter statement at page 17. This statement is wrong. I was interested when these statements started being aired on radio because, if we go to the details of apprenticeships and traineeships, both commencements and completions, over the period we find that for the year 1993-94 they are the third highest on record, surpassed only by the period 1988-89 to 1989-90. They are 250 per cent higher than the average of the 1960s. They are 80 per cent higher than the average of the 1970s. Even at the low point in the recession of 1991-92 they were still higher than anything the Liberal Party was able to achieve at its peak.

PARA.TAB: They are the facts and they stand for themselves. I think what we have to do is to understand the position that the opposition comes from in this regard because not only is the opposition wrong in terms of what it asserts, but it can hardly claim to take the moral high ground in saying that what it is about is giving more training opportunities to Australians.

Ours is an impressive record by standards of the past, but we are not stopping with that record. With what we have done prior to the white paper through initiatives to increase funding to TAFE and to vocational education and training, as well as the commitments in the white paper to expand by 50,000 the number of training places by 1995-96, we will take this impressive record even further.

We, as a nation, understand the importance of skilling and training the work force, but we are prepared to put action and policy behind the rhetoric. Through the training wage and the wage subsidies, the funding in the white paper, which is an extra $770 million over four years, plus the cutting of the red tape and the vehicle through NETTFORCE, these are targets that I am confident can be achieved. I would hope that the opposition, rather than continuing to promote falsehoods about what has happened, would recognise what has been achieved and applaud the initiatives that will take the record even further.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Will the minister explain why he ordered the former board of ANL to prepare its financial strategy for the forthcoming three years on a status quo basis? Did the board register its objections to this restriction? Did the board eventually give you two documents, one to your specification and one according to the board's preference? What was the purpose of the status quo document?

—In response to the honourable member, let me say that my instructions to the board were for it to cooperate with the due diligence process and to make sure that it did nothing that frustrated that process. The fact is that ANL has been on a status quo basis this year pending the outcome of that due diligence report. When you have the stewardship of something that has been losing a great deal of money and you have brought in a due diligence process, the last thing you want is a change of any material circumstance in the business—say, an investment running into tens of millions of dollars—until such time as you have been able to report back to the government on the outcome of the study. Quite frankly, it would have been irresponsible to have done anything other than proceed on the basis of the status quo in the intervening period.

PARA.TAB: I know that the company wanted to do all sorts of things. It wanted to buy Australian Stevedores for $140 million. But the fact is that it has been kept on a status quo basis. As to the honourable member's question about what the company may or may not have prepared by way of alternative documents, I will have my office research what it did. From my point of view, my instructions were pretty simple: keep this business going without any material change in its circumstances until the government can consider what actions it must take in the interests of the business and, of vital importance, the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware of claims that the government is creating uncertainty for the business community and undermining the confidence needed for business investment? Can the minister provide the House with information on the level of business confidence and investment in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of those claims. They were incorporated in a document which gave the Leader of the Opposition enormous cause for mirth and amusement, namely, the launching of his policy, The Things That Matter. It includes on page 10:

ANSWER.PARA: Labor's policies are creating uncertainty and concern about the future and undermining the confidence needed to invest.
Labor has no policies which will encourage business investment to reach its full potential.

In that particular document—which, as I said, created such enormous mirth and amusement for the Leader of the Opposition but not half as much as for everybody else—there is clearly absent a point that the government has been doing something about for some considerable time. Evidently, it escaped the drafters of those particular propositions that the government had cut the company tax rate to 33 per cent, put in place a changed development allowance and a general investment allowance and accelerated depreciation arrangements, included in the One Nation statement, et cetera. There has been a very considerable effort on the part of this government to improve the climate for business investment over the last couple of years.

PARA.TAB: It is quite evident from the statistics that are coming through that the government in that area has been largely successful. Investment by private enterprises in new equipment was 13.4 per cent higher in the June quarter than in the March quarter, according to the national accounts. The latest June quarter capital expenditure survey also shows that strong growth in capital expenditure is expected to continue throughout 1994-95. Based on that survey and other factors such as strong business confidence, growing capacity utilisation and robust company profits, the budget forecast of 14 1/2 per cent growth is well and truly on target.

But there is also information from other surveys. For example, the latest Pacific Power and Access Economics' investment monitor recorded a nine per cent increase in value of projects under construction or committed. That in turn was a result of an increase of nearly 50 per cent in the value of projects committed. The biannual survey by the Business Council of Australia released in May strongly supports the budget forecast of a rise in business investment. Sixty per cent of the survey respondents expected to increase their investment by more than 10 per cent and about 45 per cent of the survey respondents expected to increase investment by more than 20 per cent. The June quarter ACCI-Westpac business survey reports that the net balance of manufacturers planning an increase in plant and equipment investment over the next 12 months is at its second highest level for more than five years.

I suppose if we wanted even more direct evidence closer to home than the coalition, one of its noted supporters over the years has been invited to make a choice. The choice is: shall I continue in this supposedly poor climate created by the government and make pots of dough or shall I spend the next five years of my life winkling out the pixies from under the mushrooms when it comes to policy formation on the Liberal Party front bench? He—that is, Michael Kroger—clearly made the most sensible suggestion and the most sensible response to the opposition's policy document that anyone could make.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Minister for Transport and follows on from the comment that he made in his last answer that he is working for the best interests of Australian taxpayers. Were reservations expressed by any of your departmental officers, as was claimed by former chairman of ANL, Bill Bolitho, last Friday, or by ANL board members about the extent of the damage to the company's commercial status as a result of your statement that you `couldn't give it away'? Is it true that they have advised you that your actions have substantially reduced the value of ANL?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a terrifying question. The answer is that I have received no such advice. The member relies upon a document issued last Friday evening by the former chairman of ANL. There are only two aspects of that document with which I agree. I certainly do not agree with his contention on the matter raised by the honourable member, but I do want to take the opportunity to say that I agree with the former chairman in two respects and two respects only. One is where he sought to defend Messrs Hurlstone, Kidman, Denton and Geraghty, who were directors of ANL but appointed only late last year. Those gentlemen should not feel that the government thinks they did other than give their absolute best in the very limited time available to them, most of which was taken up during the due diligence process.

PARA.TAB: I also agree with Mr Bolitho's statement about the $160 million injected by this government in either capital or debt forgiveness in the two tranches in 1983 and 1985. He had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The 160 million dollars referred to by the minister appears to be largely debt which would have been lost to the Government had it closed ANL down when it was found to have a negative net worth of some two hundred million dollars when I became Chairman in 1983.
That just happens to coincide with some other events of 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The minister has indicated that he is not quoting from confidential notes but from a statement of Mr Bolitho. I ask whether he would care to table it.
—It has circulated right through the gallery.
—Please table it for the benefit of the House.
—Has the minister quoted from a confidential document?
—As a parliamentary tactician you have got to give it to him.
—There are standing orders that cover such matters.
—Mr Speaker, I am delighted to table it. I think it was circulated far and wide on Friday night. The opposition member must be the only one without a copy of it thus far.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of reports about the quality of Australia's social security system? How well does Australia's social security system compare with those in other countries? What action has the government taken to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of our social security system?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I note that a claim was made in an article by Mike Steketee in the Weekend Australian that, if you look at the totality of outlays for social security purposes in this country, we might not compare very well with some other countries. That is a highly misleading way of looking at the question. It fails to take proper account of the structural features of our system in comparison with those of other countries.

PARA.TAB: In this respect, it is fortuitous that the ANU has just released a study by Professor Gruen, Dr Deborah Mitchell and Professor Ann Harding which compares the social security systems of Australia and nine other developed countries. What it had to say makes very interesting reading indeed. It makes the point that you cannot just look at the totality of outlays; you have also to look at the efficiency of the social security systems of different countries at getting the assistance to those who actually need it. The people who produced this study reached the conclusion that, of the 10 countries studied, we have easily the most efficient system of getting the dollars to those who need it. To a very considerable extent, that offsets any difference in the totality of outlays.

The effectiveness of our social security system in preventing poverty is high and has increased significantly over the 1980s, largely as a consequence of the emphasis that we have placed on achieving a highly targeted system that is very efficient not only in getting money to those who need it, but also in terms of administrative costs as a proportion of total transfer outlays, in which respect we have the second most efficient system. So a great deal has been achieved in both those areas.

Since this government has come to office the benefits to those who need them—those on low incomes—have improved significantly in real terms and when measured against the various poverty indicators. The improvement and repair of our social security safety net is one of the most significant achievements of this government during its tenure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. I refer the minister to the deal just struck with the Maritime Union of Australia allowing the union to buy its stake in ANL with trade union superannuation funds. I remind the House that on 23 August the minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . you could not privatise ANL at the moment; you could not give it away. It has a negative worth . . .

Salomon Brothers and Price Waterhouse recently valued ANL at minus $117 million. As admitted a few minutes ago, ANL has lost an average of $30 million a year over the past four years. I also remind the House that the governing rules of superannuation entities require the trustee `to ensure that the trustee's duties and powers are performed and exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries'. I therefore ask the minister: how are you going to convince the superannuation fund trustees that investment in ANL is `in the best interests of the beneficiaries'?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have to convince anyone. That is entirely a matter for those who might be putting a consortium together. We are saying that, if there is someone out there who can buy ANL after it has been restructured as a going concern, we will be very happy with the result.

—Can the Deputy Prime Minister inform the House of progress under the new regional development strategy? What impact is the government's commitment to economic growth having on further development of regional Australia?

—I thank the honourable member for his question, which refers to the role of regional development and particularly progress. If there is a symbol of progress—I think the honourable member for Gippsland would agree with me—it is the Latrobe Valley development agreement which was signed last week. That agreement represents cooperation between three levels of government: the Commonwealth; the state government, represented by Mr Roger Hallam; and the representative local governments. These governments have been divided for a very long time but have come together in the Latrobe Valley to sign this agreement.

PARA.TAB: The agreement represents a degree of consensus achieved between business in the Latrobe Valley, industry, the Monash University, which is located at Churchill, trade unions and local government. I think it was very broadly welcomed within the valley. This significant agreement also represents the potential to see Latrobe Valley as a focus for a broader pattern of regional development right throughout the Gippsland region. The agreement is very important. I think what it represents is the reality that the philosophy of regional development, which was outlined in the Working Nation statement earlier this year, is now being translated not only through the Latrobe Valley in Gippsland but in regions right around Australia. People like the philosophy. They like the consultative or bottoms up approach. They like the recognition that you need partnership to achieve economic development.

I think this agreement is very important because, if there was one region that needed revitalisation, a fresh approach and broad cooperation, it was the Latrobe Valley. Last week I think we all sensed that this agreement represented a fresh start, a hope not only for the valley but also, more broadly, for the Gippsland region. Potentially, it is a model for regions, particularly those undergoing difficulties, right around Australia.

The member's question is a very pertinent question. The issue is one that the government is seeking to address broadly. Certainly, in terms of the member's own electorate, we can see the fruits of the government's well-researched approach. It is an approach that thinks through the issues and then seeks to build a partnership agreement that will be a basis of very strong economic and social development in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that in 1990-91, the government gave the Seamen's Union a grant of $40,000? Is it a fact that in the following year the government gave the maritime unions another grant of $140,000? Is it a fact that the maritime unions gave the Labor Party $84,000 to fund last year's election campaign? Why did the government give one of its biggest donors those grants? Does the $84,000 gift to the Labor Party explain why the government has done a sweetheart deal with the maritime unions?

—An $84,000 sweetheart deal! The fact is that, as this House well and truly knows, the government administers a whole range of programs that go from trade union training and education right across to workplace reform.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will come to order. The minister is entitled to be heard in silence.

—They go even further. They go to the best practice demonstration program, which is money paid by this government to encourage best practice amongst business. If you tally up the grants that are given to the union movement on the one hand and compare them with the grants that are given to the business sector under programs administered by my department, you will find that the business sector gets more than the trade union movement. It has ever been thus. The fact is that under the trade union training program—
—The honourable member for Mackellar!

—Even in the Fraser days there was direct funding of these programs by a coalition government. We have been pleased to continue that and we have been pleased to see the results of workplace reform as a result of that program. That is the reason why in the federal sphere 55 per cent of our award employees are in enterprise bargaining. In Western Australia, where there are no grants available, it is seven per cent; in New South Wales it is seven per cent; in South Australia it is six per cent. That money has been paid and paid well to achieve reforms to the Australian industrial relations system. I might say it was only a matter of a few weeks ago that I announced the last range of programs under the workplace reform program.
—I warn the honourable member for Mackellar!

—That went to provide workplace bargaining arrangements for, I think, 30 applicants. Amongst the applicants were many business houses and, indeed, the organisations that represent those businesses. We were pleased, as we have been in the past, to continue that funding. The honourable member suggests that there is something extraordinary about the union movement supporting the ALP. That is no more extraordinary than one of the other recipients of support, that is, the ACCI, doing what they did for you at the time of the last election.
—Can the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training advise the House what measures are being taken to ensure that all Australians get the best education possible?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I acknowledge the close interest that he, as a former teacher, takes in matters educational. The government's priority for quality education in schools is well known and is evidenced by over $3 billion in Commonwealth expenditure. Of course, the non-government sector is supported by Commonwealth grants of over one and a half billion dollars a year as well. In addition, the government has guaranteed real increases for government and most non-government schools through legislation.

PARA.TAB: We are spending some $258 million to improve access to education for disadvantaged children, including those isolated by geography. We are supporting the implementation of the cooperatively developed national curriculum framework. We have established the Australian Teaching Council to foster the teaching profession and we are investing some $60 million in professional development to raise the status of teachers. The list goes on.

It is pertinent to ask against such a background of impressive achievements just what it is at this time that the coalition is offering our young people. If one works through the generalisations contained in The Things That Matter, one comes up with a set of goals which, in many ways, is consistent with what the government has been successfully achieving for many years. Now we know what the coalition's new direction is. In a nutshell, it is that when you have no ideas of your own you plagiarise policies which are working and hope the community does not find out. The House and the honourable member for Gilmore know what happens when you get caught copying in school: you get nought out of 10. That is what the coalition gets for its schools policy—a big fat zero.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Given that the government has already decided the future of ANL by way of its grubby deal with the Maritime Union of Australia, does he still propose to pay $300,000 of taxpayers' funds to Mr Wran and Mr Turnbull to advise him on what to do with it? How can he justify making these payments other than as money for mates?

—This is a question I answered weeks ago in the parliament. I indicated to the House that the salaries being paid to the directors of ANL were set not by government but by the independent Remuneration Tribunal. I have indicated here in the House—

—This shows what a dreadfully poor understanding you have, what a terrible shallowness there is in your understanding of what needs to be done at ANL in order to make it profitable. The fact is, as I indicated in the House this afternoon, that the task facing Mr Wran and his fellow directors for the next five months is a crucially important one because the concessions given last Monday night will fall far short of guaranteeing that ANL has a viable future. It still needs to be vitally and completely restructured. That is the task facing Mr Wran, Mr Turnbull and their associates, and they will continue that task over the next five months.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, can I just add to an earlier answer. The figures in millions of dollars provided by the government in program funds administered by my department from 1991-92 to 30 August 1994 indicate that $11.17 million went to the union movement and $31.93 million to employers and employers' groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations. Could he outline to the House steps being taken to improve the safety of workers in the lead industry and, in particular, to bring to an end the discrimination against women working in this industry?

—Yes, I can. Late last week the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission issued a new code of practice for lead levels in blood for those 8,000 workers in Australia who work in the lead industry. There have been a number of significant advances here. The first, through cooperation with the states, the Commonwealth and the territories, is to set a new uniform blood lead level for all workers in that industry. The second, which is more important, is to lower the acceptable lead levels in blood for all workers. Thirdly, and quite distinctively, women were never allowed to work in this industry and be exposed at all to lead levels, which was a peculiar form of discrimination in the sense that they were not given the opportunity. We now find we are able to differentiate the risks between men and women such that women can, within given guidelines, work in lead-risk parts of the industry.

PARA.TAB: We have been very sensitive, though, to those women who may be of reproductive age, pregnant or in the process of breastfeeding in that very careful levels of lead in the blood have been set for them such that they can be withdrawn at any stage from lead-risk areas. It does not deny them, however, the right to work in those areas and the right of all workers to be checked on a regular basis for lead. The object is to allow men and women to work more safely in the lead industry and to progressively ensure that men and women take up jobs in this industry that tend to be risk free. I thank the state and territory governments for their cooperation in ensuring better and safer standards for men and women in the lead industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I cannot get a question around here so I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. They do not ask me questions because they do not like the answers.
—On 30 May this year I placed on the Notice Paper question No. 1207, which was directed to the Prime Minister and which is yet to be answered.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order No. 150, could you ask the Prime Minister to provide an answer to that question. He could probably do it on one of his rostered days off.
—In accordance with standing order 150, I will follow the required procedure.

—Mr Speaker, you may be aware that David Parker, the former Western Australian Labor Deputy Premier, was gaoled today for stealing from donated campaign funds. At his trial, Parker stated that while he was the minister for mines he had in February 1988 received a cheque for $20,000 from the late mining magnate Lang Hancock. PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Day
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: The Anzacs at the Gallipoli landing on 25 April 1915 were instrumental in forging a new identity for Australia. That landing was a lifetime ago but the deeds of those Anzacs of 1915-18 still speak a message of selfless service and sacrifice that will last forever.

Anzac Day is a day to remember those who left their homes with a strong desire to return but did not, as well as those who did return, but in so doing carried for the remainder of their lives the scars of these experiences.

It is a day to contemplate the spirit that moves men and women to serve, to suffer discomforts, dangers and fears and to risk their lives in defence of their country and in the pursuit of peace, justice and freedom.

On Anzac Day, we salute not only the spirit of the Anzacs but, in paying tribute to them, we take the opportunity to dedicate ourselves to striving for our country as they did and to upholding their finest qualities of courage, commitment, endurance and mateship.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House urge the Government to declare Anzac day as Australia's National Day of Commemoration and that it be held on 25 April in each year, and on no other day.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall (from 99 citizens), Mr Cunningham (from 166 citizens), Mr Lindsay (from one citizen), Mr Moore (from 12 citizens) and Mr Stephen Smith (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Gay Law Reform in Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that your petitioners are concerned that:
as Sections 122 a&c and 123 of the Tasmanian Criminal Code make all private sexual activity between consenting adult men punishable by up to 21 years imprisonment, and;

as these laws adhere a criminal stigma to the social, cultural and political activities of gay and lesbian communities, degrade the status of gay and lesbian people, reinforce their social oppression and violate their dignity, and;
as these laws foster blackmail, harassment, discrimination, vilification and violence against gay men and lesbians, and;
as these laws have been used by local and state governments to justify policies that disadvantage lesbians and gay men, and;

as these laws reduce the self esteem of gay men and lesbians, when research shows that low self esteem contributes to the higher incidence of suicide, alcohol and drug abuse, and HIV/AIDS in lesbian and gay communities, and;

as Australian criminal law is brought into disrepute by unenforced and unenforceable laws that criminalise victimless consenting activity between adults in private and deprive Australians of freedom of choice by dictating personal morality, and;
as Tasmania is the last state or territory in Australia to retain such laws, and;
as these laws have been condemned by Amnesty International, the Australian Council of Social Services, the National AIDS Strategy, and the Tasmanian Anglican and Uniting Churches, and;

as these laws violate rights enshrined in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights including the right to privacy and the right to equality before the law—rights which should be enjoyed by all citizens regardless of sexuality, and;
as the Australian Constitution gives the Commonwealth the power to rectify violations, by the states, of international treaties such as the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and;

PETITION.TITLE: Treaties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that Australia is now a signatory to more than 2100 international treaties, conventions and agreements, which, once ratified, bind Australia by international law to implement and to abide by them.

While accepting that it is necessary for Australia to subscribe to many of these agreements if it is to participate freely and effectively as a member of the international community, we are concerned that such agreements are signed and ratified by the Executive Government without first being referred to the Australian Parliament for inquiry or debate.
We are further concerned that there is no provision in the Australian Constitution for such a course of action to be followed by the Executive Government.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will:
