SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is with the Commonwealth, state and territory governments for failing to adequately fund our nation's primary schools to ensure that no child is deprived of the opportunity to fully participate in society because of inadequate skills in literacy and numeracy. For a very long time, I have argued in front of this parliament and in many other places that our school systems are failing our youth and failing the future of our country because of their failure to adequately prepare all—that is, 100 per cent—of our young people with the skills that they need to fully participate in modern society. We all know that society is becoming more complex and more technological and that entry into it demands increasing skills, including the ability of individuals to be able to read and write in English and to be able to compute—to add, subtract, multiply and divide.

PARA.TAB: In 1992, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training tabled a report entitled The literacy challenge: strategies for early intervention for literacy and learning for Australian children, which has become the bible of literacy sources for Australia for the past two years. In one section of that report we dealt with the issue of resources. It is that issue that I wish to largely address today.

We stated that it is essential that the beginnings of education—the years which provide the foundations for further learning—receive increased resourcing. The committee does not accept the assumptions implied as a justification for the differential funding of the various education sectors. In essence, on a bipartisan basis, 100 per cent of the members of that committee believed, and still believe today, that our funding of primary schools per child, being less than our funding for secondary schools per child, is inadequate and inequitable.

It is true that little people have little voices. So little voices sometimes get lost in the clamour for funds, exciting new technology and new resources. Our committee expected that one reason we have historically always funded secondary students at a higher level than primary students is that little people have smaller voices. Parents may not realise what inadequacies there may be in the education of their young children of five, six or seven.

Our committee found that all over the nation there is an understanding that, if by age seven, or grade 3, young children do not grasp the fundamentals of literacy and English, do not have a full command of the English language and have no additional assistance, they will be disadvantaged for the rest of their lives. These children are placed at the risk of future failure. The numbers that we came up with are absolutely frightening. Somewhere between 20 and 25 per cent of the young student population of Australia may be at risk of failure because of inadequate literacy skills. Our committee went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also apparent that secondary students are more visible and vocal and therefore attract more attention. It is easier to recognise when the older students are "out of step". It appears to the Committee that our youngest children are almost invisible.

It is absolutely our duty to ensure that our young children receive the basic grounding and the basics of education that will serve them for the rest of their lives. It is certainly true that one will have a great deal of difficulty in studying history if one cannot read. The report went on to say:

Traditionally, positions in the primary sector have been the domain of women and have been viewed as positions of caring or a second job. As with all organisations consisting primarily of women, junior primary schools are marginalised when it comes to the allocation of resources. The Committee was told that the power and bureaucracy appears to be dominated by people who are not in the K-6 areas.

The government responded to our report. We recommended that over a period of three years we gradually increase the resources to primary schools so that the per child funding is equal to—or approximately equal to—the funding for secondary students. Government members responded to our recommendations by saying that they would conduct a review—one more review into a sector that has been under constant review since anyone can remember.

PARA.TAB: The problem is that we no longer have any data about how bad the situation is. While the requirements for high literacy standards are constantly increasing, we have no accurate data regarding the entirety of the young student groupings across Australia. But government members say that they will undertake another inquiry. They also said that an agreement was being reached between the Commonwealth and the teaching profession, through its teaching unions, for an accord to advance the quality of teaching and learning, which will assist in addressing some of the problems in The literacy challenge: strategies for early intervention for literacy and learning for Australian children.

There is no mention in the Commonwealth's report of doing anything about the curriculum in the universities and about teaching teachers how to teach young students how to read, which is certainly the crux of the problem. Our committee maintains that part of the problem is the lack of funding in the basic years to make certain that every child has a proper grounding on how to read, write and count.

I note that in 1985 the Commonwealth's contribution to primary and secondary funding, while demonstrably less than that of the states—the Commonwealth says that it is largely a problem of the states—was $225 per primary school student and $319 per secondary school student; that is, 41 per cent more in the secondary years than in the primary years. But, in 1994, the funding for those in their secondary school years had gone up to 90 per cent more than the funding for those in their primary school years. So the Commonwealth government has not responded to The literacy challenge: strategies for early intervention for literacy and learning for Australian children and has not responded to our request for increased funding for the early years of schooling.

Last week, an education committee in Victoria commissioned by minister Don Hayward, under the chair of Professor Brian Caldwell of Melbourne University, made a number of findings in Victoria's consideration of how to fund schools under its schools of the future program, which essentially gives global funding for those schools ready to take responsibility for their own funding, for their own distribution of funds and for how they spend funds in order to achieve high quality education outcomes. In essence, that report by Professor Caldwell said:

SPEECH.PARA: More primary school students would be at risk of becoming illiterate adults unless governments increased funding in line with that for secondary schools.
The report continued:
. . . it was time federal and State governments reviewed their funding priorities to ensure the learning needs of primary school children were adequately addressed.
The professor of education said he feared more students would join the bottom classes of the school population if governments did not move to resolve such funding inequities.

PARA.TAB: The report of the committee goes on to recommend not cutting funding for secondary schools and not absolutely guaranteeing that all the years of primary schools have the same funding as that in secondary, but that at least the early years of primary school receive substantial increased resourcing over the next several years so that we can make sure we get the basics right.

It is like a tree. If there is no foundation, if there is nowhere for the roots to grab hold, how on earth will the tree grow? It is the same for our nation's children. We can have all the sophisticated curriculum in the world, we can offer them all the modern scientific aids and all the educational assistance that is possible, we can buy the highest degree of modern technology and put it in place in our classrooms, but if we do not teach them how to read and write we will fail. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate today to bring to the notice of this House the actions of the New South Wales coalition government, which I believe is violating the principles of federalism and short changing and deceiving the electorate of New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: I raise this matter because last week we saw the Liberal Treasurer of New South Wales bring down a budget transparently designed, I believe, to curry favour with the electorate. This budget was designed to be everything for everybody—higher spending and no tax increases. But when we look behind what I feel are the most deceiving mirror tricks, we find a budget of deception, the misuse of federal government grants and a cheap, desperate gamble to try to win the March 1995 New South Wales election.

As an example, last year the federal government provided for New South Wales the sum of $51.8 million in road funding. I was shocked to see in the New South Wales budget for 1993-94 that the state government had diverted a significant amount of funding away from roads. In fact, the amount the Fahey government had diverted was—surprise, surprise—$51.8 million, the exact amount that the federal government had allocated for expenditure on roads. I assure the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) that this is factual.

Now, thankfully, the New South Wales coalition government has given a commitment—after, I might add, a very public voice campaign by the Local Government and Shires Association—that this year's federal government roads allocation of some $103 million will not be accompanied by diversion of an equal amount of state funding from roads within New South Wales. The Fahey government unfortunately has given this commitment—surprise, surprise—for one year only, election year.

This is an example of deception for which I believe the New South Wales coalition has become famous. My mind goes back to when the then government gave a commitment to the people of New South Wales that a $60 a year Water Board environmental levy would be spent cleaning up the state's rivers. The levy raised approximately $100 million in the first year. The government then took $100 million from the Water Board for consolidated revenue and had the audacity to claim that it was a different $100 million.

Of course, the then chairman of the Water Board resigned in disgust at the government's action. I believe that the state lost a very hardworking and committed person in David Harley—a person, I might add, who was appointed by the coalition and who we always thought was committed to its principles. But he was, as proven by his action, a highly principled person who resigned when that step was taken.

I turn to another tax that has been implemented in New South Wales by that government: the 3x3 road tax. I believe that the Fahey government has abused the goodwill and public trust by effectively diverting federal road funding to other areas. The New South Wales government is crying out for more money for roads and is claiming that it must continue to impose a tax of 3c per litre for its roads program, and then it has the hide to effectively divert its federal government grants from those same roads.

When I look around my electorate and see all the great work that has been done with our federal government road funding—especially the black spots program—it certainly makes my blood boil to think that the state government can continue to divert funding, provided by our federal government, from roads. The New South Wales government could find enough money to shamefully pork barrel the Parramatta by-election to the tune of some $1.5 billion but then found it desirable to divert funding from roads.

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't do them any good.

—As the honourable member points out, the Liberal Party got a rude shock in the Parramatta by-election—a swing of some 10 per cent to the Labor candidate who won that election, Gabrielle Harrison. I congratulate her. I would have thought that our Liberal coalition would have learnt its lesson in that by-election.

PARA.TAB: The people of Parramatta showed a sophistication and an intelligence that obviously surprised Premier John Fahey. But he seems to think that he will get away with a con job on a state wide level. I do not know why. I think the basic premise of federal-state financial relations is the fact that federal grants are meant to supplement state funding of particular government activities. I believe that the President of the New South Wales Shires Association, Wal Mitchell, explained the situation admirably when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The credibility of the state government in making claims on the Commonwealth Government for additional funds will become a charade if this duplicitous action continues.

I believe that Mr Mitchell has hit it in one. After every COAG meeting the premiers—John Fahey is one of the loudest—claim that the federal government has sold them out. John Fahey's words will be hollow indeed, when he has sponsored a deceitful action such as this. The state governments keep asking for more untied grants, but when they behave like this, undermining the Commonwealth's program to give money to New South Wales roads, they show that they really cannot be trusted.

PARA.TAB: In the time left to me, I would like to comment briefly on the other fiscal deception by that state government: the proposal for a referendum next year which would enshrine a balanced budget, an idea of which Joh Bjelke-Petersen would certainly have been proud. This is deceptive on a number of fronts—and let not the people be fooled. Firstly, the New South Wales parliament has the power to entrench clauses in the New South Wales constitution without recourse to a referendum. So, if the government really wants to go down this path, it could merely put the proposal to a vote in the New South Wales parliament. Secondly, it is well known that the budget sector is only one part of the government expenditure and revenue and governments can expand and contract what constitutes the budget sector for its own accounting purposes. Thirdly, as the Fahey government knows, this is voodoo economics at its worst.

State budget deficits are a perfectly acceptable weapon of management within the right circumstances. The Fahey government should know this better than most because, despite all of the callous cutbacks which New South Wales has experienced since 1988, it still runs a budget deficit. As the Professor of Accounting at the University of New South Wales, Bob Walker, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: The increase between 1988 and 1993 of $7.5 billion is arguably the largest growth in liabilities in the history of New South Wales.

Surprise, surprise! Who was in power in New South Wales during this time? It was the Liberal coalition government. In 1988, after the Curran report, the incoming ministers were wandering around saying what a disgrace it was that the level of state liabilities was so high, and they have presided over the largest increase in liabilities in that state's history! Hypocrisy is a common theme running through that government—hypocrisy on road funding, hypocrisy on budget deficits.

PARA.TAB: The Fahey government has treated its electors with contempt—and it will meet the fate it deserves when obliged to go to election in March 1995. I condemn particularly the actions it has taken so readily and so openly, having seen at first-hand the problems associated with road funds being deviated to other areas. As I have said in this grievance debate today, well do we remember the commitment which was given: we have all continued to pay that water board levy in the belief that moneys raised would be used to clean up the rivers. In fact, there was a private members debate here today on the River Murray. If we do not watch it, there will be many more problems within the state of New South Wales because of the irresponsible leadership and, more particularly, the irresponsible government which has imposed on the state of New South Wales one of the highest debt servicing liabilities it has had. I condemn the government for that action.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Computer Security

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's grievance debate, I wish to bring to the attention of the House the serious matter of deletions made to audit report No. 44 1993-94, which revealed instances of maladministration in a tender process and allegations of espionage on the Commonwealth of Australia by an unnamed saboteur. This report concerned an investigation into tendering processes involving the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the electronic capture of passenger card data. The allegations made by the Auditor-General, Mr John Taylor, were alarming: that a Commonwealth department had paid almost $2 million in cash advances to a computer processing firm, without a contract and without protection for the Commonwealth; that one of these payments, for $850,000, was made by an officer with authorisation to make payments on behalf of the Commonwealth of just $20,000; and that deliberate sabotage of the DILGEA computer was discovered by audit staff during their investigation into the activities of the department.

PARA.TAB: We learn from the report that, so serious was this act of sabotage, it hindered our own intelligence agencies in their attempts to investigate the attack two years ago on the Iranian embassy. We were told by the auditor that the DILGEA mainframe computer had shut down for `unexplained reasons' just 10 minutes before a public servant tried to get information on possible suspects. Evidence given in a recent magistrates court case in Canberra points to the fact that the saboteur could be the intelligence service of a hostile foreign power. These matters, both the system of capturing information and the act of sabotage, cannot be separated. They are intimately linked and concern the apparent lack of security involving the keeping and handling of records of the millions of people who enter and leave Australia each year.

My concerns arise from a document produced by the Crown in recently completed court proceedings in the Canberra magistrates court. This document proves that a senior officer of the Australian National Audit Office conducting the DILGEA audit became so concerned about the actions of certain DILGEA staff that he sought to have them charged with criminal offences. Subsequently I have learnt that the auditor, Mr David Berthelsen, wanted the staff charged with imposition upon the Commonwealth, under section 29B of the Commonwealth Crimes Act. Paragraph 15 of the document, supported by a minute prepared by Mr Berthelsen to his executive director in the audit office of 25 February 1993, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The report on my investigation of allegations against DILGEA is close to completion and could indicate criminal conduct on the part of several persons and raise grave concerns in relation to possible access of Commonwealth government computers by a foreign power.
The question which must arise is why these grave allegations were not probed by the responsible Commonwealth investigatory authorities or why the parliament was not made aware of them.

PARA.TAB: I am in possession of a list of names of those DILGEA officers whose conduct Mr Berthelsen has sought to have the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions probe with a view to bringing criminal proceedings for imposition. I am also told that a company officer of the firm that benefited as a result of these cash advances was also under suspension and that a strong prima facie case particularly exists against this individual and the most senior of the DILGEA officers. I do not wish to name these people in this place but would be prepared to give their identities to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) for appropriate further action. Other information which has come into my possession alludes to the fact that Mr Berthelsen, acting on the instruction of his superiors, was ordered to withdraw briefing material he had made over to the DPP. He was also, to my understanding, instructed to shred the same documents and all other copies of them.

I now turn to the serious matter of national security and how it was impacted upon by what appears to have been a deliberate act of sabotage on DILGEA's electronic data collection processes, and how an ineffective DILGEA security system allowed the staff of an immigration data processing contractor to have unauthorised access to the DILGEA computer. This issue—which began with the awarding of the tender to process the data to a company trading as Keydata, the cash advances, and the apparent acts of sabotage—dates back to early January 1992, when DILGEA decided to use off-site private contracting as a means of processing incoming and outgoing passenger data. As a result, a private company was given data line links to the computer, thus providing an ideal opportunity for any would-be saboteur to engage in acts against the Commonwealth.

We know now as a result of Auditor-General Taylor's report that, on 21 January 1992, within a week of Keydata receiving DILGEA approval to undertake the work, vital DILGEA computer system records disappeared. Auditor-General Taylor has also revealed that on that day, which was three months before the attack on the Iranian embassy, four hours of vital computer records were deliberately overwritten with a string of zeros. Information I have been given indicates that the data which was wiped from the 21 January tape may have identified who accessed the department's mainframe computer without authorisation, and the same persons could have loaded and activated the software which subsequently, three months later on 12 April, caused the system to crash. Clearly, off-site processing would have created the perfect window of opportunity for a would-be saboteur.

It is now history that the attack on the Iranian embassy occurred on 6 April 1992, and that the sabotage of the DILGEA computer prevented an investigation from uncovering passenger movements involving suspected terrorists. A number of well placed sources who are aware of this matter are convinced that this sabotage was the work of a foreign intelligence service. It is a fact that the failure was detected just 10 minutes before an entry control officer attempted to retrieve data about persons suspected of being involved in the Iranian embassy raid which had occurred six days earlier. Australian security organisations were widely criticised at the time for their lack of coordination in allowing demonstrators to breach embassy security. Frankly, DILGEA also should be roundly criticised for its improper management of computer security affecting the national interest.

So serious are these issues that Auditor-General Taylor sought to have his suspicions of the compromising of the DILGEA computer probed by the Defence Signals Directorate. I am also advised that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation was separately approached by Mr Berthelsen and treated his concerns seriously. It appears that our national security has been compromised by a conspiracy involving senior DILGEA officers in their haste to shift computer processing to premises of a private contractor. Senior auditor Berthelsen's minute, which surfaced in the recent court action, indicates that there may have been a fraud committed upon the Commonwealth in the awarding of the work to an outside contractor. It also appears that a deliberate attempt was made by certain Commonwealth agencies to shield these issues from the taxpayer and this parliament by diverting attention to a costly and abortive criminal trial against a journalist and a public servant.

These matters should be investigated by both the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Accounts and ASIO, without delay, with particular reference to circumstances involving the briefing documents Mr Berthelsen made over to the DPP and their subsequent shredding. I also believe that it is the role of the parliament to order material to be provided which would lead to the identification of the hostile foreign intelligence service which is alleged to have been involved. In conclusion, I seek leave to table the document and audit office minute from which I quoted earlier and which I did show to the previous minister at the table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is for the people of New South Wales—much like the grievance made in the previous contribution by the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). More specifically, I grieve for the young families of New South Wales, particularly those in south-west Sydney which includes my electorate of Macarthur. This area has thousands of young families comprising working parents with young children.

PARA.TAB: These young families are the people who depend on the quality, affordable child-care services which the federal Labor government is attempting to provide through our children's services program. But these families are being denied access to child-care services because of the mean and uncooperative attitude taken by the New South Wales Liberal government.

Honourable members would be aware that the children's services program is one of a number of joint Commonwealth-state funded programs in the human services area. Sadly, like most of the other joint Commonwealth-state programs, it has experienced major problems due to the intransigence and political obstructiveness of some state governments. There is no worse example of this than the situation with child-care funding in New South Wales.

Over the past decade, since the election of the federal Labor government in 1983, the federal government has sought to work in cooperation with state and territory governments to dramatically expand the supply of child-care places. This began with the 1984 20,000 places strategy and continued with the 1988 national child-care strategy which provided an additional 30,000 child-care places.

Cost sharing arrangements applied in New South Wales to the long day care component of the 1984 20,000 places strategy in New South Wales and also to the long day care and occasional care components of the 1988 national child-care strategy. In New South Wales, additional family day care places and outside school hours care places under these strategies have received Commonwealth-only funding. Other states were involved in cost sharing for funding of outside school hours care services, but New South Wales was exempted from this requirement in recognition of its contribution to the capital cost of new centres under these two strategies.

In the 1988 budget papers the federal government announced funding for the additional 30,000 places in the national child-care strategy. The total number of additional places funded in New South Wales under the 1988 strategy was 9,810—that is: 6,760 outside school hours care; 1,360 family day care; 1,020 long day care; and 670 occasional care places. However, unbelievably, of the 1,020 long day care places in the 1988 strategy, some 400 places are still not operational. Of the 670 occasional care places, less than half are operational. I understand that this outrageous situation is a result of a combination of lengthy bureaucratic delays at state government level and some hold-ups with development and/or building approvals at local council level.

If that is not bad enough, let us look at the 1992-96 national child-care strategy. Continuing efforts to negotiate cost sharing arrangements with the New South Wales government for this strategy are still unsuccessful. Former Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, announced in the 1990 election campaign that the federal government would extend the national child-care strategy by a further 50,000 places over the six-year period from 1990-91 to 1995-96. This is what is now known as the 1992-96 national child-care strategy.

At a meeting with state and territory ministers on 10 August 1990, the then minister, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), indicated that New South Wales's share of these extra 50,000 places would be 16,840. That is 9,840 for outside school hours care, 3,500 for family day care, and 3,500 for long day care places, which was the original offer. It was also indicated that future outside school hours care places would be funded on a `year round care' basis, that is, including vacation care as well as before and after school care as part of a package.

The Commonwealth's initial approach to New South Wales envisaged that funding costs for the new strategy would be shared as follows. For long day care, New South Wales would be asked to pay 100 per cent of capital costs and the Commonwealth would fund recurrent expenditure, such as operational assistance, fee relief and the New South Wales salary subsidy. For outside school hours care, the Commonwealth would fund 100 per cent of capital equipment and 70 per cent of recurrent expenditure, with New South Wales to pay the other 30 per cent of recurrent expenditure. For family day care, both capital equipment and recurrent expenditure would be 100 per cent Commonwealth funded. On 1991-92 prices it was estimated that this approach would cost New South Wales about $52 million in capital expenditure over a six-year period.

Following the Commonwealth's initial approach to all states, the Special Premiers Conference in late 1990 decided to review Commonwealth-state roles in a number of human services areas, including child care. A working party of officials was established in early 1991 to conduct a functional review of child care. Unfortunately, while the Commonwealth's offer of additional places to start in 1990-91 remained on the table, all states—including New South Wales—refused to enter into serious bilateral negotiations while the review was under way. Of course, this did not stop the New South Wales Liberal government from attempting to mislead the public about child-care funding just before the 1991 state election.

In an outrageous stunt the then Premier, Nick Greiner, released a statement three days before the election on 25 May entitled `Major Greiner Government Commitment to Child Care' which claimed that his government would create 10,000 new child-care places. However, after questioning, it was revealed that this was nothing more than a reannouncement of the 10,000 places in the federal government's 1988 child-care strategy—some of which, as I have already said, are still not operational. It was also revealed by the then federal minister, the honourable member for Jagajaga, that the New South Wales government was refusing to sign the new agreement which would deliver the 16,840 places in the 1992-96 child-care strategy. So the hypocrisy of the New South Wales government on child care was well and truly exposed just before the last state election back in May 1991.

We have another state election next year. What do we find? Suddenly, the New South Wales government announced in its budget last week a lousy $1 million for 1994-95, plus $10 million for 1995-96 for capital works on child care. There is an election coming up, so it wants to be seen to be making an effort. Of course, it is nowhere near enough.

The situation now is that the New South Wales government still has not signed the agreement. The young families of New South Wales are still being denied access to over 17,000 child-care places because of the New South Wales Liberal government.

The functional review of child care in 1991 was abortive. The working party was unable to reach agreement. In any case, the planned Special Premiers Conference of 1991—remember that?—which was due to consider a report from that review did not occur due to a boycott by state premiers. The Commonwealth attempted to resume bilateral negotiations with all states in early 1992. A set of proposed principles for the 1992-96 national strategy was considered at the April 1992 meeting of the Council of Social Welfare Ministers. These principles were endorsed by those ministers `as a basis for further bilateral negotiations to be finalised by end May 1992'. However, the New South Wales government, significantly, decided to reserve its position on this resolution.

Following the social welfare ministers meeting, bilateral cost sharing agreements were negotiated and signed between the Commonwealth, the ACT, the Northern Territory, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and Western Australia, that is, all states and territories except New South Wales and Victoria. The first of these agreements, with Queensland, was signed on 25 August 1992. Of course, in New South Wales we are still waiting.

This issue is of particular concern to me, coming from an electorate which contains some of the fastest growing parts of Australia, with half of the population under the age of 20 in some areas. Both Macarthur and the neighbouring electorate of Werriwa have thousands of young families with children under the age of five in new housing estates or in public housing.

The federal government was so concerned at this situation that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) wrote to the New South Wales Premier, John Fahey, in August 1993 requesting the New South Wales government's urgent cooperation. Although the letter was acknowledged, no further progress has been made in the 13 months since that time.

What has the New South Wales government got against the young families of the state? Is it true, as the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has said, that the New South Wales government cares more about casinos than it does about child care? It would certainly appear that for the Liberal Party child care is not one of `the things that matter'—certainly not in New South Wales—not one of the things that matter at all.

Are there still people in the Liberal Party—of course, with the dries taking over the agenda there—who do not believe that we should fund child care? Do they believe that mum should be at home looking after the kids? Or is it just another political stunt to draw this matter out until the next state election and suddenly try to get away with announcing a whole raft of child-care places that should have been announced before the last state election? That was when the federal government made its commitment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance this afternoon is about the political stunt being perpetrated by this Commonwealth government on the farming community of Australia. There has been a totally inadequate response from this government to the severe drought being experienced by most of rural Australia today. It is important to note that in some areas the drought is into its fourth year, and we have just seen the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) visit affected parts of Queensland, and just prior to that some affected parts of New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The government's response to this problem to date has been minimal. While it has been left to organisations such as the Smith Family and other welfare and community groups, and public donations from some areas of Victoria, the government has continued to talk big and deliver little. A little later I want to talk about a couple of community groups that have got together and raised funds to help the drought stricken. We await this week a major announcement from this government, which I think will be delivered on Wednesday. The government has been aware of this ever increasing problem for several years now. It has been aware that the RAS has not been effective at all. Yet, as is typical of this government, it continues to talk big and deliver very little.

In April 1989 under the Hawke leadership, with the current Prime Minister as the then restless Treasurer, the government decided that droughts were no longer natural disasters and that drought relief policies should be passed from Treasury to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. In what amounted to a very strange government decision, in 1990 the McInnes report further declared that droughts were no longer random natural disasters. They became something the current Prime Minister believes that we just have to live with.

Why is there this discrimination against drought as a natural disaster? The answer has not been given to date. Whilst natural disasters such as earthquakes, floods, fires, hurricanes and blizzards continue to receive preferential treatment, for some reason the poor old drought has been singled out by this Prime Minister and government as being part of an individual farmer's responsibility and something that a farmer has to put up with as an individual.

Why did the current Prime Minister dispose of the drought relief policy from the Treasury in 1989? It seems very strange. The Prime Minister's flippant and irresponsible attitude towards drought has a history. His current comments are a continuation of the lip-service that we have seen from him throughout his 1,000 days as Prime Minister and his time as Treasurer prior to that.

I say to the Prime Minister, `The drought has caught you out.' There is unrest not just within the rural community but also within the broader community. The public is fully aware of the Prime Minister's inertia on this issue, and it is time to draw some important comparisons. Is it not telling that it has been the public of Australia that has had to institute relief measures on its own? The people of Victoria sent fodder from Geelong to New South Wales and all points north. Television and radio personalities have raised money—a great example being Channel 9's farmhand appeal concert which raised more than $4 million. Welfare organisations are also taking collections for drought relief. The Smith Family has contributed over $50,000 directly to drought relief. The reasons for these public collections are clearly due to the absence of clear government leadership on this issue.

Is it not also telling to see the relative priority given to overseas aid in this year's budget—I think overseas aid received an eight per cent increase—when a significant number of Australian farmers are suffering on the breadline? This has been a four-year drought, and the government must have been fully aware of the problems in rural and regional Australia well before this year's budget was put together. Is it not telling that the Prime Minister has proposed $150 million worth of cosmetic changes to the Sydney Harbour scene, with the removal of the Cahill Expressway and given them a higher priority than the 83 per cent of New South Wales that remains seriously drought declared?

Finally, is it not telling that the government jumped to attention within 48 hours to strike a comprehensive deal with the Maritime Union of Australia whilst the four-year drought that has ravaged eastern Australia has been left to its own devices, as `something that we just have to live with,' to quote the Prime Minister's words?

What has been the government's answer to the drought problem so far? Basically, it has relied heavily on the rural adjustment scheme to solve its headaches. However, since the legislative changes of 1990 to the rural adjustment scheme, the RAS has proved totally inadequate in the first real drought since the amendments were made. Extended droughts of four or more years duration are manifestly beyond the competence of the government's present legislation to handle.

The RAS, to which the McInnes task force was fatally attracted, has been in operation in various guises since 1970-71. It is principally a means by which low interest credit and grants can be provided to farmers who meet relevant criteria. It is fair to say now, with the benefit of hindsight, that the recommendation of the McInnes task force that drought mitigation be incorporated in the RAS was flawed, and affected farmers have been highly critical of its administration. The detailed and unrealistic exceptional circumstances provisions of the scheme have also proved particularly inflexible.

The current drought is not only a natural disaster but also an administrative disaster by this government. Surely it is time to recognise drought as a natural disaster and find a far more accommodating way of dealing with it than via the RAS. If this government continues with its current policies, it will be the cruellest of cruel hoaxes on rural Australians.

It is for this reason that the coalition has developed a significant drought relief package that overcomes many of these hurdles. The three Rs package of relief, retention and recovery are important steps in the development of a genuine drought relief package. The coalition recognises the stupidity of the current approach.

We see the priorities in terms of the three Rs—relief, retention and recovery. Relief means fair access to help for the necessities, for the groceries on the table and for education. Retention means retaining farmers and as much as possible of their productive infrastructure, including their breeding flocks and herds. Finally, there is recovery. The drought will not end when the first rains come. Recovery in many areas and for many farmers will be slow and painful, and they will be in need of government support through that process.

One of the small communities in my electorate conducted a fundraising venture last Friday night for drought ravaged farmers in the local area and further abroad in the rest of New South Wales. The community of Wingham, a town in my electorate of around 5,000 people, saw a couple of local business people—Frankie Summerville and Grant Hawkins—organise a charity auction on Friday night. The donations came from around that small community—some 255 items in all—ranging from bags of dog food to Ray Martin's tie. All these items were donated to be auctioned on the night, along with a raffle that was to be run.

The total proceeds of that night, which will help local needy farmers through the farm aid appeal and the Smith Family, came to $27,000. Bruce Moy, Allan Skinner, Nick Smith, Steve Moy, Allan Edwards, Col Banks and Herb Beer conducted the auction on that night. They and the community in general should be congratulated for having the foresight to run the auction. As I said, a small community of some 5,000-odd people raised $27,000 towards the drought relief program and the aid programs that some organisations like the Smith Family are running.

Michael Clarke, one of the business people who donated something to be raffled, rang me on Friday afternoon. He asked, `Whatever we raise tonight at the auction, will the Commonwealth government match it dollar for dollar?' I said, `I certainly doubt it.' The Commonwealth government at that stage had been dragged kicking and screaming to this particularly nasty situation in rural Australia. But I said that I would put it before the parliament this week.

I challenge the government to match the money that was raised at that auction in Wingham—$27,000, helping some of the needy farmers in the drought declared areas not just in the western parts of New South Wales and Queensland but also fairly close to the coast. The challenge is there for this government to do something positive to help maintain our vital industries.

On Sunday in Taree, Radio 2RE conducted a radioathon and a charity concert which raised a further $8,640 for the needy farmers in the community. This included a donation of $1,000 from Taree Quota and $500 from the Taree Lions Club, as well as the donation of the 2RE staff's time to run the radioathon. From a small community on the coast, part of my electorate which has been ravaged by the drought, $35,000 has been raised in two days to help the needy farmers of New South Wales and Queensland. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move on to the subject of my grievance, I will make one small comment to the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) about his criticism of the federal government. One of the things the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did was to announce that the government would match dollar for dollar all the money that was raised on the Channel 9 farm appeal. So the $4 million that was raised on that telephone appeal will be matched by $4 million from the federal government. Moreover, all donations to the Smith Family for the drought appeal are tax deductible; therefore the government is supporting the appeal in that respect as well. I suggest that the honourable member wait till he sees the size and proportions of the package that will be put forward on Wednesday. I think he will find it is a very suitable and good package to assist in what is a very great disaster that is affecting all of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The subject of my grievance this afternoon is something I am not happy to talk about because it makes a small criticism of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I am sorry to do that because the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), is a good friend of mine and is a very good minister. I am sure that once I have pointed out this particular problem to him, he will respond very quickly and correct it. I think it is important that this matter be raised in the House and that we seek some urgent action on it.

The problem relates to widows of war veterans who failed to make the change, or failed to be notified comprehensively of the fact that they could switch, from being on a half rate Department of Veterans' Affairs pension to a single rate Department of Social Security pension. You might ask: what does it matter which department pays? It can mean a difference of up to $30 a week in income.

The problem is that at the time the death occurs the department informs the widow that it will assist with bereavement costs, with the funeral expenses. At the same time, it informs the widow that if she so chooses she can make the changeover. For a lot of people that particular moment in their life is a very tragic set of circumstances so they are not particularly focusing on their pension or on making changes. In a lot of cases, they are women in their 70s or 80s who have not had to worry about applying to the DVA, or had very little if any contact with it, because that was something their husbands did—in most cases the husband was the war veteran.

The widows receive a letter that says, `If you choose, you may switch over,' followed by about four other points. Unfortunately, because it is full of typical public service language a lot of the widows do not respond. So they are kept on a pension which is half the married rate of the war service pension.

Some of them do know what they are doing, are aware they have a choice and deliberately choose to stay with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. One reason could be they like the Department of Veterans' Affairs, know the staff well and are comfortable with that department. Another reason they choose to stay on a DVA pension could be that they wish to access health care through the Repatriation Commission and the repatriation hospitals. But a lot of people are not making the change because they do not know they are eligible for it. It can amount to more than $30 a week, as I indicated.

This problem was raised with me by one of my constituents, Mr Wally McMahon of Sunnybank, who found out about the difference in pension rates which affected his mother-in-law. His mother-in-law had been in receipt of a half rate married Department of Veterans' Affairs pension since her husband passed away in the middle of last year. She did not realise that there was anything unusual about it until she started talking to some of her acquaintances in her social circle at the local bowls club. They informed her they were on a totally different rate of pension and were in fact getting $30 a week more than she was. She was a woman who did not have a lot of other means to support herself, who did not have any other source of income, so a difference of $30 a week was quite substantial.

When she contacted the department she found out that yes, she could apply and make the changeover but it was up to her to make that change. The department indicated that it had actually written to her at the time of her husband's death and because she failed to respond took no further action. When I found out about this, I contacted the Department of Veterans' Affairs to find out what the situation was. I listed this as a question on notice so I could find out how many widows were in this situation of being on half rate married DVA pensions. I found out that there are over 3,800 women around Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—There are 3,800 women around Australia who are on the half rate DVA pension when they are entitled to be on the single rate pension from the Department of Social Security. I think that a large number of those women, if they were informed they had the capacity to make the change, would make that change and seek to be on the higher rate of pension. It is their entitlement and they have forgone a lot of income for a long period of time.

PARA.TAB: I would like the minister to ensure that each and every one of those 3,800 women is written to in clear, plain, simple language to explain what their entitlements are. I also suggest there be a reply paid form with that letter so they can indicate that they understand the information and that yes, they wish to apply for the single rate of pension from DSS or no, they wish to stay on the DVA pension. That information should be kept separate from other things widows are advised of at the time of their husband's death. It should be done totally separately a few weeks after the event when people have had a chance to settle their affairs and put their minds to such issues.

I ask the minister to write to all of those people, to find out how many of them are willing to switch over and to assist those women make the switch over to the Department of Social Security pension. As I said, not all of them will choose to do so but they should be allowed to make an informed decision and an informed choice with all the information placed before them.

The second issue I would like to talk about very briefly is the question of the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. Yesterday the minister announced the successful tenderer for the purchase of the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. The Ramsay Health Care Group, the hospital group which has purchased the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital in Perth, is the successful tenderer for the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. My congratulations go to Paul Ramsay and the Ramsay group for their successful tender. I congratulate them also on the package of proposals they have put forward for renovating and rejuvenating the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital.

I have a very strong concern for the veterans and war widows of my electorate and those of Brisbane who use this hospital and value it greatly. I am reassured by Paul Ramsay that the Ramsay group will maintain absolutely first-class service for all of those people and will ensure that the quality of health care that war widows and war veterans receive at Greenslopes is the best that is available. I certainly hope that will be the case. I am also reassured that the hospital will be an even better place with the injection of an additional $8 million of capital works being funded by the Ramsay group.

I am glad that decision has been made because there was a lot of uncertainty amongst the staff and amongst war service people in my electorate about what was going to happen to the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. I am assured the hospital will maintain its name; it will continue to be the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital. It will maintain a first-rate service for war widows and war veterans. It will continue to be an important facility in my electorate in looking after the needs of all returned service personnel who are eligible to receive hospital treatment there. Again, I congratulate the Ramsay group on its successful tender. I also congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for the manner in which he has handled that decision. I hope that he is able to respond quickly to my concerns about the widows and their pensions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak about the drought that is unfolding in Australia and in particular about the real attitude of the federal Labor Party towards this drought notwithstanding the recent discovery by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when he went to Queensland to see just how devastating the drought has been on a number of families, of how it is absolutely destroying families' lives, destroying local communities and giving people such little hope.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note in the business section of this week's Bulletin some very interesting and rather different views are being expressed about the effect the drought will have on Australia. It is very hard not to believe that the government did not have a very big influence on what was written in the Bulletin this week. The opening comments state:
Perverse as it may sound, the crippling NSW and Queensland drought may have delivered just what the federal Treasurer, Ralph Willis, needed: a timely brake on a potentially overheated economy.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems when we look at the effects of the drought on business we see what the government is really thinking. This article goes on to mention some Canberra views from a couple of sources. There is also mention that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, which is one of the government's own bodies, is expected to announce its revised estimates on the value of farm exports later this month. The article interestingly says:
While the value will be down from last year's $19 billion, government sources—
note `government sources'—
indicate the drop may be far less than $1 billion, possibly about $500 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a billion dollars in wheat alone.

—As my colleague the member for Murray interjects, the loss in wheat alone will be well over $1 billion. This article demonstrates the government's real attitude towards country people, towards the farming community and towards those rural towns which have been suffering so much under this severe and prolonged drought.

PARA.TAB: The sad conclusion is that there is an obvious attempt in this article, through the government's sources and the references to the Treasurer (Mr Willis), to downgrade the significance of those being affected by the drought. In other words, the impression is given that they are really second-class citizens. It seems the real agenda was set by the Prime Minister's earlier remarks when he suggested that drought was just a normal part of farming. What I find equally amazing in this article is the statement:
Such expectations give Willis the heart to stick by budget forecasts for growth of about 4.5%.

SPEECH.PARA: Again it reinforces this extraordinary attempt by the government to indicate that it might even have planned this drought as a way of making sure that its forecasts for the overall economy are going to be met. But what is really frightening is that the government shows an incredible ignorance about the ongoing effect of a drought.

PARA.TAB: We have to look at the very real difference between this drought and the 1982-83 drought, when most farmers were in a slightly better position than they are today to withstand a drought. Farmers have now been through the recession we had to have, through the crippling interest rate regime that the Prime Minister imposed on this country, and have basically been weakened in most cases by some very low commodity prices, particularly in the wool industry. It is really only at the very bottom of the article that we find any reference to the longer term impact that this drought is going to have in the loss of wheat markets and in the loss of some very good beef markets that have been opened up in Japan and Korea, and the fact that down the track it could have a very major impact on the ability of the wool growing industry to sustain itself two or three years hence.

So I find the whole attitude expressed in this article frightening. If it is a reflection of the government, then the government ought to be condemned because clearly it shows that it has consigned country people to second-rate citizenship.
