TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I salute Andrew Peacock, who ultimately resigned late on Saturday night, on the service he has given to the parliament. I am delighted that the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), as father of the House, will also be speaking, as will one or two other members. Andrew Peacock was a party leader for a very lengthy period. He held no fewer than four key portfolios in his own right: he held the portfolio of foreign affairs from 1975 to 1985; he held the portfolio of the environment, which people often overlook, for a brief period in 1975; he held the portfolio of external territories in 1972; and he was one of the last to hold the portfolio of the army, which he held from 1969 to 1972. He was in company with Bob Katter Sr, the then member for Kennedy, who was the very last Minister for the Army before the portfolios were restructured.

PARA.TAB: In paying tribute to the work of Andrew Peacock, let me hasten to add that he is very much alive. Someone listening to the initial accolades which were given earlier this afternoon rang my office to see whether he had suddenly died. Andrew Peacock made a decision to step down as member for Kooyong and a long serving member of the House of Representatives. On a personal front, I add that he was a very genial companion around the circuit, but he did make a real contribution not only to the governance of Australia but also to the linkage of Australia with Papua New Guinea and Asia. Before it became fashionable and enjoyed the priority that it always deserved to enjoy, Andrew Peacock was building up links between Australia and Asia in the early days. Importantly, he provided the base for those subsequent developments.

I salute the work done by Andrew Peacock. I acknowledge that he went to Scots College in Melbourne, which I had reason to clash with on occasions as I went to school just down the road. I acknowledge that his tips in football and racing were sometimes lousy, but I equally acknowledge that Andrew Peacock gave his very best in representing the electors of Kooyong; in carrying out with diligence and some cut-through thinking the responsibilities of the portfolios which he held, especially that of foreign affairs; in speeding up the process of the independence of Papua New Guinea; and in helping to build a myriad of relations for Australia's sake. He did this not only through his role as Minister for Foreign Affairs but also through the many delegations that he led overseas. He also did this through work with the Pacific Democrat Union and subsequently the International Democrat Union, of which he was president for a lengthy period. Good luck, Andrew Peacock. Congratulations on a job well done!

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It would not be appropriate for Andrew Peacock to exit this place without at least several contributions from this side of the House. I note that my colleague the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) is here with us and I suspect that something may be forthcoming from him in the course of the afternoon. This gentleman whose career we celebrate in our remarks is worth an hour or two of the parliament's time, but not in the context of a valedictory which requires us to be entirely reverential. He is still very much alive and, if we should wish to take a boot to him every now and again during our remarks, it would be entirely appropriate. Nevertheless, it ought to be done in the framework of a recognition of a well-structured career and a job well done.

PARA.TAB: The British define the five great offices of state in the United Kingdom as the Prime Minister, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the Home Secretary, the Foreign Secretary and the Leader of the Opposition. We do not have a home secretary position in our system of government as we have states. Most of the tasks performed by the Home Secretary are performed by state governments. I note that Andrew Peacock held half of the four offices that the mother of all parliaments and the government based on it determine are the substantial offices of state to which all in politics ought to aspire at some point in their political careers. He held a few others, and those who have already spoken have pointed to that.

In recent times, Andrew was not averse to dropping hints on his retirement. In anticipation of his retirement, he became less and less discreet, particularly in the fortnight between when he told his party leader of his intention and when he ultimately chose to resign. I had the privilege of being regaled on the subject at a recent ministerial dinner. I said that I thought this was an unusual decision on his part and that I thought he would want to have left parliament as father of the House. He looked at me quizzically and pointed out that it had an occupant. He did not expect to live as long as it would take that occupant to leave the position. He can subsequently speak for himself and no doubt announce his intentions on that.I have been at various dinners trying to get rid of him and it all seems to have been without any success at all. Perhaps Andrew's judgment on that matter was as sound as his judgment has been in many other areas.

In many ways, whilst his career was substantial, it must have had elements that gave him less satisfaction than it could have. It cannot have been his anticipation in political life that the last 12 years of his period as a parliamentarian would be spent in opposition. That was not the nature of politics at the time that he entered politics and it has not been the nature of politics in the entire history of Federation until this last 12 years. Given his substantial capabilities and the wonderful luxury of the seat that he held, a luxury which has been denied me the entirety of my parliamentary career, he would have anticipated at some point in time taking over the mantle of prime ministership. It was certainly anticipated by his revered leader of the time.

Even though he spent much of his period in politics in opposition, he was a man of his times. Both sides of politics came to respect Andrew Peacock quite a bit in the late 1960s and 1970s. He was Minister for the Army who sat most uncomfortably with the policy of the age. He was not convinced that the best possible representation of Australian political interest internationally was served by continued commitment to the war in Vietnam. He must have been grateful that those tensions were resolved by Prime Minister Gorton when he began the process of phasing out Australia's military commitment to that war.

Andrew Peacock clearly learned a great deal more when he visited Vietnam than was learned by the people who shared his type of position amongst the other allied forces engaged in it. As more and more emerges from the record in the United States, it is quite evident that more than a few of his ministerial contemporaries in that country also came to share his views. These were not views that he could publicly express in the Australian parliamentary context, apart from inside his organisation. The extent to which he did will not really be revealed for probably another few years, as it is determined by the extent to which there is some restriction upon all matters considered by government at the time.

He then presided over the first phase of the independence of Papua New Guinea. That is a personal triumph. It is a triumph that did not just reflect his views on wishing to create for himself a name in some aspect of endeavour prior to his going on to better things. Throughout the period of long Liberal Party and National Party government, by and large those who held the territories portfolio held it with a seriousness of intent and purpose that belied the extent to which they were ignored by most of their parliamentary colleagues during the period that they held it.

The extent to which Andrew Peacock took it seriously was reflected by the fact that he persisted long after the issue had passed from his hands in efforts to ensure that the changes succeeded. One newspaper report noted that he has visited Papua New Guinea on no fewer than 54 occasions. That is an extraordinary level of personal commitment. It stands him in good stead and augments the significance of his achievements in that portfolio.

He became foreign minister for a lengthy period of time. I guess that, with all his experience as a minister, judgments about his ministerial capabilities must stand or fall on what one thought of him as a foreign minister, because he served in other portfolios for not the length of time that would give one an opportunity to make judgments about them one way or the other.

We on this side of the House would not concede that he is Australia's most substantial foreign minister. We think we have one of those wandering around in the position at the moment and another not bad one wandering around in an even more elevated position. We have more than a sneaking sympathy for Bert Evatt who also held that position. If we failed to mention Gough Whitlam, most of us would have our heads torn off.

The fact of the matter is that the Liberals have had a number of very good foreign ministers. Casey was one of them. He was a really outstanding foreign minister. Certainly if we take the period of time in which Andrew Peacock was foreign minister and in politics in the 1960s and 1970s, we will find that his contribution was substantial.

He had to handle a deeply wounded policy process. Whatever might be said about the rights or wrongs of Australia's participation in the Vietnam War, its corrosive effect upon the conduct of Australian foreign relations lasted for at least a decade after our involvement in it. It was a very difficult one to handle in the regional context and an extraordinarily difficult one to handle in the domestic political context. It was an era which required a lot of redefinition in relationships with old allies and in future commitments in the region, in which policy was seen in the 1960s not to have emerged as howlingly successful.

Oddly enough, the difficulties that the society had in coming to grips with that outcome was reflected in many other areas of national activity at the time. For example, when I was a university student, we all did Asian studies. Asian studies virtually all but disappeared from students' interests in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Everybody felt that intellectually the area had been talked out.

So it was a credit to Andrew Peacock as foreign minister that he kept developing a detailed policy direction towards the area. He had to compete with a Prime Minister who did not necessarily share his objectives and who certainly did not want to share any triumphs. Some of the feeling on that led him ultimately to resign from his position. One of the most dramatic moments I experienced as a new member of parliament was to sit in the chamber and see Andrew Peacock standing up at the back of the gathering and detailing to the parliament why he felt he could no longer successfully be a part of his Prime Minister's government. It was a performance which again did credit to the man. He deserves plaudits for it.

It is a matter for the Liberal Party to make judgments about whether his period as Leader of the Opposition and his subsequent participation in opposition politics after the demise of the Fraser Liberal government suited the advancing of the interests of the coalition. There is no doubt that he did well in the 1984 election campaign in difficult circumstances. Personally—in the long haul it may not be possible for current coalition people to speculate on this—I think that the clashes between him and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) deprived the Liberal Party of credibility in experienced leadership. As a result, whoever may be at fault for that outcome has, at least on the opposition side of politics, damaged effective participation in national affairs. As I said, on this side of the House, who cares? On that side of the House, it is a matter that ought to be thought through.

I do not think, from the point of view of the nation, that we are necessarily well served by the disappearance of Mr Peacock from this place. There has developed a fairly silly view of national affairs that parliamentary careers are decade-long affairs and that members of parliament are encouraged to exit parliament and make pots of dough at the end of the process. As a result, state and federal parliaments are constantly stripping themselves of experienced assets. The insulting proposition is being put forward to the public generally, which has a large number of experienced people in their 50s, 60s and 70s, that a judgment is being made by those being engaged in the political process that somehow, when you reach that age, you are not fit for public life. This is a judgment that no other country has been able to arrive at. That may suggest that they are perhaps right and that we are not. It is unfortunate that Mr Peacock has taken that view and decided to take himself out of the race.

We do not have to hope that he enjoys his retirement; we know that he will absolutely wallow in it. He has organised for himself a level of private interest outside this place which guarantees him joy until the day he dies. That is terrific for him. Given the contribution that he has made to national life over the last 28 years, we all ought to be able to vicariously enjoy that for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said earlier today, the former honourable member for Kooyong left this House in the way that he pursued much of his career, and that was with some flair. That he left so soon and with such little regard for the feelings of those of us who might have wished to say something about him I thought rather remarkable and typical of the man.

PARA.TAB: Like others in this place, I have known Andrew Peacock in the good times and in the bad times. One of the sad things about our democratic process is that, over the last 11 years, those of us who are members of this place have not really been able to see Andrew as a minister. They have seen Andrew in that other role, in which at times I found myself in disagreement with him. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and I look back and wonder, `What if?'

Having said that, of Andrew Peacock there are several lessons and matters that one can both commend and from which one can draw reference. In the first instance, of his ministerial record, there is little doubt that, as the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has just suggested, he was very much a man of principle and he made a very considerable contribution within cabinet. I was one of those who served with him in each of the successive portfolios that he held. When the record of cabinet is released—it will be within the next few years—many will see that, in the course of cabinet deliberations, Andrew Peacock made a very notable contribution on a far wider range of issues than just those portfolios he held.

I thought the Leader of the House was rather generous in his assessment of the status of the foreign affairs portfolio. I rather thought that was intended more for those whose presence in the political domestic scene might have been an embarrassment for the time being to whomever might have been the incumbent Prime Minister. Consequently, it is normally a portfolio allocated for reasons to attract people outside the country than to allow them to participate in the political process.

Certainly it has often been true that in cabinet debate foreign ministers have been at a disadvantage. Their departments have had little opportunity for briefing on, and understanding of, the domestic policy process. We often tend to criticise them for being ciphers of others, rather than having knowledge of their own.

Andrew was not of that order. While I note the names of those referred to by the Leader of the House as distinguished foreign ministers, I assure him that there are few who have enjoyed, and still enjoy, better personal relations with those who are of consequence in governments around the world than Andrew Peacock. In the foreign policy field, he was certainly able to give an Australian emphasis at a time when we were not quite so assertive, simply because we were younger and not quite as independent as we are today. There were many occasions before he became foreign minister, particularly in relation to policies on South-East Asia—the Leader of the House mentioned the Vietnam commitment—when Andrew Peacock's views were considerably in advance of his time.

There are several aspects of Andrew's career that many perhaps did not see. The first is that Andrew was an excellent chairman. Of those with whom I have served, there are few who I believe could chair meetings more effectively. He set about the task of chairing a meeting with the idea not of imposing his view on others but of setting an agenda which would ensure that deliberations could be pursued, discussion would follow and a conclusion would be reached. I am afraid that for many, particularly in the parliamentary scene, reaching a conclusion is the last thing on their mind. Andrew, on the other hand, always pursued the chairmanship of a committee, whether of cabinet or of other parliamentarians, in a way which ensured the meeting deliberated on whatever was before it and concluded before everybody could get bored to sobs with whatever the subject matter might be.

The second aspect of Andrew was that he really is great fun. Apart from this devotion, he had a bit of a commitment to the racehorses though I found some of his stories a little hard to believe. The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) suggested that he was not always accurate in his tips, yet he is the only man I know who has successively picked the winners of the Melbourne Cup. In that, he was remarkable. I do not know whether it was because of his contacts or for what reason, but he certainly is knowledgeable in that field.

In terms of company abroad and at home, I had some wonderful journeys with Andrew. I know that much of it flowed from the fact that he is basically a good bloke. He is always a good conversationalist and he is always prepared to listen to others. He will argue his own point of view but I found on many occasions whilst travelling that, by listening to Andrew, I did get a different slant on things—sometimes more liberal than the natural views I might affect, including in Phnom Penh when the Australian embassy had been vacated. We took Neil Davis from Phnom Penh because at that stage it was about to collapse into the hands of the Khmer Rouge.

On many occasions abroad, I have found Andrew to have a diverse range of contacts that has stood this country in good stead. When I started my speech, I talked about the problems of this generation not seeing him in government. I think it is unfortunate that men like Andrew Peacock have not been able to contribute in the way that you can in government towards the changing attitude of this country and the relationships we have, for example, in APEC, in the changing relationship we have with ASEAN and with some of the contacts that I think are necessary with the United States.

In Andrew's personal life, I have known Susan and Margaret—his two wives—particularly well, as Andrew and I were in politics together. I mention them because they were also very important in his life. They were important in assessing the role and contribution of Andrew Peacock as a parliamentarian. It is sad that, for so many of us, Canberra is so far. It is the place away from our homes and it becomes extraordinarily difficult to care for the normal family predicaments and crises. We rely so much on our wives or, for female members of parliament, on our husbands to do so. But I think it is an indictment of this place and of our system that it is very difficult for somebody who is a senior minister and who has a commitment both to politics and to his country that he must give up so much in order to pursue his career successfully.

I was one of those who at one stage wondered as a result whether it would not be a good idea for the parliament to provide homes for senior ministers and perhaps opposition members in this place simply so it would be seen as acceptable—as, for example, it is in New Zealand—for those who are involved in this process to have a presence here. On the other hand, I think when you look at the other dimension you realise that if you are too committed to Canberra perhaps you do not really know what happens in the rest of Australia, and that is a disadvantage. But there is a price you pay in the family sense and I do not think anybody has paid it to a greater degree than has Andrew Peacock.

On the general professional level, there were without doubt proper tributes paid during the remarks made regarding Andrew's role in Papua New Guinea. One thing that many perhaps did not see is the personal relationship Andrew has had with successive generations of PNG politicians. While Ceb Barnes, Andrew's predecessor in that portfolio, really set the groundwork for economic independence, there is no doubt that Andrew's personal relationships have been a very significant factor in preserving democracy, though not in the context peculiar to the Westminster system, in the sense that a parliamentary majority has determined successively who that country's Prime Minister will be. When you look at our region, you will see that to an extent democracy is really a fairly jaded flower. In Papua New Guinea, it is strong, it is vibrant and it is effective. It is the parliamentary voice that ultimately counts and the voice of the electorates that determines those who will be members.

In my view, Andrew Peacock has had a very dominant influence in that. That personal role he plays—even so late as last week, when together we were with Sir Julius Chan—is one which dates to a personal relationship and not one just on an official basis. I think Andrew's greatest personal strengths are his knowledge of Pidgin and his capacity to look at most subjects as others see them. Indeed, he might say in relation to this motion, `Im buggerup finish.' He certainly is Im buggerup finish as far as politics is concerned but, for Andrew Peacock, I am sure the future is rich—both financially and I trust personally. I wish him well.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I think that I knew Andrew Peacock probably better than anyone else now sitting on this side of the House. There would have been people before my time who knew him just as well. I would like to direct my remarks more at a personal level but touch on some of the comments made by other speakers.

PARA.TAB: I agree with the assessments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the House, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), in relation to the contribution made by Andrew Peacock over 28 years. Undoubtedly, no members from this side of the House could associate themselves with the comments made by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) in relation to Andrew's professional capacity in serving this country.

It was disappointing that some of the press reflections tended to dwell far too much on a point taken up by the Leader of the House, that is, the last 10 years when Andrew was in opposition, the disputes with the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and matters such as that. Andrew Peacock had a long career before all of that, and people forget too quickly that he went very close to a very big upset in 1984—very close indeed. If you look back at that result, you will see that it was an extraordinarily good effort on his part on behalf of his party.

Like the honourable member for Swan, I also have some concerns about the somewhat glowing tributes from time to time about Andrew as a foreign minister because there are other contenders for that, including, of course, the present foreign minister, the heir apparent to the seat of Holt. I certainly hope that the heir apparent to the seat of Holt will spend a little more time in the seat of Holt than Andrew spent in Kooyong. That aside, as other speakers have said, I think that Andrew did make a very significant contribution to public life in this country. There is a lot more to a person who held the portfolios that he did, who led his party and who very nearly became Prime Minister of this country than a lot of people have been prepared to accord him since he announced his retirement.

On a personal level, I knew Andrew first at the university in Melbourne, although not well. In those days, the Liberal Party ruled the seas and, if you were acknowledged in the precincts of the university by people of Andrew's standing, you were grateful but you did not approach them. That was the era in which he grew up, the period when we were experts at being in opposition, a role and a mantle which has now fallen on the current opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably.
—Regrettably, in the minds of some. But he did see a change in that, of course. That was one of the things he adapted to.

PARA.TAB: Leaving aside the problems that we referred to earlier about his disputes and arguments with the member for Bennelong, which are not a matter of concern to us on this side of the House, he nevertheless played a significant role when not leader of the opposition over the last 10 years. He went into overdrive fairly easily, may I say, and was able to adapt to the different pressures that he had in the last few years. He had a bit more time to concentrate on matters he liked so much, such as the races and football—interests that I shared with him. I think that is how I got to know him so well over the last 10 or 12 years.

The point I want to make about Andrew Peacock is one that I think we all ought to think about in this place from time to time as between ourselves on each side of the House and certainly as between the government and the opposition. I found Andrew Peacock to be a person who did not breach any confidence—and there were quite a few—that I shared with him over a period of 10 or 12 years. When I look back to those periods when I was acting foreign minister during the period of the present Governor-General's occupancy of the foreign minister's portfolio and later that of the present foreign minister, there were many occasions when briefings were given to Andrew—of course, this would have applied to other shadow ministers and other leaders of the opposition, but I did not deal with them as much as I did with him—and I was always very comfortable in giving any information to him. Later, when I was Attorney-General, on matters involving security the same thing applied.

But on a personal level that also applied. I often reflect on conversations that I had with Andrew which, if he had been different, I would have very much regretted. But at no stage did I have any concern about that, and I thank him for that. It is a tribute to Andrew that I was able to trust him so much over those years.

He is a very keen racegoer, owner and punter and has been a very keen follower and No. 1 ticket holder of the Essendon Football Club for many years. He enjoys his racing. Talking about his style, I noticed him on Saturday at Caulfield, impeccably dressed, with the binoculars casually slung over his shoulder and The Wizard form guide, which he follows very closely—it is a huge thing—stuck under his arm. He was all style on Saturday at the races. He did not back very many winners, but he looked the part.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you?

—No, I had every bit as bad a day as he did, but that is not relevant to this discussion. He loves the football. We shared a lot of very happy days at Windy Hill, which was the old Essendon ground. Since we have moved to the MCG I have not seen him as much because he tends to sit in the members' stand whereas I retain some reserve seats in the southern stand, which are allocated to Essendon Football Club members. He enjoys his football immensely.

PARA.TAB: He is, as the right honourable member for New England said, basically a good bloke. I found that here, in the political sense, he was exceptionally good company, as somebody else pointed out. He had all of that about him which has been caricatured so much. He did have a lot of style about him, which at times became a bit unnerving and a bit irritating.

There is one point I have to take up before closing. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), made the point today in his speech—I happened to hear it in my room—that Andrew had an `extensive' knowledge of standing orders. I doubt that he ever read the standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you'd never know it.

—I must say that the member for Berowra has picked up the point that I was about to make. It says a lot about Andrew—it may say something about the member for Mayo, too—that he did not read the standing orders. I do not think he knew anything about the standing orders. But, when he took a point of order he took it with a lot of style, he appeared to know what he was talking about and people actually listened to him. I used to sit there somewhat bemused by the fact that he could get away with such outrageous things.

PARA.TAB: I know that in debates he knew absolutely nothing about the procedures that would take place. It used to always be a desperate situation, trying to work out what to do, when I was a minister and Andrew was on the other side. That is when we realise what great assistance we get from the clerks, who perform a tremendous job in this place. I remember many debates in which Andrew was on the other side of the table from me. The task the clerks had to perform in those instances was an enormous one because they had two people who had no idea of the standing orders. I mention to the member for Mayo that I think he ought to reflect very carefully on whether Andrew knew anything about the standing orders.

All that said, Andrew Peacock was a person who enjoyed himself here. He had a life outside of politics, as people have mentioned. He was good company. He made a good contribution to this country as a minister and as Leader of the Opposition. He is somebody whom I am pleased to see we are remembering today because he was a significant figure in Australian politics and he was a significant foreign minister. Irrespective of what views the Leader of the House and I may have about where he should rank, he was a significant figure in Australian politics and I think many of us at a personal level are going to miss him here.

I will still see a fair bit of him with the Jason glasses slung casually over his shoulder and The Wizard under his arm, and occasionally at the football; but I will miss him here because he was someone you could always have a bit of a talk to. He was always available to have a yarn about something. He did have a very good sense of humour. Mercifully, he did not take himself as seriously as some people thought he did, and that was the other side of him that was probably misunderstood by very many people.

He made a great contribution to this country and I wish him all the very best in his retirement. Somebody said, `Will he enjoy it?' Yes, he will. Somebody said, `He will wallow in it.' That is correct; but he will still be active. He has indicated that he will pursue business interests. I wish him all the best in whatever he does and thank him for a friendship which started in politics and I hope will not end with his departure from politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I first met Andrew Peacock in the 1960s when I was a member of the federal council of the Liberal Party and he was the state president in Victoria. He was a very imposing young fellow with all the world behind him and obviously going a long way. To us Queenslanders it was quite impressive to see this young person with such obvious confidence and command. We in the north are not used to those sorts of samplings of power at such a young age. So I was quite naturally attracted to this personality. As a period of time went by, one could not help but enjoy watching Andrew in action in a wide variety of roles.

PARA.TAB: Within the Liberal Party itself he was always a person to whom you could say, `We are a bit short on numbers at this function. We need to raise a few bob here. Will you please come?' The Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, knows what it is like when you get those invitations. You volunteer immediately with great enthusiasm, because it is a hard task to get a lot of people along.

Andrew would always do his bit and come along to those functions and, under the most trying circumstances, he would always put in a very good performance. I know only too well that, when you are in opposition for a long period of time, to get people to turn up at functions and raise money you do need someone like Andrew to come along. So I thank him for his role not only as party president but also as an involved member of the party.

Many people here have already spoken of Andrew's enormous contribution to the parliament. When I came here he was a minister. I was lucky enough to serve in the ministry with him in some amazing circumstances. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) commented upon the fact that foreign ministers do not always know about economics and things like that. There is no doubt that keeping people out of the country was a technique enjoyed by Liberal Prime Ministers, and there are very good reasons for it sometimes. But, to give Andrew his credit, when he did turn up at cabinet meetings at which economic matters were being discussed, he did a very good job—as the right honourable member for New England did a good job from time to time—making comments, which were really not that well researched, on matters on the agenda.

I can only say that a lot of people have not seen his contribution to government. He was a very good performer in the House. He was a person who could certainly command respect and make the appropriate speech, both in the House and at a public function. He could always present well no matter what the circumstances.

In terms of his ability to communicate with others and other nations, his role in New Guinea and America has already been commented upon. On a personal note, recently I travelled with him and the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) to China. We saw the most extraordinarily polished performance in terms of his ability to communicate with the Chinese foreign ministry and officials. He had a rapport with them. He could remember something about their aunt, uncle or something else. He certainly knew about the Beijing racetrack, which no-one else seemed to know about. He also knew about the one down south which the former Prime Minister was trying to find out about.

I travelled with him to America to attend the Republican Party convention last time round. He sailed onto the floor—and I tagged along with him—straight past all the guards with a bit of bonhomie, a slap on the back. They were not too sure who he was. I am sure that they had no idea who he was. Before we knew where we were, we were underneath the podium waving to everybody up there and Bush was waving down to those at the bottom. It was just like old home week. He did not just have those sorts of connections with the Republican Party; he had them with the Democrat Party.

I think Andrew's ultimate ambition was always to be the Australian ambassador in Washington. If that had been the outcome—there is no secret about it—he would have made an absolutely magnificent ambassador for Australia in Washington. No person could have done that job better. No-one was better qualified than Andrew Peacock to do it. If there has ever been a great loss, it is certainly that. His great contribution to Australia may well have been the ambassadorship that he did not get.

I am not going to say too much, except that history will probably show that if Peacock had won the leadership challenge with Fraser in 1982 the second time around—he did not have a chance of succeeding the first time: it had to be like the Hawke takeover and the Keating takeover; it had to be on the second roll of the dice—the outcome of the 1983 election would have been different and the problems of the coalition would have been entirely different. If there is one mistake that Andrew made that flowed on from that, it was his decision in September 1985. That was, in my view, his worst political decision.

Finally, as many have pointed out, he was a guy who was enormously interesting to travel with; he was great fun. He will be missed here, but he will be enjoyed outside. His life in the future will be what he makes it. To paraphrase someone else, he will be a lot happier, a lot looser and a lot richer. I wish him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Being relatively new in this place, I cannot speak with the same authority as those who have spent a long time here with Andrew Peacock, but I was involved with the organisational wing of the Liberal Party from the late 1970s onwards. I would like to support what the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has just said. If there was a good campaign on or if there was a fund-raiser and you wanted to raise lots of money, Andrew Peacock was the man to have there. That is where I first met him. Of course I met him again in the federal council and federal executive.

PARA.TAB: He was generous with his time and the encouragement that he gave to people in the organisation. That is something I would certainly like to place on the record today. He will be very cross with us because when I spoke with him on the phone and commented on the fact that he had gone without a party or any farewell speeches he said that he could not stand any of that. He would not want this to be happening. I think it is appropriate that we comment on some of his achievements and that has been done very well by other speakers before me today.

I would happily say, although those opposite would not agree, that his time as foreign minister and his grasp of foreign affairs would certainly exceed all others. When in South Africa recently, I was made aware of the reputation and friendships he had built up there. A reception that was put on in Johannesburg was attended by a number of members from the new government. Eddie Funde, who is not a member of the government but a member of the ANC, discovered that I was a Liberal and asked me to pass on his best wishes to Andrew Peacock, Robert Hill and Philip Ruddock. As I was leaving, he again asked me not to forget to give his best wishes to Andrew Peacock because he admired him greatly.

That brief experience of mine adds weight to what previous speakers have said about his time in foreign affairs. He certainly had all that charm and style and, therefore, he is memorable. As the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) said, it is a shame that 55 is considered old in this place and it is felt that once people reach that age they should go. Personally, I think it is a shame. There is nothing like experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no; I wouldn't think that at all.
—I am glad you are here. I do not think it is old. In other countries, the elder statesmen provide advice to those who are less experienced.

PARA.TAB: I wish Andrew Peacock well. In the Australian Financial Review of 16 September, Richard Farmer farewelled him with words which I think many politicians would be pleased to have written about them as they were departing. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing to record about Andrew Peacock the politician is that he will leave the House of Representatives as he entered it—a thoroughly decent man.

PARA.TAB: That in itself is no mean achievement

SPEECH.PARA: But then Andrew Peacock is probably one of those old-fashioned Liberals who believe that you enter politics to give service to the public, not just to gain personal glory. It is worthwhile remembering that.
I wish him well.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to add my remarks to the remarks of those who have spoken of Andrew Peacock. I do so from the perspective of both a political colleague and a friend. I have known Andrew Peacock for the best part of 30 years and I have watched his career—the highs and the lows. When we have talked about his attainments, we have done so in a way that does not display how close Andrew came to being Prime Minister of this nation and what a splendid Prime Minister he would have made. In 1990, Andrew led us into an election where we gained a majority of the Australian vote; more Australians voted for the coalition, led by Andrew Peacock, than for the Labor Party led by Bob Hawke. We obtained over 50 per cent of the vote. It was a cliffhanger for several days.

PARA.TAB: Andrew has been spoken about here as a man who was a splendid chairman, and he was. But he also had a talent that would have made him a good Prime Minister because he listened to those around him and he listened to the Australian people. He made a fine foreign affairs minister because he had the skill of making people look at where their interests could merge.

I first became aware of the high regard in which the people of Papua New Guinea held him when I went there in 1980. I went there in 1980 because, like him, I have a passion for the Pacific. I knew that Australia's future as an influential power and as a trading partner lay in our own region. In the late 1970s I made the decision that I wanted to visit the various countries around the rim so that I would have a personal network that I hoped would be useful in the coming years when I hoped to enter this place.

In 1980 I began by visiting Papua New Guinea because it is our nearest and closest neighbour—the people with whom we have had an enormously close relationship dating back to the war. It was there that I learned first-hand of the enormously high regard that people such as Michael Somare and Julius Chan had for Andrew. I was there at the time of the first successful vote of no confidence moved by Iamabakey Okuk, the leader of the Nationalist Party, who has since passed on.

The motion Iamabakey moved was the result of great negotiations that had gone on to stitch up the coalition. Julius Chan emerged as Prime Minister. To see him again as Prime Minister brings back many of those memories. Despite the fact that there was much rancour about whether or not there would be a change of government in 1980, each of them spoke to me and expressed the high regard that they had for Andrew Peacock and expressed their appreciation for the part that he had played in ensuring that self-government for Papua New Guinea meant that democracy was to reign in a new nation.

Andrew did have a lighter side. On many occasions he and I have been together at international meetings. We both served on the executive of the International Democrat Union. He chaired that union from 1989 until 1992 when he was succeeded by Carl Bildt, the Prime Minister of Sweden. He has the unenviable task of cleaning up socialism after it has been entrenched and held up to the rest of the world as the great way to go. He found the nation bankrupt. During those meetings he showed leadership. In bringing parties together from around the world, all his skills had to be brought into play to ensure that that was a successful and workable forum.

Many have spoken of his love and knowledge of the horses. I am pleased to say that last year he was able to give me the name of the winner of the Melbourne Cup months in advance. I did have the good sense to have a bet on it. It was not a great bet, but it was a bet that said to him, `I know your knowledge in this field and I am prepared to accept your advice.'

I know that Andrew is looking at his new life with excitement. Things will open up for him. The contacts that he has made and his friendship with the tremendously able and entertaining woman, Shirley MacLaine, whom I have had the pleasure of meeting, are important. I wish Andrew Peacock great happiness and great success in the future and thank him for the contribution he has made over almost 30 years in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to pay a personal tribute to Andrew Peacock. To a very great extent, he is probably the reason I am in this place now. In the early months of 1968 as a young television journalist I was sent on an assignment to New Guinea, armed with a 16-millimetre black and white Bolex camera and nothing much else, where a group of us made a series of documentary features regarding the emergence of Papua New Guinea. I suppose those few weeks I spent there at that time were the beginning of my fascination with that particular place. It was something that I followed through until such time as independence was granted.

PARA.TAB: It was in that latter period that I first met, had some dealings with and interviewed Andrew Peacock on a number of occasions. I suppose to a very great extent it was the nature of Andrew Peacock, the humanity of Andrew Peacock and the politics of Andrew Peacock that ultimately helped to attract me to a parliamentary career. I thank him for that.

I too was privileged to serve in government with him, although not in the cabinet. There is no doubt that he was one of the finest foreign ministers that this country has ever had. During my experience of serving on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for more than 10 years, I sensed the tremendous influence and numerous contacts that Andrew Peacock has throughout the world. It was really quite fascinating. It really did not matter which country was involved in the inquiries that committee undertook, where you went or who you met, somebody had some kind word to say about Andrew Peacock and had some connection with Andrew Peacock. In that respect, he has been a great ambassador for Australia. I concur with the statements made here today.

I was fascinated to hear the speech by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). I think he was perfectly correct when he said that one of the great tragedies has been that Andrew Peacock was never appointed ambassador to Washington. I sometimes wonder why somebody in government does not really have a look at what is absolutely required in that post in Washington, which is a terribly important one in the Australian context. The reality is that we should have someone with great political experience in that position. We need an ambassador who has the capacity to be able to penetrate the Hill. There is no doubt that politicians have the tremendous capacity to be able to talk to other politicians. With the way that place operates, it is not always possible for some of our career diplomats to have the access that we need to the decision makers on Capitol Hill. I agree that Andrew Peacock would have made an outstanding ambassador to Washington.

TALK.START.PARA: —Still could do so.

—He could still do so, as my colleague says. In a personal sense, I also have to thank Andrew Peacock for my second coming in this parliament. I lost my seat in 1983 and made a decision to give the parliamentary scene away, joining the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation. That was a very wise decision at the time because they were exciting times. We were opening up Queensland to international tourism and having remarkable success. I had been involved in the opening up of Cairns as an international destination and I was being used by that august corporation to deal with the federal government and to make a number of forays into overseas countries to try to enhance the numbers of international tourists coming to Queensland and obviously to Australia.

PARA.TAB: It was at that time the Liberal Party was looking for candidates for the 1984 election. Peacock rang me and asked whether I would be interested in standing again and I said no. It was then that the member for Ryan got on the phone, ringing three or four times, and in his inimitable style suggested that I should look at nominating for a seat. On each occasion I declined the offer.

When coming back on one occasion from southern Africa I arrived in Perth airport at some ungodly hour in the morning—I think it was about half past three or half past four Western Australian time—to be greeted by two telephone calls, one from the honourable member for Ryan and one from Andrew Peacock. I think long flights on international aircraft are a marvellous time for members of parliament to start thinking things out. After denying the offer on three occasions, I knew I had done the wrong thing. It was fortuitous that when I landed in Perth these phone calls were there, and I had a conscience which said, `You've got to do it.'

Andrew Peacock was the one who was imposing on that sense of community and that sense of service. Ultimately I decided I would take up that challenge and renominate for a seat. I am not sorry that I did. He gave me some tremendous opportunities in this place by virtue of my time on the front bench, and I thank him for that. He has been a very great friend. He has campaigned for me in every federal election since I first stood in 1974. As others have said, he was always there to assist in the Liberal Party cause.

I have one story about him that perhaps I should not tell, but I would like to. Some years ago, Andrew and his wife and my wife and I went away together on a holiday. Erica and I had decided that we were buying an el cheapo package holiday to Thailand—which I love—and Andrew said, `We might come too.' Armed with the full one-week package to Bangkok, off we went. What was to follow was quite fascinating. I do not think Andrew did much about it. We arrived at Bangkok airport as package tourists. We were greeted at the bottom of the aircraft stairs by a limousine, a red carpet and a number of people in military uniform. Andrew was whizzed off to the VIP section in this car while my wife and I made our way through the normal terminal and wandered inside. The difference was that, whereas we cleared customs and immigration in a matter of minutes, it took Andrew about 1 1/2 hours.

It was also fascinating to learn that was the first time he had a holiday overseas since he was 18 years of age. He had made something like 58 official trips on behalf of the government as foreign minister, but had never been on a holiday. He really took to it. Watching Andrew Peacock learning the due processes of bartering and bargaining in some of the clothing markets of Bangkok was something to behold. It was one of the most pleasant weeks that my wife and I ever had. We thank him for that friendship and for the friendship, kindness and hospitality he has shown to us both over many years.

One of the great tragedies is that Andrew Peacock was never Prime Minister of Australia. That sense of humanity that I was talking about, that capacity to be able to listen, to understand what people's aspirations were all about, would have given him the wherewithal to make a great Prime Minister. That is not to be and I think that that is one of the tragedies for Australia.

I wish him well. I am sure that he is going to have an absolute ball. I saw him in this place last Tuesday night when he told me of his intentions to retire and of some of the plans that he had for the future. They are exciting ones. I wish him all the very best. I know my wife would join with me in wishing him a long, happy and most prosperous retirement. Knowing Andrew, he will have exactly that.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There have been too many speakers from the opposition side and not enough from the government side. Although I did not know Andrew Peacock as well as the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy), I probably knew him for longer. Perhaps only the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) would have known him for longer still. They had quite a complicated association back in the days when Andrew first stood for the federal seat of Yarra, then held by Jim Cairns and based on Richmond—not the Richmond in New South Wales but the Richmond of Carringbush fame, just to the east of Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: I have to confess that I did not spend time with Andrew Peacock on the race track or even at the football. Where I seemed to meet him constantly was at airports and at breakfast, which used to be a great ceremonial in the old Parliament House but has not quite reached that status in the new Parliament House.

I endorse what has been said by a number of speakers. He was excellent company, a very honourable person and of extraordinary discretion. If you told him something in confidence, that is exactly where it remained. He did not become Prime Minister, I suspect because he did not have the killer instinct. That is essential for those who rise to the top. They must have an almost Messianic confidence in their own judgment, which I think Andrew lacked. I lack it too, so I am not saying that in a pejorative sense.

I got to know him a long time ago when there were a number of public concerns and matters of public policy on which we shared interests—and he would perhaps be out of step with some of his colleagues here. We both had a very great interest in civil liberties. We were both very concerned about the abolition of the death penalty. We were both very much concerned about censorship. No matter how we might have to rethink the situation now in the 1990s, there were certain absurdities in the 1960s and the 1970s where Andrew and I shared common ground.

He was also one of those people who played a very important role in taking the demonology out of foreign affairs. We all remember that time in the 1950s and 1960s when a lot of hysteria was generated on foreign affairs. It is to the credit of people like Andrew Peacock and, I have to say, Gough Whitlam—and Garfield Barwick, in another way—that they took the demonology out of foreign policy. It is a long time since there was a federal election where foreign policy was raised in a divisive way. That is a sign of our growing maturity. I think Andrew played a very important role in that. His role in Papua New Guinea has been justly praised.

Andrew Peacock was a good campaigner. He campaigned effectively in 1984. I suspect though, to some extent, it was because we campaigned dreadfully and for too long. The campaign seemed almost eternal. He finished the election campaign sounding and looking fresher than the then Prime Minister.

It was a curious election in 1990, when both major parties polled a smaller proportion of the total vote than probably at any time since the 1940s. Where people saw some option of voting for an alternative party—whether it was the Democrats, the Independents or the Greens—they took that option. The final result was long, drawn out and it led to a very narrow result in favour of Labor simply because the preferences flowed back.

The 1990 election was not such a terrific election for either major political party. It was the high point of political convergence; there was such a degree of overlap in policy that it was difficult to distinguish between them. I noticed a silent physical assent from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). That would not have been said of the 1987 election, but was true of 1990.

Andrew has been an excellent parliamentarian. The thing that many of us will remember about him was he had that grace and style. He also, in some ways, had more front than Myer's. He had the gift of friendship. Those of us who shared that gift will always remember it.

Normally these tributes are paid when people have been carried off horizontally. This is not the case for Andrew. He is still vertical, and long may he continue to be so. I am sure that he will do well in his next career. He goes with very good wishes from people on both sides of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This place is not short on humbug. I am not going to add to its reputation today by pretending that I have been, over the years, as close within my own party to the former member for Kooyong, Andrew Peacock, as others who have spoken in this debate. It is one of life's ironies that Andrew addressed the first public meeting I had as the candidate for Bennelong in All Saints church hall in Hunters Hill in April 1974. Some of the remarks he made in that speech provoked a then resident of Woolwich who was there as a member of the public—Michael Baume—to join the Liberal Party. He subsequently became a candidate in 1975.

PARA.TAB: It has been well documented that Andrew and I had some differences inside the Liberal Party, and I will not try to so rewrite history today to suggest that we did not have differences—of course we did. Like all differences that occur between people of activity and energy inside political parties, there was blame on both sides. I have indicated that, and so has Andrew. There is no doubt that those differences were, on occasions, regrettable from the Liberal Party's point of view. However, it is also the case, as so often happens with these things, that when a view about differences becomes institutionalised, that becomes the lazy scapegoat every time a political party does not do as well as people might have liked it to have done.

I am very happy to say that over the past few years—I have used the word before and I will repeat it today—the relationship between the two of us has certainly mellowed. At a personal level, over the past few years I have enjoyed the opportunity in a way that had not existed before, for a whole combination of reasons, to get to know Andrew better. There is not a lot that I can add to what has already been said today. I think one of the three great political contributions Andrew made was undoubtedly the role that he played in preparing Papua New Guinea for independence. It is one of the gratifying things of politics that the two people who did a lot to bring PNG to independence were Andrew Peacock from the Liberal Party and Gough Whitlam from the Labor Party.

I think Andrew's role as foreign minister was very distinguished. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and I are the only members in this place who sat in government with Andrew. He certainly was in total command of his brief, especially when he made contributions to cabinet on foreign policy issues. He had a few scraps with Malcolm Fraser. The most celebrated was the argument about the timing rather than the principle of the withdrawal of recognition of the Pol Pot regime in the then Kampuchea. His career as foreign minister was very distinguished.

As the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has indicated, after the 1980 election the Liberal Party entered a period of some turbulence in which the relationship between Malcolm and Andrew was very much at the centre. There is no doubt that Andrew's performance as Leader of the Opposition in the 1984 campaign, when we entered the campaign a long way behind and ended up taking seats from the government, remains a great feather in his cap as a political campaigner. He deserves all of the kind things that have been said about his contribution to that election campaign.

One aspect that I observed about Andrew that I have not heard mentioned today is the very close relationship that he enjoys with his three daughters. People have not often described Andrew as a family man. I think in many ways he is a very good family man. He has a very close association with those three girls—something that I was very conscious of in the discussions I had with him over the last couple of years. They always came to his political meetings. On the last occasion that he addressed his electorate committee in Melbourne last week, he was accompanied by one of his children.

I join other people in wishing Andrew well. I hope he has a very happy post-parliamentary career. He has been a very significant figure, not only in the Liberal Party. Over the years we may have had our difficulties, but we have shared a number of things in common. One of those things was that we, like so many people on both sides of the House, have devoted all of our lives to our political cause. He was the President of the Victorian Young Liberals; I was the President of the New South Wales Young Liberals—a few years apart. He entered parliament some eight years before I did, but he made a very significant contribution.

I am very happy to say, not just because this is in the nature of a political valedictory, although not a human valedictory—long may that day be deferred—that in later years I think we reached a better understanding of each other's aspirations, personalities and contributions. I do not pretend that we were not engaged in very difficult argumentation on occasions. That would be an insult to the memories and intelligence of the people in this parliament. But, as so often happens in life, you grow older, a bit more mature, sophisticated, mellow and intelligent, and you learn from those experiences. I certainly have. To you, Andrew, and your three daughters, I wish you well in your future life.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Briefly, I want to recognise the great contribution that Andrew Peacock made to this parliament and this nation. I first met him when he was in the Liberal Party organisation in Victoria and I was in the then Country Party organisation in Victoria. As we all know, particularly Victorians, the relationships between the two parties have not always been brilliant. They are excellent now and long may that be the case.

PARA.TAB: With Andrew's retirement from parliament, I think I am now the fourth longest serving member of this establishment. I have been watching him since 1971. After watching him in the formal presence of this House and the other parliament, I recognise him as an outstanding and always honourable parliamentarian.

Informally, as I came to know Andrew personally over the years, I found him to be, privately, equally straight and honourable. He was a genuinely friendly person, and that was the case whether he was at the top or in one of those periods when he was not at the top in the party or in parliament. He always had time to chat. I think that was a great attribute; it is one that he still has.

I am sorry that he was deprived of the opportunity to complete his career in a very senior position in government. I say that not just for his sake but for all of us on this side of parliament. Nevertheless, he has every reason to feel satisfied that he made an outstanding contribution to this parliament, to this nation and beyond—internationally. I wish him well in his new life.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I take the opportunity to place on the record my personal thanks to Andrew Peacock, the former member for Kooyong, former Leader of the Liberal Party and former Leader of the Opposition, for the opportunities that he has given to me. He invited me first to serve as shadow minister for the Australian Capital Territory and later as shadow minister for immigration and ethnic affairs—opportunities that I have valued. The trust he had in my judgment and capacities to handle those positions was something that I appreciated. I simply want to record my thanks at this time.

PARA.TAB: As has been mentioned by so many who have spoken before, Andrew Peacock worked tirelessly in many ways for me in my electorate. He appeared first on the scene at the Eastwood Masonic Hall in Rowe Street, Eastwood—it is now in the electorate of Bennelong—in September 1973 in the lead-up to the by-election in which I first stood. For something like 21 years—that often goes unnoticed and I am not always unhappy about that—I have served in the parliament with Andrew Peacock. I do not claim to be his closest friend in the parliament. I do not claim many friends within the parliament. I recognise that in a sense we have professional relationships where we come together because of our shared interests.

In a sense, I do not have many of those very important personal statements to make about occasions shared together except for the distinct surprise that was occasioned to some Lebanese community leaders who were visiting my home one afternoon after Andrew Peacock had paid one of his occasional visits to Rosehill racecourse, which was relatively close to our home at Dundas. On that occasion he actually invited my wife to join him. I think he realised I do not have a particular affinity for either gambling or racing. The surprise of the Lebanese visitors when my wife came home with Andrew Peacock left them telling stories around the Lebanese community in Parramatta for many years to come. Each of those many stories, which we value, add a little lustre to our political life.

I always took an interest in the human rights aspect of foreign affairs and was particularly interested in events relating to Indonesia, East Timor and Cambodia. Over time we had many discussions about the pragmatic views that a person who was going to pursue Australia's foreign policy interests had to take on some of these questions and how to balance them with the very real concerns for the human beings who are involved in those matters. Certainly, from the discussions I had with Andrew Peacock in relation to those particular issues, I was very conscious of the sense in which the human aspect weighed heavily upon him as well. It was particularly gratifying for me to see his role in relation to Cambodia, after spending time there, again coming to a point where it has an elected government.

I think he made a very significant contribution to this parliament, which has been revealed in so many of the remarks made today. As has been said before, I think that if the opportunities had been there for him and for others on this side of the House to lead Australia as Prime Minister, this nation would have been very much better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to add my voice to this celebration of the achievements of Andrew Peacock and to add the homage, if you like, of a younger generation to that of his peers, colleagues and contemporaries. When I arrived as a staffer in Canberra, I did not quite know what to expect from Andrew Peacock but I found that in person he was an infinitely more sophisticated, subtle and substantial individual than his media image would allow. Grace, charm and good humour were the hallmarks of his dealings, even with the relatively junior staff member of a colleague.

PARA.TAB: Many who worked in this building would recall the night when the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced his first challenge to his predecessor. It was a night of extraordinary tension, intrigue and drama. At about two in the morning the announcement came across the public address system, `Would all members of the Labor caucus who have not yet made contact with Mr Keating please ring his office now.' It is my understanding that Mr Peacock was actually responsible for placing that announcement on the PA system. It was certainly typical of the good humour of the man that made him so well liked and well respected, even amongst those who did not always agree with him.

It is my firm belief that the young should learn from our elders and our betters. When I came to this parliament I quickly sought the advice of Andrew Peacock. I am pleased to say that I indeed received, enjoyed and was honoured by his counsel and his company in the time before he left this place. It is my hope that a new generation can be worthy of his example and build on his achievement.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to echo the sentiments of those who have spoken this evening about Andrew Peacock and make a couple of short comments. I am sure that all members of this place have a special place for the person who was leading their party at the time of their first election. Indeed, Andrew Peacock fits that bill for me.

PARA.TAB: I was, quite frankly, busy building a career during the 1980s, and the names of Howard and Peacock meant no more to me than the fact that they were leaders of the party that I so keenly supported. I had a great and abiding respect for both John Howard and Andrew Peacock, although I did not know either man personally. It was only during the 1990 election campaign when Andrew Peacock came to Ballarat that I spent a short time with him and then started what I hope is a good friendship with him.

My lasting memory of Andrew Peacock will be of him at the Ballarat airport. I think he had just arrived and, being a very keen smoker at that stage, as was I—I have certainly given up but I do not know whether Andrew has—he jumped off the plane and launched into his first cigarette. An unsuspecting trainee cameraman from channel 6, or Vic TV, was taking some panoramic views of the hills behind Ballarat. Andrew Peacock saw the camera going and gave this fellow a payout like I had never heard in my life because he had broken the rules. The rules were that you did not take photos of Andrew Peacock having a smoke when he got off the plane. It was a side of Andrew Peacock that I had not seen.

Later on, Andrew Peacock shook this fellow's hand and had a 10-minute discussion with him about life, after having scared three-years growth out of him. The cameraman told me what a delightful person Andrew Peacock was. I think the thing that will stay with me most though is the relationship between the member for Holt (Mr Duffy) and the member for Kooyong.

TALK.START.PARA: —They supported the right football team.

—They supported the wrong football team, but that is another matter entirely. When I came into this place what struck me the most was that my perception about the way life in politics should be run was shattered by these two because they had a friendship that I have no doubt—the member for Holt mentioned this tonight—will go well past politics. It was a mutual respect for men who are of great intelligence and great wit.

PARA.TAB: I hope that the story of Andrew Peacock and Michael Duffy is told outside this place because I think it really epitomises what politics should all be about. Perhaps the vitriol that we see in the new house as opposed to what I gather was the situation in the old house does not really indicate the way politics in this country is run. Indeed, there is the opportunity for members of opposing political parties to share a very close relationship like the one that Michael Duffy and Andrew Peacock shared. My views about the way I should conduct myself in this place were altered totally after having watched that relationship and appreciating what that relationship meant.

I hope that I will leave this place with friends and acquaintances on both sides of the political fence. That could not be achieved if it were not for the likes of Andrew Peacock and Michael Duffy. I am sure that Andrew will enjoy his time. I thank him for his part in my election—I am sure it was no small part—and I thank him for the contribution he has made to this parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I guess I stand late in this discussion about Andrew Peacock because his resignation from parliament makes me the most senior Liberal—I am told by some of my colleagues—in Australia. That does not mean to say I am glad to see him go; I am sorry, deeply sorry, to see him go. At my first party meeting in this place in 1966, Andrew and I sat together in the party room—and we did so for quite a while, until he became a minister. I only rise now to say that he is a good bloke, a fine fellow and he met all the qualifications that I personally, being a parliamentarian, require. He made me his opposition whip—I do not want to name the date—and we had 2 1/2 very happy years together. The House should be reminded at this time that the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) was on Andrew's staff during most of that period.

PARA.TAB: Andrew was good to work for. I shall not detail stories about him, for he will know the associations he and I shared for a very long period of time. He was always, above all things, an Australian. He thought always of what was best for Australia, he regarded the Liberal Party as part of that deal, but in the final analysis everything he ever did was in the best interests of Australia. It is a queer trick of fate that this eulogy, or whatever we are calling it, is not being broadcast, so Andrew will have to go through the dreadful experience of having to read all the Hansards and all the things that have been said this afternoon—and I say to Andrew, `So you should!'

Andrew was a very good person to be associated with in parliament—and I can say that of quite a number of my colleagues, I am pleased to say, on both sides of the House. But I am sorry that he has left us so abruptly. I am sorry he has left us with many of his ambitions unfulfilled. I wish him well in his private life—but, knowing Andrew, it will not be quite as private as he thinks it will be. He is a very well-known figure, and is regarded highly by most sections of the community. I wish him well and express my regret that he has resigned from parliament in the way that he has.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Andrew Peacock is, and has been for a very long time, a very substantial Australian. This place will miss him—we will miss his character, we will miss his participation, we will miss him because he is an individual.

PARA.TAB: I have not known Andrew Peacock for 30 years. I first met him very briefly in 1987 during an election campaign when standing for my then unwinnable seat of La Trobe. After that loss, I went back to work running my company and did not associate with politicians.

But then in 1990, with Andrew as the leader and my having stood for preselection and being honoured to be preselected, I had the opportunity to work with him in that election campaign. In a very real sense, I owe my being here in no small part to the fact that Andrew Peacock was the leader in that 1990 election campaign. There were nine of us who came into the House of Representatives as a result of that election, as well as two replacement members.

Having lost that election and having waited a very long time to find out that we were not successful, Andrew convened a meeting of all of us in the old Customs House in Melbourne to try to give us some information about our new roles in our new public life. I recall how well he accepted the loss. His demeanour at the time was pleasant and jovial. He did not display—at least outwardly—the sense of devastation he must have felt knowing that, for the second time, he had lost an election to lead the government. He was explaining to us the practical things that we needed to know to be MPs. He got around to the point of the salary. He mentioned the figure and, as I recall, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) piped up and asked, `A week?' Andrew said, `No, Peter; a month.'

During my early times in this place Andrew went out of his way to help me on two very difficult issues. The first issue was dealing, in a major respect, with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which was an issue of very serious concern in my electorate and in areas surrounding La Trobe. His advice was excellent, fastidious and certainly always worth following. He made himself freely available to give that advice. In putting forward a private member's bill for voluntary membership of association, I again sought his advice on the technicalities of the bill and those sections of the constitution which might have been used to empower such a device.

One night I walked into the whip's office where there was a large gathering. Andrew was sitting on the right side of the sofa. I sat down in the middle and we chatted. About three or four minutes later he got up and walked around the back of the sofa and sat down again on my left. I think it was Alan Cadman who said, `Andrew, why did you do that?' Andrew said, `I couldn't be seen to be sitting to the right of Bob Charles.' I wish Andrew well in the rest of his life. He has spent almost half of it in this place in the national capital serving the people of Australia. I wish him well in his future life and future career. I hope it brings him great happiness.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I first met Andrew Peacock during the 1975 federal campaign. Members will recall what a vigorous campaign that was. I was a candidate for the state election, which was to follow in March 1976. I was a pretty shy person at that time and I did not quite know what to call him. I did not know whether to call him `Your Honour', or `Mr Leader', or `Sir'. But Andrew had that happy knack of making people feel very relaxed about being involved in politics and I developed quite a good friendship with him. He regularly visited the Victorian parliament whilst I was a member from 1976 to 1988. Andrew would often drop in, have lunch and catch up on things political in the Victorian state parliament at the top end of Spring Street.

PARA.TAB: I want to place on record his support for me during the 1990 federal campaign when I was reborn as a federal member rather than as a state member. He was quite amazing during that campaign. I thank him for his support during that 1990 campaign. We have to remember that the class of 1990 was one of the biggest groups of Liberal MPs and National Party MPs to ever come into this place.

I have three things which I share a love of with Andrew Peacock. Firstly, there is the Bendigo connection. Secondly, there is the racing scene at Bendigo. If Andrew had a spare Saturday afternoon off and could get to Bendigo, he often came to the Bendigo races, met with the members of the Bendigo Jockey Club and participated in and enjoyed the racing scene. Thirdly, there is that famous Essendon Football Club, of which I have been a supporter for all of my life, and interest in football. Andrew, as we know, has been a very avid fan of the Essendon Football Club. I take this opportunity to wish Andrew every success in his new career. I am sure that he will make a success of that career, as he has done with his political career.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is a measure of the man that so many people on both sides of the House have said so many nice things today about Andrew Peacock. PARA.TAB: Subsequently, I was secretary to the government's committee on foreign affairs and defence. We had an extremely happy and active relationship during that period.
