DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 1 September.
Clause 3.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Before I call the next speaker, I will just remind the House that in considering this bill in detail we are up to clause 3 and, in particular, the opposition amendments Nos 5 to 12.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are back again debating the government's Aboriginal land fund bill. I notice some of the same faces around that we saw a couple of weeks ago. I am currently addressing my comments on this particular bill to the coalition's amendment. It is one of a series of amendments which would turn some pretty ordinary legislation into something that was moderately acceptable but, sadly, the government has so far been unwilling to accept our constructive suggestions.

PARA.TAB: I was really quite appalled to hear the minister say during the break that the coalition had been using the debate on this bill to filibuster. I was impressed with the efforts of honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), who is at the table, who must have spent some time during the break doing a fair bit of counting and reading. She observed that there had been 85 speakers in the debate in relation to amendments to this bill and of those, 43—just a majority—were from the government benches. Therefore, it was the government that was occupying the time. I do not think we should in any way be critical of that fact; indeed, I compliment the government on being able to make the time available to consider these matters in detail. I suspect we will taste the sword of its guillotine before too much longer, but at least there has been some opportunity to discuss these issues and the parliament is so often not granted that chance.

The particular clause we are dealing with now refers, amongst other things, to the question of maintaining secrecy where that is considered to be appropriate. The land corporation must ensure that, in dealing with sacred matters, the information is not disclosed and also decide whether disclosure would be inconsistent with the views or sensitivities of Aborigines or Torres Strait Islanders. Our amendment draws attention to the fact that that is really a wide-open door to hide almost any kind of unsatisfactory activities, and we are suggesting that when this type of clause is invoked that there should be a report to the minister on the details.

There has been, over recent times, a new development in this area with the Hindmarsh bridge decision, where people are basically asked to believe that the bridge is evil; the reason is secret and no-one can be told why. Clearly, if every time the corporation makes a decision about a piece of land it says the reason is secret, then there will be no opportunity for the public to test the legitimacy of that secret reason. I do not think we should allow a new industry to develop based on secret reasons.

If every time the government made an announcement, it could just say, `Well, we are going to do this, and the reason we are doing it is secret' and expect everybody to believe it, naturally, there would be widespread condemnation in the community. That is what the minister is asking the public to accept in this instance. The corporation can make a decision, tell everybody, `The reason we are doing it is secret,' and it is secret because one or two Aborigines regard the reason as a trust to themselves and no-one else can know why. If that sort of logic and reasoning is to follow through, there clearly will be a widespread opening for corruption and a widespread misuse of this particular section, and no-one will ever know whether the secrecy provisions are being used fairly or not. We are suggesting this obligation be placed and there be a report to the minister in those instances so there can be some degree of assessment as to whether the secrecy test is legitimate in that case.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13)Clause 3, page 10, at the end of proposed subsection 191N(2) add the following paragraphs:

TAB.TAB: "(d)the need to give priority in the purchase of land to land on which aboriginal people cannot claim native title under the Native Title Act 1993 or land concerning which aboriginal people cannot make applications under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976;
(e)the need to ensure that land which is the subject of a claim under the Native Title Act 1993 is not acquired;

(f)the need to give the upgrading of Aboriginal pastoral properties priority over the acquisition of land in areas where there are already substantial land holdings by Aboriginal people or corporations.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is at the core of the reason for the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. Honourable members will remember that, when first mention was made of the land fund, it was to be for those people who were not going to benefit from the Native Title Act or by association with the Aboriginal Land Rights Act of the Northern Territory. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has commented on that; he envisaged that only five per cent of the Aboriginal population would benefit from the fund as it is now set up. There was an expectation from the Aboriginal community that those people who were not in line to benefit from this bill in any way or to take advantage of the Native Title Act would benefit from the land fund. It was widely touted that it was for those who could not benefit.

PARA.TAB: I have looked through the Hansard, and the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns), the then the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, is a fairly good example. During the native title debate he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The stated purpose of the land fund is to provide a benefit to the majority of Aboriginal people who will not directly benefit from the Mabo decision.
That is the core of this amendment. The fund is directed at those who do not benefit from the Native Title Act. I will read out the exact wording of this amendment. It states:

TAB.TAB: "(d)the need to give priority in the purchase of land to land on which aboriginal people cannot claim native title under the Native Title Act 1993 or land concerning which aboriginal people cannot make applications under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976;
(e)the need to ensure that land which is the subject of a claim under the Native Title Act 1993 is not acquired;

(f)the need to give the upgrading of Aboriginal pastoral properties priority over the acquisition of land in areas where there are already substantial land holdings by Aboriginal people or corporations.".

SPEECH.PARA: I would have preferred to have paragraph (f) as a separate amendment because it is not key to the first two, but because it came in the same area the three paragraphs have been drafted as one amendment, so we will certainly take them together. However, I state at this stage that my main interest in the point I am making is paragraphs (d) and (e).

PARA.TAB: When the land fund bill came out, it was quite a surprise to both the coalition and many of the Aboriginal people I spoke to that there is no mention in it of those people who had suffered dispossession and who could not benefit from the Native Title Act. This was also the assumption of the Prime Minister. On 18 October 1993, a media statement by the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the bill—
referring to the Native Title Bill—

will make provision for a land acquisition fund to address the land needs of those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people whose dispossession from their land means they will be unlikely to benefit from the Mabo decision.
This was a very clear intention of the Prime Minister. He further elaborated on it on 30 June 1994 when he said:
. . . this will be a very small proportion of Aboriginal people because the majority have been forced from their traditional lands.

He was referring to those who would benefit from the Native Title Act. If that is not enough, the Prime Minister confirmed in writing his intention for the land fund bill. On 31 March 1994, he wrote to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory with these words:
The Government is establishing the Fund in recognition of the fact that many indigenous people have been dispossessed of their land and are unlikely to benefit from the native title legislation.

Nothing could be clearer than that. That is what we have included as our amendment to this bill. Priority should be given to those who have been dispossessed from their land and who do not have a chance to benefit under the Native Title Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to this proposed amendment comprehensively, and hopefully that will put a number of things on the record which will mean that there will be no further need for me to participate in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The first point I need to make is in respect of the proposed amendment No. 13, paragraph (d), in which the coalition again seeks to fetter, constrain and restrict the board of the Indigenous Land Corporation. Of course, what we do not see is similar constraints and directions being given to the board of any comparable statutory body. For example, it does not happen in the case of some major statutory commercial enterprises, and it does not happen in relation to comparable legislation in this portfolio, because the central purpose of establishing a board of experts and giving them the authority of the parliament to manage a corporation is to repose the trust of the parliament in those experts. Attendant to that in this bill is a very detailed regime of public accountability.

The government is not prepared to accept the first part of this amendment because there are some cases where Aboriginal people who may have a capacity to claim native title may have other needs that need to be addressed by the land fund bill that is coming into existence. The first obvious example is that people who have a form of native title may not have title and ownership over a very significant area of perhaps nearby land on which is a site of enormous significance culturally and spiritually to that community. Therefore, of course, there is obvious need for that community—and perhaps a whole region of people—to have an allocation of resources from the land fund.

Conversely, it may be that there are areas which are owned under native title and can be proven before the Native Title Tribunal which are of great cultural significance, but which may be of relatively little economic development potential for that community. Hence the need for flexibility on the part of the board.

This amendment, of course, is an amendment which can be regarded only as a slight change—perhaps a very slight change—to the bill. In fact, the coalition is now on the public record as confirming that all of its amendments are, in the words of the shadow minister, very slight. Given the fact of that acknowledgment, we can look forward to the principal members of the coalition—and perhaps the coalition as a whole—supporting this bill, if that is truly the position of the coalition.

The fact of the matter is that there was never any chance of the coalition supporting this bill. Every twist and turn on the part of the coalition does nothing to fool Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who have known very clearly right from the beginning the formal on-the-record commitment of the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer), who over a considerable period of time have put on the public record their opposition to the establishment of this fund.

The second part of the amendment under consideration is also unnecessary. The coalition has said that there is a need to ensure that land which is subject to a claim under the Native Title Act is not acquired. Such an amendment is clearly unnecessary because land that is available for purchase will be either freehold or leasehold and, therefore, on the advice to the government, native title will have been already extinguished, but any existing native title would be protected by the Native Title Act.

Proposed new paragraph 191N(2)(f) allows the board of the Indigenous Land Corporation the flexibility to determine what emphasis should be given to land management of existing pastoral properties. The suggestion that funding must necessarily be applied to pastoral properties ought to be rejected by the National Party because it would know that there are some properties that might well not be economically viable. It is not the government's view—and, I am sure, it will not be the view of the Indigenous Land Corporation—that good money should be put after bad. There is a need to retain the flexibility in the board to get proper management of these properties. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne Mr C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have been able to get into the chamber in time to comment on this debate before the adjournment. I understand that we are dealing with the coalition's amendment No. 13 dealing with proposed new subsection 191N(2). It was my understanding that the purpose of the land fund was to benefit those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who did not benefit under the Native Title Act. It surprises me that it would require the coalition to move such an amendment to put into the bill what the government did not have there in the first place. I find it surprising that the government would oppose such an amendment and not accept it outright, because it clearly is in line with the government's intentions with respect to the land fund.

PARA.TAB: In fact, incomprehensible as it may seem to some members of the government, the coalition is seeking that the government take its original position, which was to link the land fund to the Native Title Act and benefit those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who did not benefit under the Native Title Act. In fact, coalition members are seeking to do what the government is no longer doing—we are seeking to make sure that the land fund abides by the Native Title Act. That was the original intention of government members, but they have thrown that out of the window in the hope of scoring political points by opposing our amendments. The preamble to the Native Title Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to recognise that many Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders, because they have been dispossessed of their traditional lands, will be unable to assert native title rights and interests and that a special fund needs to be established to assist them to acquire land.

It is very clear that the government's plan was that the land fund would benefit those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who would not otherwise benefit under the Native Title Act. It is very clear that it is the coalition that is seeking to bring the government back to its potential ideal. It is the coalition that is forcing the government to wake up to the fact that it is seeking potential political points by opposing our amendment.

PARA.TAB: I ask the minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), to consider very seriously what he is doing in opposing this amendment. He knows—he and I have discussed it before, including across this chamber—of the bipartisan nature of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs in the last three years. It must irk him, as it irks me, that the government is opposing an amendment which so clearly is within the loop of the government's intentions with respect to both the Native Title Act and the land fund.

The final thing that the coalition is seeking to do is to ensure that moneys spent on the land fund in this particular area go to improving the properties that are currently under the ownership of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. No-one can deny that there have been very serious ramifications of land ownership which has not worked out for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and that there are very strong cases for extra funds to be directed in that area. And what better way to do so than with the land fund?

I cannot believe that the government would conceive of a position which opposed improving land currently owned by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. One of the reasons the government has given for opposing this is that it would require the government to spend money where the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders might not want to do it; that it would somehow preclude purchasing properties that surround current Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander properties—which, of course, is garbage.

The coalition's amendment encourages continual purchase around a certain area of land or pastoral properties which could be the subject of Aboriginal ownership. So the stated opposition of government members to the coalition's amendments is absurd, as is their opposition to all the amendments the coalition has been seeking to have included in the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994. The reason for that is that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has decided that Aboriginal affairs will be a battleground between the coalition and the government. More is the pity for the Australian electorate and particularly for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander welfare, which we all have discussed many times in this debate already.

I ask the minister to reconsider his position. I ask the government to understand that coalition members are genuinely seeking to have a bipartisan position on the land fund similar to the position we had on ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—If you were here for the ATSIC debate, which I was not, or if you speak to people who were, I am sure that other members—particularly the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown)—will tell you that the coalition sat down with the government and worked out an ATSIC we could all accept. So why can you not do that on the land fund? (Time expired)

The fact of the matter is that Aboriginal people have made very clear to this government what they require of this land fund bill and that is reflected in this legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —We are trying to be constructive.

—You may well be trying to be constructive. I have said previously that there are members of the opposition, and you are one of them, who have endeavoured to be constructive in their role in this place. I am not deprecating you for doing that. I am saying that your position is not that of the opposition. In fact, you represent a minority view within the opposition and you know you do. PARA.TAB: You have been saying a lot in this place about the role of the ILC. We are saying that the corporation should not be fettered in the way you want to fetter it. I am suggesting that in the context of this legislation the opposition's proposal should not and will not be supported by the government. TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today a former Deputy Premier of Western Australia, Mr David Parker, was sentenced to 12 months jail on each of seven charges of stealing from his election campaign account. Regrettably, the charges are to be served concurrently, which means that he will be in prison with his former boss, former WA Premier Brian Burke, for a maximum of only 12 months. This is but another episode in the shameful and ugly saga of WA Inc., as it is known.

PARA.TAB: The saga highlights the moral bankruptcy and political corruption of the Labor Party in Western Australia in particular and Australia in general. Indeed, the sentencing judge, Nigel Clarke, actually described Mr Parker's action as carrying `a strong whiff of corruption' and said that Mr Parker was avaricious, naive and conceited.

I ask the House to look back on the past year and at how the history books will record it for the Labor Party. We had the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) and the sandwich shop affair, the politically corrupt sports rorts affair involving the member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), the gaoling of Brian Burke, once touted as a future Labor prime minister, and the gaoling of David Parker today. What a shameful episode this has become in the history of the Labor Party. The likes of John Curtin would be turning in their graves to think—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I think the member made reference to politically corrupt arrangements that he said involved the honourable member for Canberra. I think that should be withdrawn. That is extremely offensive. It is an assertion which should not be made except in the form of a substantive motion. That is a very serious charge against the member for Canberra, a former minister.

—The honourable member in fact used the term, as you pointed out, `politically corrupt' and, as I recall, during the course of debates in this place on many occasions that term has been deemed acceptable. It may not appeal to all members; nevertheless, in terms of parliamentary procedure it has been deemed to be acceptable in that it is not charging a member of this place with in fact being corrupt themselves. I would just say to members in this place that on issues of this nature their choice of language should be a bit more tolerant.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order: on the same issue, the term `politically corrupt' was definitely in specific relation to the member for Canberra. It was definitely in relation to her. It was therefore a specific allegation of political corruption, not a general one.
—I have already ruled on that. There is no point of order.

—That a former premier and deputy premier of Western Australia are now behind bars taints all politicians but in particular explains why politicians are held in such low esteem in this nation. As representatives of the people, you would think that our positions would hold respect, but we are rated alongside journalists and second-hand car salesmen in terms of credibility. That, of course, is hardly surprising when we have people who were entrusted to hold the highest and second highest positions in Western Australia now languishing behind bars.

PARA.TAB: What is worse is that the Labor Party is fully supportive of the actions of Burke and Parker. Mr Parker was found guilty of stealing $38,000 of campaign funds, yet the man who was the state secretary of the ALP at the time of those offences and who is now in the esteemed position of President of the Senate, Senator Michael Beahan, has actually justified these actions. He said that Mr Parker's theft was acceptable. How appalling that a senator for Western Australia, a representative of the people of Western Australia, can condone this criminal behaviour! He told the court last week—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Stirling is now going a bit too far in respect of a member of another place. I would again caution him on the choice of language he uses.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I am just quoting what Senator Beahan told the court last week, that political donations were used to pay off gambling debts—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. What the member for Stirling did was to say that Senator Beahan condoned the criminal behaviour—
—No, I have already ruled on the point of order. Resume your seat.

—He told the court last week that political donations were used to pay off gambling debts and other personal debts of political candidates and that this was acceptable. Such a position, however, has been determined by the court to be theft. Senator Beahan, a man in a position of great responsibility, has condoned that activity. I know that when the final chapter on WA Inc. is written—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. He has again stated that the President of the Senate has condoned criminal activity and I demand that it be withdrawn.

—The honourable member for Gilmore does go to a valid point. I have cautioned the honourable member for Stirling on his choice of terms. Again, if he wishes to go down that path, I am sure he will invite other points of order.
—They have succeeded in using up all of my time. (Time expired)

—I wish to speak about environmental protection. I am glad to see a range of members from various parts of the country in the chamber at the moment. The question should be put: what is the major threat to the continued existence of native fauna in this country? One could jump to the conclusion, as many do, that it is habitat destruction through woodchip or timber getting. As great a problem as woodchip or timber getting poses in habitat destruction, it is not, in fact, the greatest problem regarding the continued existence of native fauna. Is it the destruction of habitat through development? As great as that may be, it is not. In fact, the real and major threat to the continuation of native fauna in this country is posed by feral cats and foxes. I do not know whether many people in this place are aware of it, but I travel over vast distances in my electorate—although not as vast as the distances travelled by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I travelled 80,000 kilometres in my first 12 months. I am continually confronted by foxes and feral cats wherever I go.
—A feral member.
—Yes, there are a few feral members around at various times, too.
—Order! The honourable member for Stirling has had his go and the honourable member for Gilmore might not respond.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker, I will not. Part of the problem has been that, as with smokers in our community, shooters have been put in a position where they are virtually as popular as an STD. The net outcome is as tragic and as horrible as the Hoddle Street and Strathfield massacres. It has led to a situation where many people on the land, because of a lack of knowledge about people who may or may not come to shoot on their properties, have determined that the safest bet is to preclude those people from their properties. The result over the last 10 or 15 years has been a dramatic explosion in the population of feral cats and, in particular, feral foxes—not that foxes are anything other than feral, but I think we should continue to call them that.

PARA.TAB: I have had some contact with the Snowy Mountains Environmental Alliance. The spokesman for that alliance, Mr Peter Muller, from Thredbo, has convinced me that it would be in the interests of this government and in the interests of environmental protection for us to impose a bounty on feral cats and feral foxes. We would need a substantial bounty, something between $10 and $20. If we do not do this, I believe that all other actions in terms of the environment, protection of wildlife areas and wilderness and the elimination of some industries will be in vain.

I noted recently in a shooting magazine that a number of shooters went to an area in the Northern Territory which was so far away from townships that they felt they would not find any feral animals. They ended up bagging something like 200 feral cats in an area which would not be seen as a place which could possibly support that population. The reason why it supported that population is that man has introduced ready water supplies. Whereas these animals would not previously have been able to inhabit such arid areas, with access to ready water supplies such as bores they are able to inhabit these areas. If people in the Snowy Mountains Environmental Alliance can see that the Kosciusko National Park is in danger, and if feral cats and feral foxes are able to exist in the far-flung, dry parts of our continent, I believe we have a problem which is far greater than any of us can imagine.

If we do not take these animals out, and if we do not do it quickly, then I do not believe that there will be anything to hand on to our children. I do not believe that there will be any native fauna left for the future. I ask that all parties—Labor, Liberal and National—and Independents have a good look at this. Please do not look at it as if people who shoot have some sort of plague or sexually transmitted disease. These people have a sport. Many of them—and I have been one of them in the past—have a conscience about the continued existence of our fauna and our environment and many of them are prepared to assist. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about a problem which is now bedevilling so many of Australia's urban areas; namely, telecommunications installations, mobile phone towers, which are sprouting like mushrooms in the cities and towns of our country. We do not know the health risks that these towers pose, but we do know the aesthetic outrage that so many of them actually engender. The problem is that the telecommunications rules permitted by this government do not adequately provide for better consultation and better communication between telecommunications companies and residents.

PARA.TAB: I have had a number of instances of this in my own electorate. In Harbord, Optus attempted to put up a 30-metre mobile phone base station in the grounds of a hospital and next door to a child-care facility. Luckily this has been defeated thanks to the efforts of local residents Glenda Dorro and Ann Birchfield and also thanks to the good sense of Optus, which withdrew once it realised just how deep local opposition to this installation was. Unfortunately, there is another situation in the electorate of Warringah and this time the company Vodaphone has not shown the same good sense that Optus showed.

Vodaphone wants to install a mobile phone base station in the Tarquin block of flats in Fairlight. The body corporate council—that is to say not the body corporate but the council of the body corporate—agreed at what I believe was a very sparsely attended meeting to accept this installation, to give Vodaphone a lease. Vodaphone must have known that under the Strata Titles Act a lease of this sort requires not just a majority decision but the unanimous consent of all the members of the body corporate. Notwithstanding the fact that it did not have that, Vodaphone went ahead and began to carry out construction work in the Tarquin building.

It became clear once this was done that there was in fact massive opposition amongst the residents of Tarquin to what was being done. But instead of saying, `Let's stop. Let's consider. Let's consult,' the company's attitude has been `Let's push ahead. Let's bulldoze opposition. Let us steamroller our way into constructing this facility'. Vodaphone is now arguing that because the installation is, to some measure, already there, it has a licence to operate its installation even though the Strata Titles Act makes no provision whatsoever for a licence to be given by the body corporate.

What I am saying is that Vodaphone, as a responsible corporate citizen, must draw back. It must stop trying to intimidate the body corporate and residents via lawyers' letters. It must accept that there is significant opposition. I believe that what it must do is sit down and renegotiate this thing from scratch. Unless it can secure the unanimous consent of the residents of this building, it should not go ahead.

The problem is that the rules do not provide for sufficient consultation; they do not provide sufficiently for the rights of residents. In the Senate the coalition will shortly be moving to block the telecommunications code. We believe that there should be more emphasis on co-location. We believe that there should be a much longer consultation period between these companies and residents. We believe that the government should at least consider the possibility of a residents' veto for people living within the shadow of these towers.

The Telecommunications Act gives companies the virtual right to invade the properties of Australian citizens. It is most out of keeping with our national character that these companies should be given these sorts of rights. The coalition, by contrast, believes that in this instance citizens need to be put ahead of corporations. We believe in the importance of returning our neighbourhoods to those who live there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came into this House tonight to talk about the BIPR. But we had the performance of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) who used to feature himself as a megastar when he was on ABC radio—I do not know about that; I certainly never heard him—but his performance tonight was megasleaze.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the honourable member for Kalgoorlie well knows that the term `sleaze' is unparliamentary and, as a consequence, he should withdraw that remark.
—It will assist the chair if the member withdraws.
—I am not aware it is an unparliamentary term, but I will withdraw it. Is it not amazing how sensitive opposition members are; they can say what they like but if the cap fits, you wear it.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order—
—There is no point of order.

—I will be here all night, so you can make all the points of order you like. I am certainly no friend of Mr Parker. I consider him to be arrogant, opinionated, out of touch and lacking in commonsense. Certainly, he would not have a high opinion of me. I remember him telling me once that I would never get anywhere in the Australian Labor Party because I was far too left wing. None of those things is a crime. Honourable members on both sides would exactly fit that description.

PARA.TAB: The royal commission was the most expensive inquiry we ever had in Western Australia. It had rambling terms of reference. It has already cost over $30 million and will undoubtedly cost $40 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who set it up?

—I am well aware of who set it up and I will come to that. That royal commission cost the Australian public $40 million. What were the findings of the royal commission? The commission's written findings were: firstly, there was no evidence of any corrupt behaviour by the government in Western Australia; and, secondly, no evidence of illegality by any government member. It did say there were issues of what it described as `inappropriate behaviour'—not illegal, but inappropriate behaviour.

PARA.TAB: Mr Parker is not suffering from the royal commission but from the attack that went on afterwards. After spending all that amount of money there had to be scalps. I have spoken before about Brian Burke and I can say this about him: I was not a supporter of Burke because of his style. I never believed he was corrupt; I do not believe so now. I believe that he was not convicted on the evidence—the waffle by the judge who sent him to gaol was absolutely disgraceful.

Parker was convicted by a jury that was fed absolute venom by the media—McCarthyism at its height. For years the West Australian sat on its hands and all of a sudden it felt it had to atone. The stupidity of this jury decision was that the only two witnesses were dead. How could that jury have a better idea of their instructions to Parker than Parker himself?

Lang Hancock was a great man who, I believe, has not been honoured enough in this country. He was a man who saw his own character and enterprise attacked savagely by Sir Charles Court. I knew Lang Hancock well and I was an unabashed admirer of him. Lang Hancock was the first man to ever give me a donation, and I was very young at the time. I said to Lang Hancock, `I couldn't possibly take a donation from you unless I was absolutely sure there were no strings attached.' Lang Hancock looked at me distastefully and said, `What could you possibly do for me?' He went to his drawer, pulled out $2,000 and flicked the money across to me saying, `It's all in old bank notes. Do you want to count it?' I said, `No. I am very happy to accept it.' That was 1979 and that was the first donation I had. It was in a campaign where I was not expected to win and there was absolutely no suggestion of any sort of ties with that money at all, and the same would have applied to Mr Parker. That was the scenario.

However, these people were convicted because of this absolute torrid McCarthyism where evidence did not matter any more. People went into that jury saturated with venom from the only daily newspaper in Australia that had run this vendetta. I will say this before my time runs out: I have a file this thick on the performance of a very senior member of the Liberal Party which goes to corruption affecting the national interest—not over recent times but over 15 years. This will come out in due course. It is hard to get it out now because when this was taken to the police force they said, `Phooey, all your witnesses are dead.' That is the sort of justice we are getting in Western Australia. The honourable member opposite looking at me with his Christian outrage is one of the people I believe has a lot to answer for. I believe that, eventually, this will come out.
The truth is they tried to destroy the documentation of the Western Australian royal commission. We say that justice will come in the end. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat bemused by what the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) is trying to imply. I want to talk about the breadth and the depth of the corruption within the Labor Party in Western Australia. He has acknowledged that Brian Burke was corrupt.
—I have not said that at all. I said he wasn't.

—You said in your speech that he was corrupt. With the gaoling today of the former Deputy Premier of Western Australia, David Parker, for 12 months it is opportune to look back at the trail of deceit and dishonesty which lead the Labor Party to such ignominy. The names of those involved in bringing the single most devastating period of political putridness to this country are legion. It is not a Christian attack or anything else; it is an attack based on the fact that your party wasted a billion dollars worth of taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: Mr Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Kalgoorlie has had his go.
—You gave it away and you have to accept just as much responsibility as any other member of your party.
—Order! This may well be a very emotive issue for members from Western Australia; nevertheless, members are entitled to be heard and will be heard.

—Let me make those names clear: Parker, Burke, Edwards, Brush, Pearce—the list goes on for longer than the adjournment debate would allow. These names are just the visible tip of the problem. What about the people who knew about the stealing, about the graft and corruption, and yet remained silent? Surely they are just as culpable, yet they run for cover like frightened puppies when the truth comes out.

PARA.TAB: As I have indicated, David Parker, the former Deputy Premier of an Australian state, now stands convicted of seven charges of stealing—serious charges indeed. His former friend and Western Australian Premier Brian Burke is also at this moment in gaol after being convicted on similar and no less serious charges. Notwithstanding what the member for Kalgoorlie had to say about the Western Australian royal commission, the royal commission in its final report said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are satisfied that Mr Burke deliberately diverted the funds ($100,000) from this particular donation (Yosse Goldberg's $300,000) with the intention of using those funds for his own purposes.
The commission described his conduct as reprehensible. Later this year Mr Burke faces more charges of improperly using Labor Party funds for his own purposes.

PARA.TAB: This is the legacy of corruption. It is corruption so foul that almost every man, woman and child in the Labor Party has disowned both men. I note that the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) is here this evening. Even she said that she hardly worked with Mr Burke after he had finally received his sentence. It will be interesting to see how well she admits to knowing Mr Parker in light of today's developments.

The member for Fremantle is not the only Labor figure who moved through the stench of WA Inc. but said they refused to inhale. As I have said, the blame for this fiasco caused by the Labor Party in the mid-1980s rests with a lot more people than just the gaolbirds. The real tragedy here is the way the entire party allowed its own to steal, corrupt and lie with nothing so much as a word of caution.

The member for Kalgoorlie will recall the 1989 state election and how at the very time that election was being conducted the Premier of Western Australia was involved in a project dubbed the PICL project. He was in negotiations with Mr Bond concerning a project that eventually wasted $450 million of Western Australian taxpayers' money for nothing except blue sky. Even now after the convictions, after the revelations of the royal commission, we have Labor luminaries and lesser luminaries prepared to try to justify the conduct of these Labor Party parasites.

In defence of Mr Parker at the recent trial in Perth the President of the Senate, the then state secretary, admitted that the Labor Party used campaign funds for all sorts of interesting expenses. In the West Australian on 19 September he was quoted as defending the practice of paying one Labor candidate's gambling debts with donated money to prevent any bad publicity. `The party's image and reputation were at stake,' he said. `The only thing that mattered was winning the election,' he said. That just about sums up the Western Australian Labor Party's attitude to accountability and to proper conduct of government business.

The Western Australian Labor Party's attitude is win at all costs, ignoring all the foibles of your own mates—damn accountability, forget honesty, turn a blind eye to the filthy lucre of bribery and extortion. What a laudable platform on which to build a political party! All I can say is that if the member for Kalgoorlie seeks to defend that sort of behaviour in this chamber by trying to throw it back at us then God knows what he is up to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—
—What about Carmen?

—I've got the call, thank you. You don't run the chair yet. The WA Inc. royal commission documentation is absolutely clear and it is as I stated, not as the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) stated. Even so, he pulls back from saying that the royal commission said there was any illegality. There was none.

PARA.TAB: Let us take the PICL project, for example. The cost of the PICL project to the state was $5 million. That is well within the valuations that were given to the government by the experts of the day. I know a little about the PICL project. I believe it was a very useful project and it would have been very beneficial to the people of Western Australia. I approached ICI, a very large chemical company, during the height of the battle. I said, `I know you people have been looking at this. I want you to come clean with me.' They said, `Yes, we have been looking at it. In our view the return on capital is not good enough. We are looking for something like 30 per cent. We believe the return on capital will be something like 17 per cent.' But, they said, for a government which has other priorities, such as employment, and has to use the gas, which it was forced to do because Charles Court signed a take or pay contract, the contract that nearly sent Western Australia broke—because of those parameters, we think it is a good project and we would like a window into it.' I asked, `What's a window?' They said, `Five or 10 per cent; no more than 10 per cent.' I asked, `Would you buy 10 per cent at the present valuation?' They said, `Yes we would.' I said `I suppose you would want to manage it then.' They said, `No. It is our view that Alan Bond has assembled the best management team in the world. We could do no better. We would like someone on the board but we don't want to interfere in the management.'

That was the impression given. I tried to communicate that to Dowding, but Dowding's office was in a siege mode and had already decided that it was going to wrap it up? Why? Because it was operating on the advice of those great economic geniuses Wran and Turnbull who said, `If you pull the plug, Bond will be broke in a couple of months and he won't bother you.' They were about two years out in their timing. That was the situation with the PICL project. It was a very good project that was destroyed by lack of intestinal fortitude on Dowding's part and by the continual sniping of the opposition.

The royal commission findings were that there was no evidence of corruption or illegality. But we see people like the honourable member opposite, the honourable member for Moore—and it is done repeatedly in Western Australia—taking the money that was lost and saying that it was lost in Rothwells, buttressing Rothwells. Then they say that it was lost in PICL and they add the two together. The truth was that no money was lost in Rothwells because it was rolled into PICL. The money can be lost only once.

But, not surprisingly, those opposite know nothing about business and they are obviously hell-bent on double counting. The reality is this: the economy in Western Australia was probably second only to Queensland. The truth is that Bjelke-Petersen left the economy of Queensland in an excellent state. Western Australia was the next best. Western Australia had never been in a recession. We did not have an official recession because of the good groundwork laid by the Burke government. Had the Burke government not decided on that long weekend to bail out Rothwells there would have been a catastrophe. There would probably have been 10,000 jobs lost and wholesale panic in the stock market. The government took the only reasonable action.

Senator Crichton-Browne, the only one on the Liberal side from Western Australia who has any understanding of business at all, said to me, and he has kept his word, `You will never hear a word out of me about so-called WA Inc. because in my view the government will be the last to know. If it happened tomorrow the government would do it all over again.' We saw that happen, on a smaller scale albeit, when the Liberal government moved to bail out the Albany cannery. It just so happened that the directors were also creditors and all members of the Liberal Party. I do not blame them for doing that.

We saw what happened in Victoria when the government there said after Pyramid,`Oh, hands off. It's nothing to do with us.' There was a great crescendo in the media and the government lasted 48 hours. What the government did in Western Australia was the correct thing to do at the time.

I turn now to the teachers union. We bailed out the teachers credit union. We guaranteed that people did not lose their money. It was a sensible thing for responsible government. Why did this happen? For 20 years you had a controller of credit unions appointed by the Liberal Party who did nothing. The Labor Party appointed a controller of credit unions and said, `This whole thing stinks. It is wrong' and pulled the plug on it. The Labor government therefore bailed out 20 years of incompetence and dishonesty by the Court government. Those are the facts of the matter. This will eventually come out because we were able, in the face of strong moves by people such as you, to destroy the records of the royal commission. The truth will come out.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 30 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What (a) criteria, (b) guidelines and (c) principles were used in allocating funds to the SBS in the 1994-95 Budget.
(2) Have he and his Department evaluated which areas of Australia are to receive SBS; if so, which areas are to receive SBS.
(3) Which areas are yet to receive funding and what are the details regarding the criteria and guidelines referred to in part (1).
(4) Have (a) Albury-Wodonga, (b) Southern Riverina and (c) North-east Victoria been evaluated against the guidelines and criteria; if so, what was the evaluation of each.
(5) What priorities have been allocated to the areas which have not yet been funded.
(6) What priorities were allocated to areas seeking funding in the 1994-95 Budget.
(7) How were the priorities determined.
(8) Were (a) Albury-Wodonga, (b) Southern Riverina and (c) North-east Victoria excluded from funding in the 1994-95 Budget; if so, why.
(9) Did the areas referred to in part (8) fail to meet any guideline or criterion; if so, what are the details.
(10) What further information, research or action would be required to ensure that the areas referred to in part (8) are funded in the next round of SBS funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a)-(c) Following a review of triennial funding arrangements, the Government agreed in the context of the 1994/95 Budget to maintain ABC and SBS base funding levels in real terms and to provide guaranteed funding for a further three years.

The Government also agreed to the provision of a further $3m to the SBS over the next three years for research in relation to its digital transmission requirements and replacement of obsolete production equipment.

The Government provides funding to the National Transmission Agency (NTA) for the construction, operation and maintenance of transmission facilities to transmit the programs of the ABC and the SBS. Government decisions in relation to provision of funds for the extension of national broadcasting services are based primarily on the need to achieve the most cost-effective use of scarce resources.

(2)&(3) In the context of the 1994/95 Budget the Government announced that it would provide a further $4.9m for construction and $0.45m for operation to the NTA in 1995/96 to extend terrestrial transmission of SBS television to two more regions, Richmond/Tweed in NSW and Wide Bay in QLD. A further $0.9m will be provided annually for continuing operating costs. These centres were chosen by the Government because they provided the largest audience coverage which could be achieved by the provision of new transmission facilities, thus enabling a more cost effective use of resources relative to other regions. The extension of SBS television will provide access to the service for a further 286,000 people in the Richmond/Tweed region and 268,000 people in the Wide Bay region (total 554,000). By comparison, it is estimated that the extension of SBS television to the Upper Murray region (including Albury/ Wodonga) would provide coverage to between 135,000 and 150,000 people.
(4)&(5) The claims of other regions will be considered by the Government in future budgets.

(10) The Government is aware of strong demand for access to SBS television. The views and needs of residents of (a) Albury-Wodonga, (b) Southern Riverina and (c) North-east Victoria along with the claims of other areas will be taken into account when further extensions are considered.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) ruled that donations to the Queensland Ambulance Service are no longer tax deductible; if so, is this a consequence of the Queensland Government changing the service to a government authority to which the tax deductibility enjoyed by private benevolent institutions is not available.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that of the service's 1993-94 budget, $1,000,000 was derived from bequests and donations.
(3) Has the impact of the ATO's ruling on the fund raising capacity of the service been assessed.
(4) Will he reverse the ATO's ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Donations to the Queensland Ambulance Service are not tax deductible.

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that, in response to a query by the Queensland State Bureau of Emergency Services, the activities and objects of the Queensland Ambulance Service were reviewed by the ATO and the decision was made that the Service is not a public benevolent institution under item 4.1.1 of table 4 in subsection 78(4) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (the Act).

The Queensland Ambulance Service, as an organ of the Queensland Government, falls outside the definition of a public benevolent institution. The view of the ATO is based on the decision of the Full Federal Court in Metropolitan Fire Brigade v FC of T (1991) 91 ATC 4052. This decision has become established authority for the view that a government body performing the accepted functions of government does not qualify for public benevolent institution status. This is because, unlike voluntary organisations performing the same functions, the necessary benevolence criteria are not satisfied. Such bodies are simply performing the accepted functions of government.

The Commissioner has also advised that when determining whether an organisation or fund is eligible for tax deduction gift status, the ATO considers each case on its merits and applies the criteria set down in the income tax law. The ATO has not received nor sought any advice regarding the extent to which the Queensland Ambulance Service derives income from bequests and donations. In any event, this information would not form part of the decision making process in determining whether an organisation is entitled to tax deductible gift status.
(2) Yes.
(3) No. Please see my answer to part (1) for an explanation.

(4) The Commissioner of Taxation is responsible for the administration and interpretation of the tax law. The Commissioner has advised that the decision not to grant public benevolent institution status to the Queensland Ambulance Service has been made on the correct application of the law as it stands at the present time and as endorsed by the Full Federal Court.

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article entitled `Government sends mixed signals on railways' in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 June 1994 which indicated that the National Rail Corporation is planning to spend $300 million on 100 new diesel locomotives.

(2) Will the Government fund the purchase of 100 new locomotives; if so, (a) is this contrary to the advice of the Bureau of Industry Economics, (b) from where will the locomotives be purchased and why and (c) will the Government provide a payment guarantee on behalf of the National Rail Corporation to the successful tenderer.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) National Rail has been established as a company to operate on a strictly commercial basis and has three shareholders: the Commonwealth, the New South Wales and Victorian Governments. The decision to purchase new locomotives, and the selection of a tenderer to supply these locomotives, are matters for National Rail, not its shareholders. The funding of any such purchase is also a matter for the Corporation and not for any one of its shareholders, who collectively agreed, when establishing the company, not to guarantee any borrowings by it.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Industrial Relations: Electronic Information

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What services does the Minister's Department, or government enterprises for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility, provide, or will it provide, using public access points for the distribution of electronic information in regional, district or suburban centres around Australia.
(2) How will each service referred to in part (1) be accommodated and operated.
(3) What consideration has been given to using Australia's extensive network of municipal libraries to house the services and foster public access.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(3) The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Worksafe Australia) holds and disseminates authoritative Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) information in hard copy and electronic format. Through its Library, Worksafe is responsible for the national OHS collection of bibliographic material which is listed on the Australian Bibliographic Network (ABN) and is therefore accessible through State, regional and municipal libraries. The Library is able to conduct searches of Australian and overseas databases; requests for such services (at a fee) are able to be received from members of the public either to Worksafe or through their local library. The Library is also connected to Internet (via AARNet, the global email network) and therefore is able to obtain OHS information from international academic institutions.

The Commission also publishes an electronic database of OHS material on cdrom, Worksafe Disc (`the Disc'). The second edition of the Disc is due for release in October 1994, supported by a new marketing campaign from Worksafe's Publicity and Promotions Section. The Disc is available by subscription and can be obtained by contacting Worksafe Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: Is it a fact that if a Member or Senator writes to a senior officer in the Australian Defence Force or a public servant in the Minister's Department, the letter must be referred to the Minister before any action is taken; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Yes. Constitutionally, under our parliamentary democracy, I am accountable to the Parliament for the administration of the Department of Defence. I consider it appropriate therefore that I take responsibility for action in relation to correspondence received from Members or Senators.
